PROCTEXT.PARA: Madam SPEAKER (Hon. Joan Child) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. I refer to today's news reports that a refusenik demonstration held yesterday in Moscow was brutally dispersed by KGB operatives. In view of the Prime Minister's pleasure, shared by the Opposition, at the release last week of five refuseniks and his reported statement that this decision was more than mere tokenism, will he today express in the strongest possible terms his condemnation of the thuggery used at yesterday's demonstration to the Soviet Embassy in Canberra?

—Of course, I share with the Leader of the Opposition deep regret as to the reported action that is contained in his question. It would be quite consistent with all I have said both here and in the Soviet Union that this should be conveyed at an appropriate time to the Soviet authorities.

—Is the Minister for Community Services and Health aware of claims made by that well-known opponent of Medicare, Dr Jodhi Menon, of the Private Doctors Association, over the weekend of massive medifraud taking place within the Health Insurance Commission (HIC) by its employees? Can the Minister advise the House of what action he is taking to investigate these allegations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the claims made over the weekend by Dr Jodhi Menon of the Private Doctors Association. Dr Menon's extravagant claims about Medicare have been notable in the past for both their lack of substance and their lack of credibility. His latest claims are more extravagant than usual and they go beyond just attacking this Government; they include the previous Government and the Joint Committee of Public Accounts of this Parliament.

ANSWER.PARA: Dr Menon is reported to have claimed that Medicare has lost up to $5 billion in 10 years because of elaborate computer fraud involving bogus cheques allegedly issued by Health Insurance Commission employees. Considering that Medicare is not quite four years old, this is a remarkable revelation. Dr Menon bases his estimate on what he claims are 60 cases he knows of where bogus cheques have been sent out by the HIC incorrectly to doctors over the past five years. It is a pretty extraordinary piece of extrapolation which would be branded by most sensible people as pretty dubious economically, doing more credit to imagination than to economic sense, though I notice that the honourable member for O'Connor has hitched his star to these claims.

As explained to this House recently, Medicare has an extraordinarily low error rate, particularly given that Medicare pays for about 130 million services a year, For example, in September in New South Wales the error rate was only 0.29 per cent for direct bill claims and 2.14 per cent for patient claims. The 2.14 per cent for patient claims included minor keying errors and only 0.13 per cent were incorrect payments. Of course, clerical errors can occur, for example, where the doctor's provider number is not shown on account documents and staff are required to make a computer inquiry to try to locate the correct number. I am at least grateful to Dr Menon that, by implication, he is urging doctors to include their provider numbers and properly itemise accounts so that such future clerical errors can be avoided.

While the claims of Dr Menon appear to have very little substance, they are, nevertheless, extremely serious in that he alleges massive criminality by HIC staff throughout Australia under both this Government and the previous Government. If Dr Menon has concrete proof that this has occurred-as he claims to have-he should have provided that information to allow the matter to be fully investigated. As he has not done so, I have today requested the Australian Federal Police to arrange to interview Dr Menon so that he can provide the alleged proof.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Prime Minister: What commitments did Mr Mikhail Gorbachev or other Soviet officials give to the Prime Minister on Afghanistan, Cam Ranh Bay and Vietnam's withdrawal from Cambodia which enable him to make the judgment that the Soviet Union can and should play a greater role in the Asia-Pacific region?

—As is so often the case when members of the Opposition are talking about these matters, they content themselves with less than the full statement of what is said by spokespersons on this side of the House. Madam Speaker, you will recall that I referred to a place for a constructive role by the Soviet Union, but, of course, members of the Opposition would not want to include the adjective because it would not suit their purposes. I will be making a detailed statement to the House tomorrow afternoon in a way which will cover the issues involved in the honourable member's question. If, after that, he wants to address any further question to me, I will be more than happy to answer it.
—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Can he inform the House of any further developments following his representations in Moscow last week on the issue of human rights?
—Order!

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I deeply regret that those opposite are unable on this issue to address themselves to the realities of the tragedies involved and the advances that have been made. As the honourable member for Hinkler will know, in Moscow last week I raised the matter of human rights issues generally with the Soviet leadership, including the issue of the rights of Soviet Jews to leave the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics if they so choose, and also the question of the right of Soviet citizens to reunite with their families in Australia. I made representations on behalf of people in both categories in my discussions both with General Secretary Gorbachev and with Prime Minister Ryzhkov. I, and others with me, had the deeply moving experience of meeting a number of Jewish refuseniks privately at the Australian Embassy. There is no doubt about the tragedy of the lives of these people. As I said in answer to the first question from the Leader of the Opposition, it is to be deplored that the tragedy of these people is further added to by their treatment at the hands of some Soviet citizens.

ANSWER.PARA: At the same time, we recognise and we welcome the fact that the Soviet authorities have taken some positive steps in this area in recent months. I would hope that all honourable members of this House share with me the pleasure that I had in being informed before I left that five people-that is, Pavel Abramovich, his wife, Marta, Professor Alexander and Rosa Joffe and their daughter, Anna-have been given permission to leave the Soviet Union. I also raised the case of Mr Leonid Romanovsky, a family reunion applicant, whose application had been refused as recently as 29 November this year. He has waited seven years to be reunited with his wife, Danuta, who lives in Melbourne. I was very pleased, as I hope other members will be, to learn this morning that Mr Romanovsky has been given permission to leave the Soviet Union. That has been conveyed to his wife, Danuta, who lives in Melbourne. One can imagine her joy.
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it difficult to express my contempt for those on the other side of the House who, on an issue such as this, have a total incapacity to identify themselves in a realistic, constructive way with the cause of the people concerned. On an issue such as this they do no more than seek miserably to score political capital. Opposition members can go on like this; I hope in a sense that they do because they will be judged appropriately by the people of Australia for the contemptible rabble that they are. I and this Government will continue to press on the Soviet authorities the cases of all peoples in all these categories that I had the opportunity to raise personally in Moscow.

—I direct my question to the Prime Minister. It is supplementary to that asked by the honourable member for Mayo. What kind of political involvement, as distinct from economic involvement, does the Prime Minister want the Soviet Union to have in our part of the world? Will the Prime Minister give one example of the Soviet Union's constructive involvement in the countries where it had political involvement, such as Afghanistan, Cuba, Vietnam, Cambodia, Hungary, Czechoslovakia, Poland, East Germany, North Korea or the Baltic states?

—All the areas that the honourable gentleman raised in his question have been the subject of past representation by the Foreign Minister. On this visit to the Soviet Union they were the subject of representation by me to General Secretary Gorbachev and Prime Minister Ryzhkov. No one would have any doubt-I believe that no one in the world has any doubt-about the position of the Australian Government in regard to all these issues. What I have said-and I am in the company of such radical people as Mrs Thatcher and President Reagan in this respect-is that as we face the realities of the world in 1987 going into 1988, intelligent people will welcome the evident signs of change in the Soviet Union. This does not mean that we in this country, or Mrs Thatcher or President Reagan, endorse what has been done by the Soviet Union in the past in the areas that have been mentioned. I, together with Mrs Thatcher, President Reagan and others, have consistently pointed out the deep concern that we have about those matters. I did so again last week in Moscow. What I have said, what Thatcher says and what Reagan says is that--
—You have been played like a trout-a great successful exercise with Gorbachev.
—Order!
—Madam Speaker, do not worry about his babbling.
—The Prime Minister will continue his answer.

—We have said that it is intelligent to recognise the changes that are taking place. In referring to the Pacific area, it is a fact that the Soviet Union, whether or not the Leader of the Opposition wants to recognise the geography of the Pacific, is a Pacific power. It has, as a Pacific power, a right to have an interest in the region. That fact is recognised here and around the world. The question is: How will the Soviet Union exercise that power? I have been concerned to point out that it should be used in a constructive way. We do not regard the past as indicative of such constructive methods or approaches. If the Soviet Union, for instance, concludes with an island state in the Pacific a fisheries agreement, if that is desired by the Pacific state concerned, and if it is truly an economic agreement, that is something which is constructive for the Soviet Union and it is certainly constructive for the Pacific state concerned. What my Foreign Minister and I said to Mr Shevardnadze here in Australia in March of this year and what I repeated to the Soviet leadership in Moscow last week was this: we will be watching very closely to see, for instance, in the case of such fisheries agreements, that they are fisheries agreements and no more and not a cover for some exercise which would not be a constructive involvement in the affairs of the region. This is the sort of thing that we mean; it is the sort of thing that Mrs Thatcher means; it is the sort of thing that President Reagan means. As distinct from the extreme right wing elements in the United States with which this rabble opposite would associate themselves, we associate ourselves with the infinitely more constructive approach of President Reagan and Mrs Thatcher. If this world is to have the maximum opportunity of living in peace, we in the West must take a responsible and constructive approach to the new ideas that are emanating in the Soviet Union. That does not mean that we embrace them in respect of everything they might say or do but it does mean that we should adopt a constructive approach which is tempered with a caution born of the experience of the past.

—Has the Minister for Employment, Education and Training seen the comments of the Opposition spokesman on finance, Senator Stone, in which he claims that the education programs administered by the Minister constitute duplication and overlap? In particular, has he seen those remarks which complain of the work of 1,800 public servants working in the education area? Can the Minister advise the House of the duties performed by those members of his Department and of the programs they administer?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the comments of Senator Stone, the shadow Finance Minister, in a speech--
—The biggest tax dodger in the Parliament gets this question.
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will withdraw that comment.
—Madam Speaker, I withdraw the comment.
—Order! The honourable member will not argue with the Chair.
—I withdraw the remark that he is a tax dodger.
—Order! I warn the honourable member for O'Connor.
—On what basis?
—The Chair will not tolerate intrusions into personal lives.
—Are you going to ask him to sit down?
—Order! I have called the Minister to answer a question. I can do that without the interjection by the Leader of the National Party.
—More particularly when the allegations are completely untrue and without foundation.
—Order! The Minister will answer the question. The allegation has been withdrawn.

—I will, Madam Speaker. I did observe the comments by Senator Stone in his speech, which was perhaps more remarkable for its abuse of the policies of his own Party and, of course, the Liberal Party. I expect that it is a speech which will be more widely read on that side of the House than it will be on this side of the House. I was impressed by the extent of the inaccuracies in relation to some of the allegations about the administration of my Department.

ANSWER.PARA: In the first instance, he alleged that there were some 1,800 people in a department which he described as the Department of Education. Of course, for several months that Department has ceased to exist. The appropriate figure would be something like 1,400. This shows that he is out by a factor of a mere 30 per cent in relation to the number of people employed in the Department. Perhaps more remarkable was his complete misunderstanding of the work undertaken by the people in that Department that he was referring to, because over 900 of those people are responsible for administering the student allowance system which, of course, provides income support to young people in secondary and tertiary education. I am not quite sure whether the people of Queensland whom he purports to represent are aware that at last June more than 30,000 people were in receipt of Austudy, and that figure is likely to grow to 40,000 next year. I can only assume that the senator's criticism of the numbers of people employed by the Department reflected his intention to eliminate that particular program. It is totally facile to criticise the number of people employed in delivering a program, saying that those people are not necessary, without at the same time owning up to the fact that what one really has in mind is eliminating that important program. The program has meant that many people from poorer, low income families-indeed, there are 30,000 people in Queensland-have been able to continue in the secondary education system and go on to the tertiary system.

I notice in passing Senator Stone's own record in relation to discipline in staffing issues. I note that during the period from 1976 to 1982, when the Public Service increased by 6 per cent, there was an increase in the Department of the Treasury-Senator Stone's own department-of 30 per cent. There was a 30 per cent staff increase in his Department and a 6 per cent increase in the Public Service as a whole. In the Second Division, which is the most highly paid part of the Public Service, there was an increase in the Treasury of 36 per cent compared with 7.2 per cent for the Service as a whole. I am perfectly happy to consider the senator's criticism, but I think it ought to be considered in terms of its accuracy and the display, once again, of his extraordinary ignorance of the detail of Commonwealth administration. More importantly, it ought to be considered in relation to his own record.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister will be aware of three recent significant developments in relation to strategic defence initiative (SDI) research: firstly, last week's public admission by the Soviet Union that it has engaged in SDI-type research for nearly two decades; secondly, informed reports that Soviet research and development in certain areas of SDI-type technology is more advanced than that of the West; and, thirdly, today's reports that the Soviets may be prepared to put the SDI issue to one side in the negotiation of a long-range missile treaty. In view of these major developments, on what basis does the Government maintain its continued refusal to participate in SDI research and thus deny the participation of Australian scientists in exciting and innovative research connected with this program?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first two elements to which the right honourable gentleman referred may come to him as major new developments, but that is a reflection upon the state of his knowledge rather that the facts. It has been known that the Soviet Union has been engaged in elements equivalent to SDI research. That is known to us, the United States of America and anyone who has the beginnings of any knowledge in this area. That the Leader of the National Party of Australia has just become acquainted with these facts is a reflection not upon those facts but upon the abysmal state of his knowledge.

ANSWER.PARA: In Moscow last week when I appeared on a television program I was asked about the question of SDI. I made it clear to the interviewer that we should get the position straight and said, `Don't let us go on with this business that is implicit in your question to me, Mr Interviewer, that it is only the United States that is involved in SDI research'. I told the interviewer and, therefore, millions of Soviet television watchers-something which they may not have known-that their own country was engaged in this sort of research.

It is known in the United States and by anyone in the kindergarten of international politics that the Soviet Union has been engaged in such research. Equally, it has been suggested in regard to some elements of laser research that the Soviet Union may be in advance of the research being conducted in the United States. So let us get rid of this nonsense implicit in the question that the Leader of the National Party has just found out something which, in fact, has been well known to anyone with a minimal knowledge of events in this area. It makes no difference because we have known of these facts in the whole period in which we have formulated our position.

We do not endorse the research that is being done and the activities of those on either side. We endorse neither the SDI nor the comparable program which, as I have said, we have long known has been undertaken by the Soviet Union. We do not propose to change our longstanding decision to decline the invitation from the United States to participate in the research program supporting the SDI. As I have said in this place and outside it, our refusal to involve ourselves in that program in no way questions the integrity of the United States Government in pursuing SDI. We share the desire of the United States Government to move beyond a deterrence based solely on the threat of nuclear offensive retaliation. Our main concern, as I have made clear in this place and elsewhere, relates to the potential for SDI and the comparable Soviet program to lead to an intensification of the arms race.

We believe that priority should be given to the negotiation of balanced and verifiable reductions in the nuclear arsenals and we are encouraging both super-powers to move beyond the intermediate range nuclear force negotiations to deep reductions in strategic weapons. That is the position of this Government. It has been clear for a very long time and, among other things, it has been based upon the knowledge that we-and every other person with minimal interest in this area-have of the involvement and extent of Soviet research in that area. It is a tragedy that the question from the right honourable gentleman is simply another piece of evidence of the Opposition's incompetence and ignorance in this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Science and Small Business. What is the proposal known as Multifunction Polis? What have been the developments, if any, in relation to this proposal?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —In 1986 the Japanese Government first raised the issue of the establishment of a futuristic, science based city, to be set up in Australia, as a model of what urban development will be like in the twenty-first century. In January 1987, this proposal was put more formally by the Minister for International Trade and Industry-the MITI Minister-at the ninth Australia-Japan Ministerial Committee meeting here in Canberra. The original MITI proposal involved creating a city which would be funded by the private sector to be a focus for international technological and cultural development in the Pacific basin. There would be heavy emphasis on sophisticated communication and transport links, with appropriate leisure and living conditions. The Australian Government suggested the modification that, instead of being simply a bilateral arrangement between Australia and Japan, the concept should be broadened to be internationalised, or multilateralised as the bureaucrats say, to include non-Japanese firms, with internationally competitive high technology research and development activities forming the activity base of the Multifunction Polis so that it would provide a forum for international information and scientific and cultural exchange within the Pacific basin.

ANSWER.PARA: The matter was discussed last week in Christchurch, New Zealand, at the meeting of the Australian Industry and Technology Council, the body of Commonwealth and State Ministers responsible for industry and technology policy, attended also by the New Zealand Minister. I am glad to be able to report strong indications of support and interest from the States. As yet, some of the States are not firmly committed about the extent of their involvement, but it looks as if the next stage will be to respond to the Japanese by proposing a full scale feasibility study, largely funded by the private sector and to which the Commonwealth and States will make appropriate contributions.

Originally, the idea was to have a single centre. As can be imagined, with a federal system like ours that was not overwhelmingly popular among the States. The States, instead of having a single centre, preferred the idea of the Multifunction Polis like a hub and a wheel with something in Brisbane, Perth and in cities in the other States. There is a high degree of interest because all see that it could generate enormous economic activity in the States that are interested. There was a positive response in Christchurch.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. I refer the Prime Minister to his reported statement attacking Japan last week, when he said:

QUESTION.PARA: Australians have suffered a decline in their living standards. That is a result of the hypocrisy of those who have the capacity to preach to others and cannot apply it to their own economies.
I also refer the Prime Minister to a report prepared by the former Director of the Bureau of Agricultural Economics, Dr Andy Stoeckel, which states, inter alia:
Sixty per cent of Australia's effort should be directed at the domestic scene.
How does the Prime Minister reconcile his attempt to transfer the blame for Australia's economic predicament to other countries with, for example, the analysis in Dr Stoeckel's report?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me make clear what I said in Japan-which the honourable gentleman has sought to characterise as an attack on Japan. My observations were much broader than remarks just referring to Japan. In essence, what I had to say was in the context of an attack on this country that was made by a questioner. Very strangely, as Prime Minister of this country, I sought to defend the country. I know that that is an exercise that does not appeal very much to those honourable members opposite, but that is what I was about. I was indicating the view-not only a view that I hold, but also one that is held very widely in this country-that we are getting sick and tired of being told by some countries and some people, purporting to speak on behalf of some countries, that Australia is not facing up to what is economically, rationally necessary to do in respect of the economic challenge confronting it.

ANSWER.PARA: We are proud indeed of what has been done, particularly in regard to picking up the challenge which confronted us after seven years of neglect of those opposite. I would be here well beyond the end of Question Time were I to list the great range of changes that have been undertaken by this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just give us 15 minutes.

—Okay, I will just give honourable members 15 minutes. Let us look at the area of financial deregulation. Honourable members opposite had seven years. They were the people who talked about competition and deregulation but they sat on their collective butts and did nothing. We came in and deregulated the financial sector. Honourable members opposite talked about competition in the banking industry. Again, they sat on their collective butts and let a worn out, ossified Australian banking system continue to have a monopoly of operations in this country. We brought in 16 foreign banks, something honourable members opposite should have had the guts-but did not have the guts-to do. I point to what we did in regard to the steel industry. The contribution of honour- able members opposite to the steel industry when they were in government was to let it run down to the point where, when we came to office, the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd was saying that it was going to close the steel industry down. So, with imagination and economic intelligence, we saved the steel industry from the destruction that honourable members opposite, in fact, had inflicted on it. I could continue in regard to the deregulation and the reconstruction that has characterised the approach of this Government.

ANSWER.PARA: Therefore, on behalf not merely of the Government of this country but also of the people of this country, I was expressing the view that we were getting a little sick and tired of being told by others about what needed to be done in an economically rational way in this country. I make this point to the honourable gentleman who asked the question, because he knows the truth of what I say: in terms of the interest of the people of Japan, infinitely more damage has been done to their interests by their myopic, irrational and misguided policy in regard to agriculture than has ever been done by any suggestion of a threat of the continuity of supplies from this country. So it is absurd for Australia to be lectured about a lack of economic rationality by Japan, the United States or Europe.

Let me just point out the economic irrationality of European countries, which they have been trying to deal with at Copenhagen. Representatives of all those countries met there last weekend. They threw up their hands in horror, saying, `Yes, we know we are stupid; we know that we are irrational; but we have not got the political wit, will or wisdom to deal with it'. What has this meant for Europe? According to the same sort of economic analyses done within the Bureau of Agricultural Economics here, in Europe, as of this very day, there are one million more unemployed than there need be because of the stupid, irrational policies in regard to agriculture. Those countries have inflated their cost and price structures in a way that has meant that there are one million more people unemployed than there need be.

The United States of America subsidises its inefficient agricultural producers to the tune of something like $50 billion because they cannot compete on world markets with Australian producers and must be propped up. At present Soviet consumers get wheat at something like $50 a tonne less than United States consumers pay for their wheat. So the cost and price structure is propped up in a totally irrational way. Japanese consumers pay infinitely more for their agricultural products than they should; a million people in Europe are unemployed because of the irrational policies followed in that part of the world; and the same sort of situation applies in the United States. In that circumstance I, as Prime Minister of this country, will not sit silently by and be told that we are not economically rational when those countries, by their own stupidly irrational policies, are inflicting damage not only upon themselves but also upon the rest of the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Defence. Which nations are now involved in activities designed to preserve freedom of passage by commercial shipping through international waters in the Persian Gulf? How important is the continued trade in petroleum from the Gulf to Australia and the world?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable gentleman for his question. At present a substantial number of countries are engaged in escort activities associated with freedom of navigation in the Persian Gulf. Of course, the United States of America attracts a considerable amount of publicity in regard to its effort in that region. The Soviet Union has some nine ships operating in the Gulf. The British have a substantial number of ships, both destroyers and minehunters, in the area. The French and Italians also have ships operating in the Gulf, and the Dutch and Belgian governments are operating ships there as well, both warships and minehunters. In addition, the German Government has made available to the United States German warships for operation in the Mediterranean in order that United States assets can be freed to operate in the Gulf.

ANSWER.PARA: Basically, all the ships in the Gulf, in addition to being generally committed to freedom of navigation, operate in defence of vessels under their own flag. There are a couple of exceptions to this general rule. It seems that the Soviet Union follows the practice of offering protection to Eastern bloc vessels generally, given the events that occurred last week when a Romanian tanker got itself into trouble and was effectively protected by a Soviet destroyer that came to its assistance. The other exception-there may be others but I am aware of two-involves the Royal Navy, which has offered escort facilities to Australian vessels operating in the Gulf. One Australian vessel actively receives assistance or escort from the British whenever it enters the Gulf. The other three or four vessels that operate in the Gulf receive information on safe passage times from the Royal Navy and also receive escort assistance under what is called the buddy system. If they wish to avail themselves of that arrangement, they are allowed to join a British convoy passing through the Gulf.

The efficacy of the efforts of those escort ships can be seen in the statistics for this year. There have been some 150-plus attacks on shipping in the Gulf in the course of this year. Only two attacks on shipping in the course of the year have involved ships that have been under escort. One such attack was a mine incident involving the Bridgetown. Of course, a mine is essentially a passive instrument. It is not passive when it hits the ship but it is passive in the sense that it is laid for the purpose of being struck by any passing ship. The other instance related to the period after a ship had been escorted. When the ship was in a Kuwaiti port it was attacked by a silkworm missile. Otherwise vessels being escorted have been left alone; vessels not being escorted are attacked frequently.

As I said, all of the countries I mentioned are devoted to a policy of freedom of navigation in the Gulf. It is a principle which the Minister for Foreign Affairs upheld a couple of months ago when he was asked a question on that matter in this House. As I said, Australia receives assistance from the British in the operation of our own shipping. All of those countries also maintain strict neutrality. On the question of the outcome of the Iran-Iraq war, those ships operate in the Gulf in an even-handed fashion against any potential attackers, from whatever source.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Science and Small Business. Did the Chairman of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, Mr Neville Wran, and the CSIRO's Chief of the Division of Entomology fly to Mr Kerry Packer's property in the Barrington Tops area of New South Wales in a helicopter at the weekend? Did Mr Wran, at the conclusion of a meeting on Mr Packer's property, agree to allocate a quarter of a million dollars towards biological control of the noxious weed scotch broom which is a problem on the property? Was this decision taken by Mr Wran without consideration of the overall allocation of funds to CSIRO research? Is it also a fact that it is not a priority for CSIRO research? When the CSIRO is being forced to reduce dramatically its rural research effort, why is the CSIRO's rural research allocation being determined on the basis of Labor Party cronyism?
—I have no information at all about the matter raised. It is the first I have heard of it. Naturally, I shall check it out. It sounds rather unlikely to me but since I am on my feet--
—It has been running everywhere in the media today.

—Well, I shall have to check it out. If there were anything in it, Mr Wran would have contacted me already. The fact that he has not done so suggests that there is nothing to it. I may have done myself and the House a slight injustice when I answered a question last time from the honourable member for Page. I said that there would be a decline in relativity in the number of people involved in rural research compared with other areas, but that I thought there would be a small decline in the number of people employed directly in rural research. The injustice I did myself was that there is not a decline; there is a small increase in the number of people so employed. It is true that about 100 people have been persuaded to retire because in every research organisation it is an excellent idea to have a turnover, to have new people come in as new projects are addressed. The result is that, notwithstanding the fact that about 100 people are leaving, the Press reports, which have been extremely inaccurate, have failed to mention that there will be recruitments and the result is that there will be a small net gain in absolute figures.
—On a point of order, Madam Speaker: if that is the case, why have reductions taken place?
—Order! That is not a point of order, and the honourable member knows that. If he takes that liberty again, I shall deal with him.

—My question is also addressed to the Minister for Science and Small Business. Is the Minister aware of allegations that the Federal Government has secretly established a bomb-proof fortress at Deakin in Canberra to house computers designed to store confidential information on all Australians? Have those making the allegations claimed that the Minister for Science and Small Business would be the only member of the House capable of understanding the technical capacity of the computer equipment at Deakin and the threat that the equipment poses to the people of Australia? Has the Minister inspected the Deakin offices and are the allegations made by these people correct?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Dobell for his question. I was very flattered by the remarks of Mr Peter Sawyer, who was kind enough to suggest that I would be a wake-up if anything untoward was happening. I have had a number of letters on this subject, almost entirely from electors in the Federal seat of Richmond, as it happens, who have also been urging me as part of my patriotic duty to expose what was happening in Kent Street, Deakin. I went along twice, once unannounced in the comparatively early morning because I was eager to see the armed guards, not to mention the killer dogs, to have a look at this fortress. I had a rather dim recollection of that fortress because, as a member of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I visited it some years ago when it was still in the hands of Telecom Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Sawyer makes some very interesting allegations. First of all, he says it is a specially designed fortress, not just a run of the mill standard Canberra fortress, which was built in the past four years. In fact it was built in 1972-73 for Telecom Australia and has undergone no structural alterations since. I found it quite extraordinary that he should say that the building has no windows and no doors, which I must say seemed to me to pose some major problems about entry and exit, unless, of course, the entry was entirely subterranean. But I am glad to report that there are both windows and doors. He says that the walls are, in fact, 4 1/2 feet thick-he uses the imperial measurement-that is about 1.37 metres. My rough estimate, not having taken a ruler with me, is that the walls would be about 27 or 28 centimetres thick, a very small proportion--

TALK.START.PARA: —How thick is that?

—That is about 10 inches in the old measurement. He said there was a Facom computer inside worth between $25m and $28m, of a kind normally used only by the Central Intelligence Agency and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. Alas, even though the Government is very generous in providing funds for computerisation, I do not think it has been able to run to that kind of money. There was no sign of the Facom, nor am I persuaded that the Facom was hidden away in a cupboard somewhere just because it was known that I was coming. As I say, I called first without warning and found only two professional unarmed employees of Wormald International (Aust) Pty Ltd, who were working not just for the Department of Social Security but for a number of other clients who are in the building.

ANSWER.PARA: The conclusion I have reached is that what is going on there is no more sinister than anything else that happens in the Department of the Minister for Social Security. I understand that the Public Accounts Committee has also made an inspection, I think this morning, and I have little doubt that its observation will exactly tally with mine.

PETITION.TITLE: Importation of Radioactive Substances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth. We most strongly oppose the process of Food Irradiation by radioactive Cobalt 60 or any other radioactive substance.

Make unlawful the creation of a public nuisance by loitering.
Ensure the enforcement of laws which prohibit the public consumption of alcohol by under-age persons, and
Legislate to restrict the production, distribution and sale of material which depicts extreme violence.

PETITION.TITLE: Gymea Bay Post Office, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House should take all possible steps to prevent the closure of Gymea Bay Post Office.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

Intervene to stop the proposed closure and sale of land at Wallace Street, Macksville, and initiate action to have a permanent Depot built on the Army's Macksville land.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives of the Parliament of Australia assembled.

We, the undersigned, being appalled that the Government has set no penalty for the possession of child pornography, and has set no penalty for importing unclassified child pornography, do ask that Parliament urgently legislate to:
Make the importation of child pornography, and the possession of child pornography, and all tapes and goods banned by Customs, to be a criminal offence, with deterrent penalties, and
Close the Customs barriers to pornography in the A.C.T., in respect of X-rated videos, (and ER) and end the shameful Canberra trade, and the Mafia Connection.
Because 98% of Australians in other States have banned X-rated videos.
Because the trade is still flourishing, and it's availability escalates sexual crime.
Because importers of child pornography face only a fine for lying.
Because child pornography pedlars are safe if they cross a border, and cannot be extradited for a summary offence.

Because the government does not intervene in that.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled.

``The majority believes the creation of a new bureaucracy of 2000 public servants within the HIC [Health Insurance Commission], with the sole task of identifying every man, woman and child in Australia, is a wasteful exercise which will not address the problems of tax evasion and social security fraud but will provide the mechanism by which the very fabric of our society will be irreversibly altered, opening the way for the greatest attack on the privacy of individuals as the `Identity Bureau' identifies, monitors, and updates information on every person in Australia.'' PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the Speaker and the members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

PETITION.TITLE: Pine Gap
PETITION.PARA: We, the undersigned, call on the Federal Government to give notice to terminate the lease of the US base at Pine Gap before October 1986.
We believe that in the interests of world peace and the Australian people, this lease should be terminated and the base closed because Pine Gap is a spy base and war base:

Since it was opened in 1969, it has eavesdropped on Australian telephone and telex communications. Information obtained in this way was used by the CIA to destabilise the Whitlam Government in late 1975.

It provides communication facilities for CIA activity in countries throughout the world, much of which is connected with overthrowing other country's governments. Last year it became clear Pine Gap was spying on Greece.
The electronic and photographic information its satellites receive is used to select nuclear targets in the territory of the Soviet Union and its allies.
Many US military activities short of nuclear war are also co-ordinated by Pine Gap. These include the war against Vietnam and the invasion of Lebanon by US marines in 1984.
Pine Gap spends only a tiny percentage of its time monitoring arms control agreements, and even then the data gathered is so top-secret Australia has no access to it.
Pine Gap's role will be expanded under Reagan's Star Wars scheme to extend the arms race to outer space, threatening the existence of our planet.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The unintended consequences of the Government's recent Medicare decisions.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In bringing forward this matter of public importance, the unintended consequences of the Government's recent Medicare decisions, I state that we have to start to recognise that Medicare is generally having unintended consequences by its mere operation. Since I became the shadow Minister responsible for health every piece of health legislation bar one which re-allocated a mere $200,000 of benefits for a very limited period has dealt with increasing taxes-the levy was increased from one per cent to 1.25 per cent-or has been aimed at reducing or removing benefits under the various schemes. Nothing seems to be being done to reduce or remove the problems that are associated with this area which are materialising every day. The Federal Government is allocating $8,200m this year to health expenditure and $5,212m of that is allocated in the hospital and medical services area. The community cost of health services is in fact about $18,000m or an average of $25 a week. Health services are a community problem revolving around costs and benefits. Costs are escalating and benefits are reducing.

SPEECH.PARA: Today I do not want the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) to get up at the end of my speech and try to give us a history lesson or a political answer. We are talking about the objective of both parties, and that is to give Australians high quality and affordable health care. I am about to identify a number of areas where that is not happening. I sincerely hope the Minister will address those problems and not take a position of self-congratulation. We are talking about people's pain and suffering. We are talking about life and death. I hope the Minister and other Government speakers are sufficiently responsible to respond to the needs of the Australian people. The difference between him and me is only in direction. His idea is having total control of the system; ours is not.

I want to give two examples of what is happening in the community. I refer first to a letter addressed to the Minister on 30 June 1987. I will not read it as it is lengthy. It relates to a person living in the Newcastle area, a good Labor voting area, who suffered a leg injury as a young person in a shooting accident. He suffered further injury some two years later in a vehicle accident and now he suffers very severely as a result of that injury-in fact to the extent that he now receives an invalid pension and was granted sales tax exemption 1960, 1962 and 1974 for the purchase of special vehicles. Over a period he has taken so much medication that he has now been told that he can take no more because the medication has created an ulcer. He wrote telling the Minister all this. In November 1984 things had deteriorated so much that he got his invalid pension. He also told the Minister that the surgeons at the Newcastle Hospital have told him that he must have a knee replacement. At his most recent visit, just a few weeks back, he was told that he still has another two years to wait. He can no longer have reasonable pharmaceutical treatment because it has given him an ulcer. He says that he has been suffering also from anaemia, nausea and stomach and chest pains. The continued use of anti-inflammatory drugs over a period exceeding 25 years has irritated his system to the extent that a gastrointestinal ulcer has developed and he has been advised to cease taking the medication. I have a copy of the letter which the Minister's Department sent to that gentleman. It says:
There are waiting lists for elective surgery in public hospitals. However, I understand that all emergency patients are able to receive appropriate and timely treatment.

No encouragement is offered to that gentleman. That is one side of the problem. The other side has to do with costs and the fact that people are forced to rely on the private system. I quote from a letter:
I am writing to you concerning Medibank Private. I have rung my local member of Parliament . . . whom I believe has made a phone call to your Department regarding my complaint.

I have been Medibank Private since 1979 under the same code . . . which gave my family basic private hospital table cover. My rates have gone up every 4 or 5 months which I have been paying and have always paid in advance.
I was in . . . private hospital last October and . . . private hospital and the difference I had to pay was approximately $30 a day.
I returned to . . . private hospital this October.
I find that I had to pay a difference of $105 a day and after fourteen days $150 a day.

It seems that I have been paying these increases in payments and my code is still the same . . . but my coverage has dropped down to basic hospital cover and not basic private hospital cover. How can that be. If my cover has dropped back, how come I have been paying increases and my code has not altered. Could you please have this explained to me and could you please let other people know that although you pay your increases, keep up your payments and retain your code, your standard of cover drops.
Please help me to understand why I have wasted my money, I am no better off than someone with no cover at all.
It has cost me $1500 to get out of hospital.

That is the situation. The Minister has created public hospital queues and increasing costs in public hospitals with the result that people's private health cover, through Medibank Private or other private funds, is no longer adequate to assist them. The problem now is that every time the funds increase their charges, only the sick and the elderly remain as their customers. Young people think that they have a rather strange protection called Medicare. They think that is a protection because they do not use it in any meaningful way, such as going to hospital. There are public hospital queues and insufficient fund coverage generally for people on basic private cover to utilise the 9,000 vacant private hospital beds.

If the Minister thinks that I am the only person telling him that, let me remind him of the statements by Victorian Premier, John Cain, when he opened the Australian Hospital Association Conference recently. He said that the Government's policies were distorted incentives and were not logical. He said he was concerned that, by abolishing the private hospital subsidy and reducing Medicare benefits for out of hours services, the Commonwealth had distorted incentives and placed even greater pressure on the public hospital system. He was also critical of the Government's subsidies for private patients in public hospitals which, he said, gave the privately insured an incentive to use public rather than private hospitals. He said:
This incentive operates at a time when some patients wait for a public hospital bed and some private hospitals have only 60 per cent occupancy.

He went on to say that in Victoria at that time 26,288 people were waiting for elective surgery. Of course, the New South Wales Government does not keep figures relating to waiting lists. Let it tell me that if those lists were good news it would not publish them; that if those lists in New South Wales were to the benefit of Mr Unsworth and Mr Anderson they would not have them on the front page of the Sydney Morning Herald! They will not do so now because the figures are disastrous. As we know, people have died while they have waited to get into hospital. But we are told not to worry about that. When the matter was raised the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mr John Brown) got up and said that we should not worry about that; all these people died of natural causes. If one dies while waiting for some relief of pain and suffering it is of no particular assistance to say that.

In recent times there have been cutbacks in the health area. No doubt Senator Walsh has had something to say about that. The Minister's Department now has the second biggest one line item budget. He has been able to achieve that by calling up the computers. There is enough talk about computers in this place, but the great problem with computers is that they give only a physical evidence as to what is going on; they never give the people side of it. The computer told the Minister that too much money was being spent by dermatologists. The computer does not know that Australia has some of the highest incidence of sun cancers and associated conditions, such as keratosis, in the world. It is estimated by the Cancer Council and others that probably 125,000 Australians have skin cancers and do not know it, and that this is the cause of about 1,000 deaths a year. This was ignored. It was argued that it was all right to take some items off the schedule because doctors could still address skin cancer when people found out that they had this condition. However, people now have to play lotto. If they are sent off to the skin specialists and happen to have only the more common keratosis, which could, and probably will, turn into a skin cancer later, they cannot be treated under the schedule. If they choose to be treated while they are there, they will have to pay the full charge, which will probably be about $50. They have to pay that out of their pockets, and this is where the problem is-it is the people who are being hurt on these issues.

The honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear) is waiting to speak next and tip another bucket over the medical profession. That is part of a planned campaign. If the Minister is successful with some polling carried out by Australian Nationwide Opinion Polls Pty Ltd, no doubt he will want to tip the bucket over the medical people as well. Nevertheless, I see the honourable member for Canning as the back bench bunny at the moment. The point about all this is that the Minister did not get the doctors to do what he wants them to do. The doctors are still charging what they think is reasonable, and they do not make huge fortunes. People are paying as a consequence of the Minister's decision. He promised them good health services through Medicare. Even some who chose to keep private cover have found that that service does not work.

The computer also contains numbers which cover warts. To a computer, a wart is a wart; to many of us, it is something one gets on one's hand and is not a problem. However, the numbers also relate to venereal warts, which another part of the massive Department has declared a notifiable disease because it is so serious. This condition requires an operation. People are told by their doctors, frequently private doctors, that they can be operated on to have the warts removed-in the case of women, they are a precursor to cervical cancer-but that they will have to pay the full amount. There is an option. The patient can make a claim to the Medical Benefits Advisory Committee, as though people with such conditions would do that.

Consultant physicians-people who rely heavily on charging out their time-do not get paid for carrying out procedures. They can see only so many people in a day. In the Senate Estimates Committee D hearing on 22 October, the Department's officials agreed that, of 27 items put to them, 26 could not be handled by anybody else and would require more than three visits to a physician. Those items include such simple little things as chemotherapy for people dying of cancer! The computer said that too much money was being spent there. It inferred that these people could be shunted back to general practitioners, although the departmental head and other qualified people in the Department told the Senate Estimates Committee that they could not, and that lengthy treatment was needed. The physicians continue to charge $50, but whereas there used to be a rebate of about $40 for subsequent visits after three, it has now dropped to $18.75 or $21.25. In other words, each time people such as cancer sufferers go to a physician, they have to find $30 of their own money because the Minister is trying to save some money by bluffing the doctors into taking a drop in their remuneration. That, too, was recorded in the Senate Estimates Hansard, when one of the departmental officials said that that was the intention. It just so happened that the Minister has failed-and ordinary Australians are hurt.

Originally the rebate for lens extraction required by people suffering from cataracts-people who happen not to be able to see, and are nearly blind-was $650. Therefore, they had very little to pay themselves. But the rebate for this procedure has been dropped to $337.50. The rebate for a lens insertion, which usually goes with such treatment, has been dropped from $345 to $187.50. Therefore, for a $995 operation the patient has to find $470. These people are elderly, they are pensioners, and they have not got that sort of money. I refer to obstetrics-the business of having babies-because this Government claims to have concerns for womanhood. The independent arbitrator, the Layton Medicare Benefits Review Committee, set down a flat fee of $700 for that. The Government decided to make it $410. The obstetricians decided on $650 to $800. Therefore, the patient again is paying between $240 and $390. It is a crying shame that the Minister has not been able to do anything about this. He knows about it. He has received letters such as the one I read to him. He has ignored the situation and has not done anything to correct those unintended consequences. Of course, he must take the blame.

TALKER.NAME: Dr BLEWETT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Community Services and Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course it is easy to embark on destructive criticisms of health schemes in this country. However, what we have to point out is that the Opposition has now had five years in opposition and has not yet produced an agreed alternative to Medicare. It is easy to be destructive but the Opposition has proven over five years that it has a complete inability to be constructive. In fact, the Opposition has now had as many schemes in opposition as it had in government. One by one, each of those schemes has been rejected. The Opposition forgets entirely that before this Government came to power two million Australians were without full and proper health cover. In the years of opposition it has shifted from one health policy to another and, in fact, has had no alternative to the Medicare scheme. All it can do is to embark on destructive criticism.

SPEECH.PARA: In fact, in 1984 the Opposition went to the election with three health schemes. Last year, the Opposition had two more such schemes. Now I am told that the scheme the Opposition went to the people with in July has simply been dumped. Certainly it was rejected by the Australian people, who endorsed Medicare for a third time. That seems to have led the Opposition to abandon its last scheme. Of course, that last scheme had very little concern for families. We have heard the Opposition talking now about individual problems in relations to the Medicare schedule. However, I remind honourable members what the Opposition offered to the Australian people in July. The Opposition proposed to have families and individuals still paying a Medicare levy and, in addition, paying for private insurance. However, it was proposed that people not get health cover until they had paid the first $250 of their bills unless, of course, they took out extra insurance to cover that. This came from the party that now weeps about about particular cases. Yet that was the kind of policy that the Opposition offered the Australian people at the last election.

I am not surprised that the Opposition, having thought up the policy in three weeks, has dumped it in about four weeks. Even the latest efforts of the Opposition in terms of a health policy-I do not call it any more than that-contained elements of that policy to which I have referred. It came from the Opposition health spokesman, the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), when he gathered with his surgeon mates at a conference of the Australian Association of Surgeons. Very quickly indeed the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) brought him into line. I will have a little more to say in a moment about the alternative that he offered at that stage which, very quickly, had the Leader of the Opposition dressing him down.

Let me now refer to the decision we had to make about the Medicare benefit schedule in the May economic statement and the other decisions we have made. The honourable member for O'Connor said, `Let us talk about the problems in a serious and reasonable way'. As he rightly pointed out, health is one of the major elements of the Commonwealth Budget. This country has been facing major economic challenges which have required us to restructure this economy and to look very carefully at Government spending. Health is an integral part of that Budget. I believe that health costs, along with all the other elements of our budgetary policy, had to be examined and restrained in order that this country could deal with its economic problems. It is not possible to discuss the health issues of this country, as the honourable member for O'Connor did, without any reference to the economic challenges this country faces. Therefore, I acknowledged in the May statement that we would have to make some tough decisions in relation to the health budget. However, we were determined that they would be carefully targeted and that they would be appropriate decisions.

What we did was to target particular areas of concern in the medical benefits schedule in ways that should encourage good medical practice and more accurately reflect the cost of those services. They were the two things we were trying to do. The first was based on economic considerations and was designed to reflect accurately the cost of the services, and the second was designed to encourage good medical practice. In addition, we sought to remove from that schedule some potential financial incentives for abuse of some services. We were concerned, and any serious politician would have been concerned, that services provided under some parts of the schedule were over-rewarded by inappropriately high fees. We needed also to make adjustments to those fees to reflect the changing nature of medical practice or the reduced cost of services due to the introduction of high technology.

Can the Opposition not acknowledge that over the past 15 or 20 years very significant changes have occurred in medical technology which have transformed a number of medical procedures and processes? It was only fair and just that some of those matters be looked at. Again, the change we made in May in reducing to 75 per cent the rebate of schedule fee for in-hospital services was seen as the fairest and most sensitive way of achieving savings without causing widespread disruption and hardship. That change did not cause such hardships because the gap payments for those in-hospital services are covered by medical insurance. They are the only medical services in hospitals that are covered by this gap payments proposal. Therefore, patients were faced with no direct additional cost and only a minimal increase in health contribution rates as a result of that change.

So the whole May budgetary process gave recognition to the fact that we had to have economic restraint and that the relevant areas had to be targeted in the most responsible and fairest way. As I say, the Government determined on two major things it wanted to do. It wanted to effect some changes to the medical benefits schedule. Those changes produced a saving of $121m. At the same time we provided for an increase across the board in all fees, which cost the Government $151m. We were saying to one of the wealthiest professions in this country that we wanted it to show some of the restraint that ordinary working people in this country were asked to show. We asked it to show restraint in specific areas where we believed there was justification for modifying the schedule.

I shall deal with those areas, some of which the honourable member for O'Connor referred to in particular. The first was the area of consultant physicians. I point out that the decisions we made in this area received strong support from the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners. It is true, as I have acknowledged in this House, that the consultant physicians and patient groups have approached the Government with suggestions about how further changes to the schedule could improve the whole structure of consultant physician fees but at the same time achieve the Government's budgetary restraints. The physicians have put to government proposals that meet these objectives and the physicians' desire to modify the new fee structure. I hope that later this week I will be able to make a formal announcement about those new arrangements, which are the result of the Government's willingness to discuss proposed changes with the affected elements of the medical profession.

The argument is not whether a patient should have more than three visits to the consultant physician but the cost of many of those later visits. Again, responsible consultant physicians admit that there are many minor consultations throughout the process of treating illnesses, particularly long term and chronic illnesses, and that there are appropriate arguments for a reduction in the fees charged to long term patients. Though the consultant physicians are paid a very high fee for that first consultation-it is more than five times that paid to a general practitioner for a consultation-and substantial second and third consultation fees, all that the Government is saying is that it believes, and I think all thinking people in the profession would agree, that there is a strong case for arguing that many of the later consultations should be charged for at a somewhat lower rate.

I turn to the eye surgery issue that was raised by the honourable member for O'Connor. Of all the services within the schedule affected by the May economic statement, cataract surgery was clearly the most overrewarded. The previous fee for cataract removal and lens insertion-and these were performed in a single operation-was $820 when both were done together, as they were done most of the time. Usually the operating time was less than an hour. Of course, this fee was structured in the 1970s when patients were treated on an in-patient basis and required a good deal of after-care, so that had to be built into the fee. Today, operations are often performed on a same day basis. Changed technology in the form of finer needles and biodegradable sutures means patients require far less after-care.

Computer figures for some of these operations show that some eye surgeons were performing several of these eye operations on the same day in addition to many other consultative services. Medicare earnings for some eye surgeons had been in excess of $5,000 a day. There is no doubt that because of the technological changes that have taken place, this particular operation was very much overrewarded. The new fees-$450 for lens extraction and $250 for lens insertion-seemed to us appropriate for operations which together usually take less than one hour to perform. It is true that many of these operations are performed on elderly pensioners. The threats by ophthalmologists to cease bulk billing and to continue to charge the old fee condemn that group of surgeons and reflect poorly on the profession as a whole. We are saying that the medical profession, particularly these very high earners in the medical profession, should bear their share of the restraint we are asking of working people and we have asked of pensioners. Yet, when we ask it of people like eye surgeons, these are the kinds of responses we get.

The other major elements in the changes were the warts and keratoses changes. The honourable member for O'Connor, in this place and elsewhere, has been particularly alarmist and irresponsible in the campaign he has run about these changes. Despite his attempt to claim the contrary, the cost of treatment of pre-malignant keratoses-potentially cancerous skin lesions-is still covered by Medicare. It is quite untrue to run around the country saying that treatment is not covered by Medicare. The difference is that since 1 August the specific items for the removal of warts and keratoses have been deleted from the schedule because of the concern about the rapid increase in utilisation. In fact, during the past two financial years there has been an increase in utilisation of these elements of the schedule of 45 per cent. That is an enormous outburst of operations in this area. Again, one of the reasons for that is that technology has changed dramatically. Now, just like most other minor procedures, removals will be covered by consultations at either general practitioner or specialist rates. Seventy-five per cent of removals of warts and keratoses are performed by General Practitioners and will be at GP consultation rates. If it is done by a specialist dermatologist it will be at specialist rates. That provides adequate and appropriate remuneration. As I said, the removal of warts and keratoses was previously a time consuming and difficult task performed mainly by specialists. It is now much less so. Three-quarters of these operations are performed by GPs and the time taken is very much less than it was in the past. I point out of course that items for skin cancers remain in the schedule. I take a specific point made by the honourable member for O'Connor and that is the question of anal and genital warts. We are having discussions with the profession about that element of the changes.

Finally, let me say a little about the usual argument we get about waiting lists in public hospitals being due to Medicare. I have pointed out time and again that there is very little substance to that argument. For one thing, private hospital occupancy rates are now very much the same as they have been for the past 10 or 15 years. If the honourable member looks at the figures he will find there has been very little decline in occupancy rates. What decline there has been in some ways is a credit to the private hospitals because they are also becoming much more efficient in their turnover of patients and so their occupancy days have been marginally reduced. But the interesting thing is that the 60 per cent figure, which the honourable member for O'Connor quoted, is a figure which has been pretty typical of private hospitals with only marginal variations over the last 10 or 15 years. But the sources of our problems in the public hospitals remain the shortage of nurses and some specialists and the improvement in technology means that so much more can be done today than could be done even five years ago-the classic example of that is the hip operations on old people, a rare operation in the early 1970s but now the most common surgical procedure on people over the age of 65. I also refer to the changed demand that has resulted from that and, one does not deny it, industrial difficulties particularly in the States with the most serious waiting list problems-New South Wales and Victoria. But, again, the Commonwealth and the State governments are taking specific responses to that particular problem.
