SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woods Dr R. L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very disappointed that the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) has spoken such drivel about what is probably one of the most important portfolios. I cannot believe that we do not have a Minister in this portfolio who shows some compassion and caring about the public in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I wonder how many of these unintended consequences are, in fact, unintended and how many are intended. The Minister has talked to us today about targeted areas and appropriate decisions to encourage good medical practice. I ask: Is it good medical practice to abolish preventative care for skin cancer? Is it good medical practice to abolish after hours payments so that if a person is unfortunate enough to get sick after hours he has to wait until the next morning? Or is it good medical practice to not get oneself cared for by the specialist or the consultant in the field? Of course it is not. The Minister mentioned that there was no support from the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners. He forgot to mention in regard to the consultants' fees that the Royal College of Physicians, which is not a political body, probably had its strongest outcry ever about the disgraceful behaviour of the Department of Community Services and Health in this regard. The fact that he is now planning to change things surely indicates that he has admitted the error that he has made in this regard.

Let us remember that the levy itself is just basically another tax. It is called a levy, but it is basically a tax. It raises another $2 billion. Again, I just point out in passing that it is part of the record taxation levels of this Government. The Minister mentioned savings. According to the Minister, these changes will save $116m each year. Let us just look at that. What are we talking about? We are talking about $116m extra in taxation paid for, not by the whole population-that would be bad enough-but by those who can least afford it, the sick. It is covered by health insurance, but who pays the health insurance premiums? Honourable members are right, it is the sick.

What else has been happening to this levy and this Medicare of ours? Let us look at State health care grants. In 1982-83 the outlaid grant to the States overall was $1,449m. In 1986-87 it was $2,770m-an increase of 91 per cent. Does anybody here seriously think that our health delivery has improved by 91 per cent or indeed improved at all? Of course it has not. We could break those figures down for New South Wales; they are the same. One of the causes for this is the enormous bureaucracy of Medicare. In the first 12 months of Medicare alone, Medicare staff increased from 1,863 to 4,346, an increase of 2,483 staff. I ask honourable members to think just for a moment what 2,483 extra nurses would have done for our health system.

What sort of health system do we actually have? Let us look at my own State of New South Wales. Let us look at the claims from our State Minister for Health, Mr Anderson. He claims that there are no waiting problems in New South Wales; there are no such things as waiting lists in New South Wales.

TALK.START.PARA: —People die waiting in your State.

—I will come to that. They certainly do die in our State. This Government has quoted statistics in regard to Healthline. Healthline was set up mainly to deal with waiting list problems. If we do not have any waiting list problems, why do we have to set up a Healthline especially to deal with them? Of course, the answer is quite clear. The Government put out some publicity showing that, of the people who phoned the Healthline, about half had actually been waiting less than six months. What that means, of course, is that more than half have been waiting more than six months. If there really were no problem with waiting times in public hospitals in New South Wales the Healthline would just not be necessary. But this week Barrie Unsworth announced that the Healthline would become a permanent service. If the hospital service is so good, why on earth do we need a permanent Healthline service?

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister glossed over the waiting lists. He tried to dismiss them as being irrelevant. Let us look at them a little more closely. We have had some data recently from St George Hospital in New South Wales. The waiting list for surgery alone was 936 patients. It does not include medicine and all the other non-surgical specialities. A total of 344 people had waited for more than 12 months. I refer to some data from the Royal North Shore Hospital. In terms of the cardiac unit, the average waiting time for so-called elective cardiac surgery-cardiac surgery is not the sort of thing one usually likes to wait for at all-is five to six months. Over the last year there was an average of 100 patients on the waiting list at any time. Five people have died this year at Royal North Shore Hospital awaiting either cardiac catheterisation or cardiac surgery.

I refer to my own specialty of cancer medicine prior to entering Parliament. I will explain to the Minister, because I am sure he will not understand, that it is important when one is giving cancer chemotherapy to give it on time. A day or so can be crucial. If one waits and gives chemotherapy late, in the meantime the cancer starts to grow and when cancers grow it tends to be fairly fatal. In the last few months the average waiting time for routine chemotherapy at the Royal North Shore Hospital is one week and it has been up to two weeks in the last few weeks. That refers to chemotherapy which is given at three-week cycles. Thus we have people waiting for two weeks on a three-week cycle. I think it is absolutely appalling that we can tolerate this sort of behaviour.

The Minister mentioned the fact that the empty private beds are not related to the waiting list. The honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) has mentioned that there are 9,000 empty private beds. If they were utilised properly the waiting list problems would be solved at a single stroke. However, this Government will not put compassion above ideology. It sticks by the ideology that Medicare should not be allowed to be used in private hospitals. If it were, we could allow ordinary Medicare patients to use private beds, we could get rid of the waiting list in no time at all and we could resolve the problem pretty well immediately. But, of course, that is not possible. Ideology comes before compassion and caring for this particular Government.

Let us look at psychiatric patients. In New South Wales in particular we have a major problem which is just beginning to develop as a result of the Richmond report. According to recent information put out by the Press and supported by the leader of the Public Medical Officers Association, 27 psychiatric patients who have been discharged from institutions in New South Wales, following the Richmond report recommendations that they be allocated to homes and half-way houses, have died in circumstances which would indicate that their deaths in the main may well be attributable to suicides. They include patients with chronic severe depression and a previous history of suicide attempts and other patients with poorly controlled schizophrenia. Some of the staff at Peat Island over the last week have shown enormous concern about discharging some of their patients who apparently attack staff, attack each other, expose themselves and break windows and who have formed liaisons outside Peat Island with 13-year-old girls. These are the sorts of people that the New South Wales Health Department is planning to send out into our community. For their own good, as well as for the good of the community, they need to be cared for in a secure and safe environment. There are aspects of the Richmond report which are worth implementing, but not wholesale as the Government in New South Wales is doing.

The honourable member for O'Connor touched on preventative medicine in terms of keratoses. I cannot believe this Government which paid lip service during the election campaign to preventative medicine, particularly in relation to breast cancer and cervical cancer. As soon as the election is over the Minister attacks the most effective preventative medicine available in Australia, which is the removal of pre-cancerous skin lesions. Sure, a patient can get them removed, but he cannot get them removed by an expert. If he does, he does not get rebated for it. Where is the incentive to encourage the removal of these pre-cancerous lesions? So much for preventative medicine.

Let us look back a little to May, before we had the problems we now face, before the Argentinean road came along and while we were just an ordinary banana republic, if honourable members can remember. As always happens, this Government took more from us in May and gave us back less. As we have heard, it reduced the Medicare rebate but, more importantly, and the Minister did not mention this, the Government has reduced the maximum gap of $20 which it had previously promised to retain. This means that if a person needs a coronary artery by-pass graft and he survives the waiting list, he may need to take out a bank loan because the gap between the recommended doctor's fee from the Australian Medical Association and the Medicare rebate is $728. Should a person be lucky enough to find somewhere to get his hip replaced-it is pretty difficult to find anywhere to get it done nowadays, one probably has more chance of winning the lottery-he has to find a gap which would amount to $538. Honourable members should bear in mind the age group we are looking at. We are looking at the 60 plus age group and we are looking, as always, at this Government attacking the poor, the needy and the defenceless. The cataract problem reflects the same age group. It may well be okay, if eye specialists actually have all the new equipment, to charge a lesser fee. But in regard to those eye specialists who do not have that extra equipment the Government is trying to push them out of their business, which is caring for the elderly in our society. The Government clearly does not believe that people should be looked after by specialists; it believes that people should be looked after by ordinary general practitioners. Many conditions can be looked after very well by general practitioners but the Government, which cares only about saving money, and cannot even do that decently, does not believe that there can be an ongoing medical problem that needs the care of a specialist and an expert.

I mentioned at the commencement of this discussion the question of after hours consultations. It is bad enough if one gets sick between nine to five, but heaven help us if we get sick after hours, because the Government has removed the loading paid to doctors to work outside normal hours. This is probably the only situation in Australia in which people do not get paid for working extraordinary hours. I understand that bulk billing may have been a problem and the system is being misused by a minority of doctors. But if the system is being misused, surely one fixes the system. One does not destroy the system and destroy health care for needy people who just happen to be inconsiderate enough to get sick out of hours.

This Government has effectively destroyed the principle of universality of health care. It has created two classes of Australians: the first class who are well-off financially and have immediate access to private hospitals and an unlimited capacity for long term specialist care; and a second class, those on pensions, fixed incomes and low wages who are compelled to wait, sometimes for years, in queues for elective surgery. In a civilised community, the health of individuals should never be forced to depend upon the size of pockets or purse. Health care should be available to everyone, regardless of means, and without significant delays. I urge this Government strongly to stop making promises and to start caring about the people of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it pretty galling that members of the Opposition get up in this place and attack the Government on its health policies when they do not have one of their own. I have some sympathy for the honourable member for Lowe (Dr Woods) who had to get up and talk about the medical profession rather than about health policy. He talked about the increases in Medicare personnel and he has shown, in his first couple of weeks in this place, that he can use statistics. Of course, he did not mention that 2,000 staff from private health funds have gone over to Medicare. He neglected to mention that the same amount of work was being done by the same number of people. He also said that if we could just shift that huge waiting list over to the private hospitals we would solve the problem. We would not solve the problem because there are not enough nurses to look after the patients who would flood into private hospitals. But he did not mention that.

SPEECH.PARA: I had some sympathy for the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) when he first got up to speak today because all his colleagues on the back bench kept talking over him. He actually had to turn around and ask them to stop talking and to listen to what he was saying.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have not got any, George.

—That is better than his situation. He actually had to say, `Thank you. Would you please keep quiet so that I can talk on the matter of public importance.' That just shows what honourable members opposite think of the Opposition's health policy. The honourable member for O'Connor also talked about excessive hospital bills. He never talked about excessive specialists' charges. He thinks it is okay for people in private practice to charge, in many cases, what they want. He also did not mention in relation to excessive charges that, under any health system, one could never insure above the schedule fee. I have recently brought this to the attention of the public and I will be doing so again.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) adequately covered the specifics of the matter of public importance and I do not want to elaborate on that. Yet another attack has been made on Medicare. This is all that we have had from the Opposition; we have had no positive response from it and no clear signal on where it would go. All that members of the Opposition can do is attack Medicare. Medicare is the fairest health insurance system that this country has ever had. I suppose in that respect the Opposition is being consistent because it has always opposed any decency and fairness that we have tried to put into the taxation system, the retirement income area, industrial policy or any other policy that we have addressed. I suppose that its position on tax stands out more than its position on other matters. But certainly, on the question of health members of the Opposition have opposed Medicare from day one, usually on ideological grounds, and we cannot pin them down on specifics. In fact, according to an article from the Australian Doctor, the honourable member for O'Connor ironed out a health policy; he prefers free market forces and he would walk away from the community rating principle. That is the sort of thing we are getting from the Opposition; we are getting nothing constructive.

The honourable member for Lowe touched briefly on the philosophy of Medicare, even though he did not acknowledge it as such. That philosophy is that medical services should be provided on the basis of need and not on the size of one's bank balance. It is not a question of a person's ability to pay. The levies that go towards Medicare should be based on a person's ability to pay and they are. It is a levy on income.

TALK.START.PARA: —But he wants them paid at AMA rates.

—As the Minister points out, the honourable member for Lowe wants to be paid at Australian Medical Association (AMA) rates. Yet, he is talking about fiscal responsibility. The Opposition is talking about cutting $11 billion off the Budget at the same time as talking about increasing, in many ways, the cost of health insurance and I will come to that in just a minute.

SPEECH.PARA: The health policy of the honourable member for O'Connor reminds me a lot of car insurance-the free market forces where everybody pays the same rate if they can afford it. As the Minister pointed out, under the previous health system over two million Australians just could not afford health insurance. They were in limbo. People on low incomes could not get benefits and they were not affluent enough to afford health insurance. I do not think the principle of car insurance is good enough and Medicare certainly does not embrace that principle. As I have said, it is the fairest system we have.

Let us look at health costs in macro terms. The statistics that I have cover the period from 1975 to 1986 and are expressed as a percentage of gross domestic product. The figures in the United State of America went from 8.6 per cent in 1975 to 11 per cent in 1986. In Canada, over the same period, the statistics went from 7.4 per cent to 8.4 per cent. The figure for Australia has actually gone down from 7.6 per cent to 7.5 per cent. In 1983 the figure for the United Kingdom, which has a total national health service, was 6.2 per cent. It is always interesting for those people who follow ideology to note that Margaret Thatcher has not touched the health insurance system in the United Kingdom. I will not make any comment other than that. But it seems to me that people driven by ideology would think that she might start espousing the sorts of policies espoused by the honourable member for O'Connor in a speech that was widely reported. The simple fact is that Medicare is the most efficient system in macro terms-the actual cost to the community of maintaining health schemes.

Utilisation is another way in which we can measure Medicare. The rate of increase in terms of utilisation certainly went down in 1986 and is continuing to go down in 1987. When we first introduced Medicare the rate of increase went up slightly initially. But that rate is now dropping, which leads us to believe that the rubbish that is sometimes put out about Medicare increasing the number of services is totally wrong. In actual fact, the number of services has gone down under Medicare.

Another benefit of Medicare is that all health insurance claims now go through the same computer. Up until quite recently over 130 different health insurance companies supplied statistics to the Health Insurance Commission or to the former Department of Health. However, those statistics were so fragmented that they were very hard to use in any meaningful way. For the first time ever we have accurate figures that make it possible for us to sit down and actually plan how we run our health system in this country. Many of the changes in the May statement that the Minister talked about were a direct result of having accurate statistics. With accurate statistics we can look at overservicing, whether it happens on an individual basis or throughout a speciality service within the medical area. Accurate statistics also make medical research and the delivery of medical services a lot simpler and much more efficient.

The AMA did not appreciate the fact that I was able to tell it how much it earned. But this is another statistic that we were able to put out to show that doctors are not really travelling all that badly when we compare them with the rest of the community. I join the Minister in saying that some members of the medical profession-not all of them, as I think most of them accept their duties responsibly-are ripping off the system and are paying no real heed to the way in which Australia is trying to restructure itself by asking for restraint.

Let us have a look at the community's acceptance of Medicare and what the community actually thinks of it. As the Minister said, we were returned at the last election for a third time after going to the people on a platform that included Medicare. The 1986-87 report of the Health Insurance Commission, in commenting on the results of a survey that it undertook, stated:
The results show that community support for the Medicare program has grown by 3 per cent to 64 per cent with only 15 per cent believing that it should be abolished.
There is an amazing approval rate. It goes on:
As illustrated in figure 18-
which I cannot incorporate-

overall customer satisfaction with Medicare claims payment service has grown to a quite remarkable 94 per cent, a level that is virtually constant across all States. The main reason given by those satisfied were the efficiency with which claims are handled, the fast service and prompt payment, the helpful staff and simple straightforward procedures.

Medicare is widely accepted in the community. The longer this Government stays in power the more acceptance it will attract. Not only has Medicare always been accepted by patients but also it has always been opposed by some sections of the AMA. The recent call by Mr Bruce Shepherd for the schedule fee to rise to $30 is outrageous and is certainly not in the best interests of patients. Medicare is there for patients, not for doctors. From my dealings with the AMA it seems to me that it is more interested in how the system treats that doctors than in how the system treats the patients. I have a few letters here which show the way in which some doctors responded when we made the changes. One letter, which was sent out with a patient's bill, states:

Regrettably the gap you have to pay between my account and your Medicare refund has increased. The reason is that on August 1 many Medicare benefits items were reduced and some were abolished. Remaining benefits have not kept pace with inflation. If you feel strongly about this change I suggest that you complain to your member of parliament that Medicare benefits are failing to meet the promises this Government made.

DEBATE.TITLE: PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION TO INDIA AND SRI LANKA

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present the report of the Australian Parliamentary Delegation to India and Sri Lanka during November 1986 and seek leave to make a short statement in connection with the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to present the report by the Australian Parliamentary Delegation to India and Sri Lanka. The delegation visited India and Sri Lanka in November 1986. Our visit occurred at a time of considerable importance, both in the recent history of the region and of relations between India and Sri Lanka. Our visit also followed shortly after the initiation of a number of important advances in Australian-India relations which were initiated during a visit to Australia in October 1986 by the Prime Minister of India, Rajiv Gandhi.

SPEECH.PARA: As a result of meetings between Mr Gandhi and the Australian Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) a number of steps were taken both to develop further and rejuvenate the Australian-Indian relationship, notably in the areas of trade and commerce, culture, science and in areas of particular Australian expertise such as agricultural research and infrastructure development. The delegation's visit to India gave members the chance to seek views from senior government leaders, parliamentarians and people in industry on possible practical and effective ways of continuing and influencing the improvement and invigoration of Australian-Indian relations. In particular we were interested to see several innovative joint ventures between Australian and Indian business in Madras which could provide considerable potential economic benefits to Australian companies and beneficial technology transfer to India.

The delegation was also able to explore the potential for improved Indian-Australian relations that are promised in business, scientific and cultural exchanges and contact between the Australian and Indian peoples. A point that visitors to India-particularly members of parliament-can always report on with admiration is the strength of Indian parliamentary institutions, both at the federal and state levels. The presiding officers of all parliaments we visited extended warm and open hospitality to us.

The inevitable focus of the delegation's visit to India and Sri Lanka was the serious communal conflict which has developed in Sri Lanka since 1983 and the tragedy of the gentle and cultured Sri Lankan people which has worsened in recent times. The conflict, which centres on the position in Sri Lankan society of the Tamil community, has undermined the political stability and general security in large parts of the north and east of the island. Terrorism generated by the conflict has led to extremely damaging long term economic consequences for Sri Lanka, particularly for tourism and foreign investment. It has inevitably also led to great personal tragedy, dispossession and death to large numbers of the population in the areas directly affected by the conflict.

The focus of much of the delegation's discussions with Ministers, officials and interested groups in Sri Lanka was, therefore, on the conflict, on its possible future course and on details of the initiatives proposed by the Government of Sri Lanka during 1986 to bring about a settlement of the conflict and eventual reconciliation of the Sri Lankan ethnic communities. A consequence of the conflict has been the establishment by Tamil separatist groups of guerrilla training camps in Tamil Nadu, the Indian state in closest proximity to Sri Lanka. The severe security and social problems, including the presence of large numbers of refugees which resulted from this situation, both for the Indian central Government and the state Government of Tamil Nadu, led to the Indian Government and in particular the Prime Minister-taking an active mediating role and proposing a number of actions directed at resolving the conflict. Several such initiatives were taken by Indian and Sri Lankan leaders at the November 1986 meeting of the South Asian Association for Regional Co-operation which took place during the delegation's visit to India.

The delegation had particularly hoped and anticipated that it would be able to hold discussions with Mr Gandhi or other senior Ministers of his Government on these developments, from the Indian perspective. It was disappointing for the delegation that this opportunity did not arise due to the Prime Minister's personal involvement in attempts made at the time of our visit-which unfortunately failed-to promote an agreement on peaceful resolution of the Sri Lankan communal conflict. We were able to hold detailed and very frank talks with President Jayewardene of Sir Lanka and Foreign Minister Hameed and to canvass opinions from other Sri Lankan leaders and concerned groups and individuals. All members of the delegation were particularly pleased at the amount of time given to us, and the extent and depth of the discussions we had, while we were in Colombo. We also were able to put forward concerns of the International Committee of the Red Cross and its inability to gain access to areas of conflict and also of Amnesty International's list of disappearances which Ministers, including Minister Lalith Athulathmadali, promised to take on board and follow through. To a certain extent this has been done.

As all honourable members are aware the Sri Lankan communal conflict has severely deteriorated in 1987. The Indian-Sri Lankan peace accord which was signed in July had led to open warfare between the militant Tamil separatist groups and the Indian armed forces that have been deployed in Sri Lankan under the accord. The current situation in Sri Lanka is a most tragic and disturbing one. No visitor to Sri Lanka has failed to be impressed and entranced by the beauty of the country and of its people. It adds to the sense of the tragedy of that small nation. A major offshoot of our discussions with Sinhalese Tamils and Moslems in the government and non-government sectors in Sri Lanka was an awareness of the perceived growth of terrorism in Sri Lanka as a factor detracting from the potential for a peaceful settlement. Certainly, the problem of historical enmity and shortsightedness by the Sinhalese communities since Sri Lanka independence led to a sense of political powerlessness and frustration in the Tamil community. Time and again members were assailed by expressions of concern that what may have been and presumably did start out as a reactionary militancy born of oppression had now become an oppressive and self-perpetuating element in prolonging war. This was a viewpoint put to us by members of both Tamil and Sinhalese communities.

Sri Lanka is undoubtedly war-weary. People are being killed. They live in fear. They want peace. These factors blur the factional edges. One thing is clear: Sri Lanka needs answers, not ideological posturing. The situation we have witnessed since 1983, particularly over the last year, has resulted from polarisation of the Sri Lankan community, a polarisation which as lead to the breakdown of the civil life in the country. I should stress that of course the delegation does not and would not condone or support the use of terrorist violence to achieve political ends. This point was made by delegation members continually in discussions held on our visit.

An area of Australian activity in the region on which I particularly wanted to gain first-hand information was Australian voluntary aid and community development aid. India and Sri Lanka have historically received contributions of governmental aid from Australia, which has now been considerably reduced. Australia's contributions of aid and assistance from voluntary sources, particularly from Community Aid Abroad and World Vision, are of particular importance in the provision of such aid and its direction to the most potentially productive and needy areas was a matter the delegation was able to examine at first hand. I would say that all members were involved in these discussions but Senator Richard Alston in particular followed through with me on this particular interest. We were impressed by the number of non-government organisations and the excellent way in which they worked together with the Australian High Commission. Anne Leach of the Australian High Commission, in the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau, knows the non-governmental sector like the back of her hand and most certainly is making the best possible use of Australian funding that is going into the discretionary fund in Colombo. In a country which most definately requires that aid we were impressed by the way in which the two sectors worked together.

I express the thanks of the delegation for the hospitality shown by Speaker Jakhar of the Lok Sabha and Speaker Senanayake of the Sri Lankan Parliament. I also thank the Australian High Commissioner to India, Mr Graham Feakes, the Australian High Commissioner to Sri Lanka, Mr Bob Cotton, the Australian Consul-General in Bombay, Mr Graham Hawker, and the staffs of the Australian High Commissions in New Delhi and Colombo, for their assistance, guidance and support during the visit. Our understanding and perception of the complex bilaterial and domestic issues faced by both India and Sri Lanka and of Australia's role in the region was greatly assisted and improved by the briefings, advice and information provided. I express particular thanks for the valuable assistance provided by Ian Wille of the High Commission, New Delhi, who travelled with the delegation in India, and Pat Hardy and Anne Leach of the High Commission in Colombo.

It is a valuable and important experience for members of parliament to gain first-hand knowledge of the activities and difficulties associated with Australian diplomatic posts. Such opportunities allow members better to assess the effectiveness of our representation and to report on their observations to the Parliament. Australia's missions in India and Sri Lanka have a very large brief indeed which they discharge with energy and professionalism-often in very difficult circumstances. The delegation was able to assess the work of Australia's diplomatic missions in both countries and has commented on several areas of activity, particularly immigration and trade, in the report.

In finishing this tabling statement I want to refer particularly to the deputy leader of the delegation, who is now in the chamber, the honourable member for Cook, the Hon. Don Dobie. I would also like to thank all other members-Senator Richard Alston; the Hon. Peter Duncan, the honourable member for Makin and now a Minister in this House; Mr Peter Fisher, the honourable member for Mallee; and Mr Roger Price, the honourable member for Chifley-for their enthusiasm and energy and the co-operation they displayed during this visit so that we were able to cut across political and other divisions and to move as a unit as we met other parliamentarians, and, more particularly, in contact with the real living conditions of the people within India and Sri Lanka.

Also, the spouses of some of the delegates added to the interest and the comfort of our discussions. I would particularly thank Mrs Fisher, Mrs Duncan and my husband, Bob, who were able to travel with us. Particular thanks must go to the Secretary to the delegation, Mr Andrew Snedden, for his hard work in smoothing the delegation's way. Above all I wish to register the warm gratitude of the delegation to the Indian and the Sri Lankan governments. Certainly, as far as the delegation was concerned, it was an exercise well worth while. We feel very strongly that the role that the Indian Government is now playing in trying to ensure that the underlying and growing bitterness that shadows the lives of people in a country with such great potential in our regional area should not be allowed to consolidate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dobie The Hon J.D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I endorse the remarks made by the leader of the delegation, the honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling). It was a good visit; it was successful in that it maintained contacts with these two very important countries. I was one of those who had tried to have the dates of the visit changed so that it fitted more comfortably with our sitting dates last year. We could not quite work out why this did not come to pass until we discovered that Mr Gorbachev and his planeloads of advisers were due to arrive a week after we did. Of course, this did have something to do with the non-availability of certain Indian Ministers for our discussion purposes. Nonetheless, it was useful and we have to pay particular tribute to two men in India-High Commissioner Feakes and Deputy High Commissioner Ian Wille, who I am pleased to note in the last week or two has himself been made a head of mission within the diplomatic service. He will serve our country very well in the new country which he is visiting.

SPEECH.PARA: The tragedy of the Tamil problem totally influenced everything we thought of the whole visit because it is impossible to think of the Tamil tragedy without also thinking of India's involvement in it. Since our visit we have seen the arrival of 15,000 Indian troops to try to `contain'-I think that is the diplomatic word-the Tamil guerrillas. But while we were in the state of Tamil Nadu, with its capital Madras, we were made very much aware of the role that is played within that state in the country of India with succour and assistance being given to many sections of the Tamil guerrilla forces. I believe the Indian Government is very disturbed by it and I believe the action taken by Prime Minister Gandhi is significant in that it displays the concern he too must be sharing as to why this revolt in the north of Sri Lanka, only a handful of miles away from India across the sea, should have been receiving such assistance, which I observed while I was there. It was interesting that while the delegation was in Madras an edict came out ordering the giving up of arms by the Tamil camps in Madras. It was withdrawn three days after our departure.

I do not want to take the time of the House to discuss the Tamil problem, except to say that there are vast differences of opinion in the Tamil population in Australia as to what the role should be in that country. If our visit has meant one thing, I hope that it is making the issue of the Tamil problem in Sri Lanka the cause of some public discussion and debate and not merely the outpourings of publicity and propaganda from one section of the Tamil population in Australia. I know of the great distress of my own Sri Lankan friends in Sydney, who happen to be Tamils, about the large amount of disinformation which is being spread among our community. However, as I have said, this is not the time to open a debate on that subject.

We did not have the problem of Secretary-General Gorbachev visiting Sri Lanka so our visit to Sri Lanka was a totally different affair. The availability of Ministers, heads of departments, local authorities and community aid leaders was speedy and readily available and we enjoyed a frankness which was very stimulating. I pay a tribute to High Commissioner Bob Cotton for his deep involvement in our visit and the energy he displayed in making certain that we saw those whom we wished to see. The Minister for National Security, whose name I cannot say with the same ease as the leader of the delegation did-Lalith Athulathmudali-displayed a remarkable sympathy when the leader placed before him on behalf of Amnesty International in this Parliament the names of people who we believed were missing. He was frank and open. It is very interesting, and I think that the Parliament should be made aware of it, that subsequently he visited Australia and met with Amnesty International in this Parliament and the delegation. A very frank and open discussion took place in this building. That was a direct result of our visit to this country.

I also pay tribute to the Speaker of the Lok Sabha, Speaker Jakhar, and Speaker Senanayake in Sri Lanka. We would not be doing the visit to Sri Lanka justice if we did not talk of the Speaker's pet elephant and the role the pet elephant played in our visit to the Speaker's home. If anything achieved goodwill between that country and ours, it was our becoming friendly with his little pet elephant. I will have no remarks made from this side of the House that there were reasons why I found such a common bond, but be that as it may. This was added to by the fact that Speaker Senanayake has led a delegation of Sri Lankan parliamentarians including Dr Bandaranaike, the Opposition Leader, to Australia. They have been to Australia since our visit. The ground has been set for a continuation of good relationships between Australia and those two Indian Ocean countries.

Coming from the west, Mr Deputy Speaker, you will be very much aware of the reality of Indian Ocean politics. It behoves this Parliament to be much more conscious of what is happening in our neighbouring countries which share the Indian Ocean. Western Australian businessmen have already taken the lead in Madras. It was our pleasure to be at the port-I am not quite sure what the function turned out to be, but at any rate it was the launching of something-which showed the degree to which those Western Australian businessmen have made contact and are going forward with joint ventures in India. It is obvious that there is tremendous opportunity for further joint ventures to be undertaken.

The other point I wish to make-I made it while I was there-is that it is a shame that more of the international carriers to Australia do not stop in Colombo on the way to Australia rather than other Asian ports. Of course, the Tamil problem frightens many tourists, and well it might, but I put it to some of our carriers that they should be thinking of dropping into Colombo. If that happens relationships will improve.

I have visited Sri Lanka three times. The first was in 1953 on my way to Britain. In those days the first foreign port of call for every Australian who travelled to Europe was Colombo. The significance of that has always been that, to my generation, Sri Lanka has had a greater importance in our thinking than it has to later generations. It has to do with the fact that our first experience of different languages and situations was always in Colombo. My second visit was as a member of a parliamentary delegation in 1968. Therefore, my recent visit showed with great clarity the tremendous material advance that that country has made with regard to the provision of facilities as well as the sheer appearance of Colombo as a city. Its tourist facilities are second to none. One hopes that it will be rewarded in the time ahead by, firstly, peace in that country and, secondly, an increasing tourist trade. A member of my family flies with Air Lanka so I have an above average interest in the country.

Members of the delegation came back hurt by the problems in Sri Lanka. One cannot go to such a peaceful place and see and hear of war every day without coming back distressed at what is happening to such a lovely country. Although Sri Lanka is different from Australia and the colour of the skin and the traditions of the people are different from those in our country, their whole society also has a very large British element in it. Their courts, parliaments and law enforcement are based on British law, government and law enforcement. Therefore, it is distressing to find that those very institutions are being challenged by the Tamil uprising.

I wish the Sri Lanka Government strength in what it is about. I wish it progress in its peace talks. I hope that it will not be so long before another parliamentary delegation visits that country. I pay a tribute to the leader and my colleagues on the trip. We had an enjoyable time. At one stage we all fell victim to a complaint which, in India, I cannot call Montezuma's revenge.

TALK.START.PARA: —Delhi belly.

—One of my fellow deputy chairmen assists me. Perhaps it is the correct description. We were all sick for the required two or three days, but that made no difference to an enjoyable, very action packed and tremendously busy program. In conclusion, I thank the official from the Indian Foreign Affairs Department who travelled with us. I think that we took 10 years off his life with our disregard for time and schedules. My greatest interest was visiting the museum of modern art in Delhi. I recommend to all Australian visitors to Delhi that they go to that outstanding art gallery. I was pleased to take my fellow delegates along to it, as it was not on our program. I am pleased to say that the State Department has now decided that a visit will be included in all future parliamentary visits, wherever the delegations come from. That is my tourist push in that respect. I thank the Parliament for the opportunity of speaking at this time and I thank the delegates for what was a good trip.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price Mr L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I want to make a few brief remarks. First, I would like to endorse the remarks of the leader and deputy leader of the delegation. As a first trip for me, it afforded an interesting opportunity to get to know a little better not only Government members but also some of the Opposition members. A feature of the trip was the outstanding hospitality afforded to us, and the kindness shown by the governments of India and Sri Lanka. I was particularly interested in going on this trip because I think Australia's future resides in south Asia, South East Asia and the Pacific region. For that reason, I sought nomination for the trip and I feel thoroughly rewarded for having made it.

SPEECH.PARA: It is now some 12 months since we made the trip, and it is difficult to give the flavour of that time. However, I want to make a couple of points about each country. We have already talked about the communal violence in Sri Lanka, and at Madras I had the opportunity to meet with each of the Tamil militant groups-unofficially, of course-such as the Tigers, the Tamil United Liberation Front and the People's Liberation Organisation of Tamil Eelam, and that formed an indispensable background to going there. The honourable member for Cook (Mr Dobie) has already commented about the access that we had to the Ministers and the Government in Colombo and, for a backbencher, it was not only kind but a little flattering to have the benefit of such frank and free discussion. At the time there was a debate within the Government as to whether it would opt for a military solution or continue negotiations. I think every member of the delegation came back with the view that there were real prospects for peace. Unfortunately, that was not realised: a military option was exercised. And then there was the intervention of India.

One of the interesting things about talking to both the Government in Colombo and the militants was, at that time, they both appeared to underestimate the role and authority that India could bring to bear, I hope and believe, for peaceful purposes. I am not claiming the benefit of hindsight in this. I note that the peacekeeping force sent by India, with the agreement of the government at Colombo, is now in the northern provinces. If one talks about the communal violence in Sri Lanka, one runs the risk of alienating not only the Tamils but also the Sinhalese. I am pleased that India has sent those troops. It was an outstanding act of courage by the President of Sri Lanka to have negotiated that accord. I say to Tamil and Sinhalese friends in both Australia and Sri Lanka that this affords us the best prospects for peace, and I hope that process will continue. It is a magnificent country, and a people deserving of peace.

I have supported the role of both governments in this accord. Initially the militants, particularly the Tigers, were reluctant to accept the Indian presence but I believe that that has now changed and I hope that, in the future, we shall be able to visit Jaffna and a country at peace. When we visited Colombo, we discussed the impact of war, which was visible from the security aspect. The communal violence is typical of what is happening overseas where there is selective presentation of the news and where people and international bodies like the Red Cross and the media are kept out. The media play a tremendously important role when they are given access, in terms of bringing the horrors of war and communal violence to everyone, whether they be in that or any country.

One of the things that interested me in India was immigration, as, like every member of parliament, I often deal with immigration. I was pleased to see the High Commission at Delhi. Just for the record, let me say that it operates in the most appalling of conditions. What Indians who wish to migrate to this country have to suffer in terms of the space available to them to be interviewed in is absolutely disgusting. I say that as a reflection not on the Embassy staff but on those who fund those facilities. It is an opportune time to suggest that the FitzGerald Commission to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policy have a look at some of the factors affecting countries such as India, Sri Lanka and the Philippines. I have no evidence about this, but I think that we should confront the issue as to whether or not non-Australian officials working on migration matters are in receipt of bribes. There must be an inquiry-and if it is not FitzGerald, it must be someone else-that allows people to come forward and either put that to rest or expose it, whatever is the case.

We ought to be honest to those who want to migrate to Australia from those countries, and tell them that there are departmental targets. It is rubbish to say that anyone who wishes to migrate has to satisfy only a points system. That is just so much hocus-pocus. We ought to have the integrity and honesty to admit that there are targets. In addition, people from India and other countries suffer because, for example, tertiary qualifications are often not recognised in Australia. If they are not recognised in Australia there is no allowance so that they can upgrade their qualifications in terms of the allocation of points. When they migrate they also suffer again under the professional, technical and trade skills area, so they cop a double whammy because they can only claim matriculation not professional or technical status. If they happen to be in an occupation that has recognised shortages, because of the lack of recognition of their skills, they cop a triple whammy. The FitzGerald inquiry ought to address those issues honestly and sincerely.

The physical conditions of the immigration section in India are appalling. For example, the manipulating of files under a manual system is absolutely crazy in this day and age. We have to provide a better method of doing that. Every member of the delegation, at every point at which we stopped, was approached about migration issues. I am sure that both the leader and the deputy leader were; and certainly I was. One of the things that I resent about the current method by which we handle migration is the fact that we put the onus on the person who wants to come out here to come up to counters at our embassies and high commissions and assert his right to information from the same people who will ultimately assess him for suitability to migrate. To think that one has an equality or an ability to do that is very naive. That is another thing at which the FitzGerald inquiry should look.

As both previous speakers have mentioned, there are tremendous trade opportunities for Australian companies, and we were privileged to go around and see a few of them. If Australia is to maximise its potential in countries like India or Sri Lanka, there is no doubt that we shall have to come up with better financing packages to back up the offers and opportunities for Australian companies. DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS, DEFENCE AND TRADE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cross Mr M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, I present the Committee's report entitled the Management of Australia's Defence, together with the minutes of proceedings and evidence received by the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I have pleasure in tabling a report of the Joint Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee on the Management of Australia's Defence. The report is in response to a reference by the Committee to its Defence Sub-Committee which was originally issued in the previous parliament and was subsequently renewed by the present Committee this year. It follows, and largely complements, the Committee's 1984 report on the Australian Defence Force: its structure and capabilities and, like its predecessor, will make a significant and constructive contribution to the defence debate in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: As its title implies, the report focuses on the higher defence organisation in Australia and examines whether the present organisational structure and policy processes are the most suitable for peace and war. It begins with a description of the existing arrangements and how they have evolved, and then examines the major criticisms that have been made both in this and earlier inquiries. Here, some of the issues include:
The division of powers and responsibilities between the Secretary to the Department of Defence and the Chief of the Defence Force (CDF);
political supervision and control of defence policy and activities;
the overall integration of defence functions;
the current staffing of the Defence Department and the Australian Defence Force (ADF); and
problems associated with planning, programming and budgeting in Defence, and with the equipment acquisition process.
Additionally, a major section of the report deals with the command and control of the Australian Defence Force, with particular reference to:
The evolution of, and problems associated with, the existing operational command structure;
the role and functions of headquarters ADF (HQADF);
the role and functions of the joint force commanders and their commands;
the single Service command structure; and
the provision of collective military advice to the Minister and the CDF.

The report ends with an overview of the implications for the defence establishment as a whole of the recommendations of the preceding chapters and a discussion of whether there are grounds for more substantive reforms. It concludes that there would be considerable advantages in establishing a fully unified higher defence organisation in Australia.

While understandably concentrating on perceived organisational and managerial deficiencies, the report acknowledges that in recent years there has been considerable progress in some areas of the defence establishment. The 1987 defence White Paper, for example, represents a significant milestone in the formulation of a logical and coherent strategy for the defence of Australia and an appropriate basis on which to develop our Defence Force structure.

Further, the adoption of a joint force operational command structure is both sensible and timely. Both the Department and the ADF have sought to rationalise and make more efficient many of their internal organisational and policy structures. In spite of this progress, the existing arrangements continue to exhibit a number of problems and deficiencies which serve to undermine the overall efficiency and effectiveness of the defence establishment.
These are documented throughout the report and include:
Continuing overlap in responsibilities and consequent potential conflict of interest between the Secretary and the CDF and between the CDF and the Service Chiefs of Staff;

isolation of the Minister for Defence from the defence policy-making process, excessive spans of control for many senior managers and lack of sufficient means of reviewing or monitoring the defence establishment as a whole;
inadequate involvement of the CDF and his joint staff in the development of defence guidance and the defence program;
continuing imbalance between single Service and joint Service interests and perspectives;
overstaffing and overranking within Russell Hill;
an unduly complicated policy process;
inadequate means of developing strategic and national security policies and continuing absence of basic defence guidance; and
continuing tensions between civilians and military personnel at all levels within the establishment and breakdown of the `joint process'.

Many of these problems and deficiencies were identified by earlier inquiries into the defence establishment. Some stem from the diarchic structure of the higher organisation which continues to separate the military and civilian staffs and thereby ensures that much of defence policy-making proceeds by a process of confrontation and bargaining rather than mutual co-operation and collaboration.

The report makes a series of recommendations to help overcome or eliminate these problems and deficiencies and identifies a number of problem areas in which further study is required either by Defence itself or by an appropriate external review body. In making its recommendations, the primary objective has been to enhance the overall efficiency and effectiveness of the higher defence organisations and their policy processes, while still ensuring the primacy of control of the Executive and the Parliament.

In seeking to satisfy these objectives the report has sought first to clarify and redefine in a number of areas the basic roles and functions of the principal organisational interests within the defence establishment. The suggested changes affect the relationship between the CDF and the Secretary, and the respective roles and the functions of the joint staff and the Services.

In the first case, the report proposes that the CDF be given prime responsibility for developing and issuing detailed defence guidance and preparing the annual defence program. In the Committee's view, the arrangements that have operated in the past have not worked satisfactorily and they have served to undermine the confidence of the military and others within Defence in the Force development process. More importantly, we believe, as a matter of principle, that the person who is to be responsible to the Government for the defence of Australia in times of emergency or war should, within the overall policy and resource constraints set by the Minister, have the major say in how the Defence Force and its supporting framework is developed and managed.

The proposed realignment of responsibilities between the CDF and the Secretary is in line with changes that were recently made in the United Kingdom Ministry of Defence and entails the transfer of the Force Development and Analysis Division and some other elements of Defence Central and the Service offices into HQADF.

A further important change in this area is the proposed establishment of a defence guidance and capabilities committee which would be chaired by the Vice-Chief of the Defence Force and would take over the current functions of the Force Structure Committee and the Defence Operations Concepts and Capabilities Committee. This would simplify and streamline the Force development process and provide the potential for greater control of Force development by the joint staff. At the same time, proposals have been made which would strengthen the present process for preparing the broad strategic framework within which the defence must work, namely, through expanding the functions and roles of the Defence Committee and the Strategic and International Policy Division.

In the second case, the current roles and responsibilities of the Services and their respective chiefs of staff would be further downgraded in favour of the CDF and the joint force commanders. This has been done by proposing that the Australian Defence Force be divided, in conceptual terms at least, into two discrete elements: an employing or operational element and a maintaining or administrative element. This would help emphasise the importance of joint service structures and capabilities, simplify the operational command structure and remove the potential conflicts of loyalty and interest which characterise the present arrangements. The operational element would be purely joint service and would be responsible for planning and conducting all Defence Force operations and operational training activities in peace and war.

The second element would be made up of the three services that would play a purely enabling role with no operational responsibilities at all. In keeping with that approach, the report recommends that rank parity be established between the joint force commanders and the service chiefs of staff, and it suggests that there is scope to rationalise the maintaining element of the ADF either along functional or joint service lines. Within this revised framework, the report proposes a number of additional changes and measures which aim to:
(a) increase the first-hand involvement of the Minister for Defence and his assistant Minister in departmental and ADF matters;
(b) ease the work load of top-level management and provide additional mechanisms for reviewing the structure and performance of the organisation as a whole;
(c) provide for further rationalisation between and within existing functional areas within the establishment;
(d) simplify the current policy process by eliminating some committees and decreasing the number of interests involved in decision making, especially at the top; and
(e) improve joint service structures, capabilities and career opportunities.

On the last measure, the report acknowledges that the Australian Defence Force now recognises the value of adopting in peacetime the kind of operational command structure that will be required in times of defence emergency or war, and that it has begun to move in this direction. It argues, however, that the present operational command structure is simply a single service command system by another name and that it will not provide sufficient opportunity to develop and practice joint service capabilities and doctrine or to train military officers in joint staff appointments. Accordingly, the report recommends that the CDF:
(a) adjust the peacetime missions and tasks of the joint force commanders to ensure that they involve units and assets from two and preferably three services and assigns these forces accordingly;
(b) investigates the establishment of a permanent `theatre' joint force headquarters in the north or north-west of Australia;
(c) reviews the existing joint force command structure in order to determine its suitability both now and in the future; and
(d) implements a range of policies, such as those described in the report, that would establish a strong, confident and motivated joint staff.
The problem areas in which further study or review is required include:
1. the utilisation and current distribution of the civilian and service work force within the higher defence organisation;

2. officer and other rank separation from the ADF, and here I should mention that the matter of personnel wastage rates in the Australian Defence Force has been referred by the Senate to the Joint Committee for inquiry;
3. the means of formulating Australia's national security policies;
4. the defence planning, programming and budgeting system;
5. The role of the joint force commanders in the formulation and oversight of joint service and defence policy; and
6. the current means or providing collective military advice to the CDF and the Minister for Defence.

The Committee appreciates the ready assistance given to the Sub-Committee throughout the inquiry by the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) and his officers from the Department and the ADF. It also thanks those who made submissions to the inquiry and who took part in public hearings. As Chairman of the Defence Sub-Committee, I would like to thank the Deputy Chairman, Senator David MacGibbon, and all the other members of the Sub-Committee for their hard work. I would also like to place on record the Sub-Committee's gratitude to the staff of its secretariat who assisted in the conduct of the inquiry and in the preparation of the report. Particular mention should be made of the Committee's defence adviser, Dr Graeme Cheeseman, who is leaving the secretariat after four years to take up an appointment at the Australian National University. The members of the Joint Committee believe this report represents a positive and timely contribution to the defence debate in Australia. I commend the report to the House.
