DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON TRANSPORT, COMMUNICATIONS AND INFRASTRUCTURE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, I present the Committee's report entitled Constructing and restructuring Australia's public infrastructure, together with the minutes of the proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-A wave of concern around the community about Australia's public infrastructure was focused into a National Infrastructure Forum in October 1985. From that Forum came the suggestion of a parliamentary inquiry into the national infrastructure. The Expenditure Committee in the Thirty-fourth Parliament conducted the inquiry, but drafting of the report had not been completed when Parliament was dissolved. The new Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure has completed the task, and I thank the members for their co-operation. The two sources of the widespread concern about infrastructure are the massive decline in public investment and the growing need for maintenance. Public investment in Australia has been allowed to fall as a proportion of gross domestic product (GDP) from just over 9.6 per cent in 1965-66 to 7.5 per cent in 1985-86. Private investment has not increased to fill the gap either. In fact, private investment, including that in housing, has also fallen from 18.4 per cent of GDP in 1965-66 to 15.9 per cent in 1985-86. In real terms the falls are greater because prices of goods which make up public infrastructure have risen more rapidly than consumer prices.

SPEECH.PARA: Many submissions were received from organisations also concerned about insufficient funding for maintenance and replacement. Though Australia's infrastructure is younger than that of comparable Western countries, it is not much younger, and therefore we can expect the build up of rehabilitation or replacement during the next decade that has already occurred in other industrialised countries. This report, which is entitled Constructing and restructuring Australia's public infrastructure, is an overview of physical infrastructure for economic and social purposes. The public infrastructure includes all the networks of roads and railways, ports and airports, telephone and postal services and some parts of broadcasting, electricity and gas, water and sewerage, schools and hospitals. The Committee was concerned about the national issues involving these networks-their extent and quality, gaps in their provision, future needs, means of funding future provision and methods of increasing the efficiency of their use.

Two of Australia's most serious economic problems are the current account deficit and high unemployment. Reducing the seriousness of those problems will involve restructuring economic activity to build up new and existing export industries and to reduce imports. This requires not only private investment but also efficient, up to date public infrastructure so as to maximise Australia's competitiveness. The need for improved productivity cannot end at the factory gate. Recent work has shown that Australia is facing severe capital capacity constraints-we need more investment in both human and physical capital to achieve a more rapid growth in Australian exports. This means we cannot simply employ more people without the capital backup, if the employment is to be most productive. The size of the current account deficit is imposing severe constraints on Australia and on the public sector at present. It is tempting for governments to reduce capital spending in the current economic climate. However, this not only reduces economic activity and employment growth in the short run but also runs down the nation's investment in infrastructure, its economic efficiency, and eventually the social fabric of society.

The main theme of the report is the need to increase investment to achieve more rapid economic and employment growth and to cope with our current account deficit. One of the few relationships about which all economists agree is that between investment and economic growth. To illustrate this the Committee drew on comparative figures for Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) countries. To account for the different growth in work force numbers standardised figures were used to show investment and GDP per person employed. The figures from 1962 to 1979 show that Australia has the third lowest rate of investment and the fourth lowest GDP growth rate of 25 OECD countries. Only the United States, Canada and New Zealand had a lower rate of economic growth per person employed than Australia. Perhaps there is a lesson here for these established, complacent English-speaking countries. Over the 17-year period Australia's trend rate of investment per employee rose by little more than one per cent per year, half that of the United Kingdom and well short of most European countries with 3 to 4 per cent or Japan's 8 per cent. In common with New Zealand, Canada and the United States we have relied too heavily on past investment and now find our relative place in the national income per head to be slipping away.

The inquiry has established that the worst fears of major infrastructure networks all falling apart at the same time are probably unfounded. Many of our infrastructure services and networks do compare well with the best in the world, but to avoid the problems of the gradual, inevitable deterioration of infrastructure thought and planning are required. We have not seen major freeways in Australia fall into such a bad state of repair that they could not be used, as happened in parts of the United States in the 1970s after funds had been provided for new works but not for rehabilitation and maintenance. The same thing could happen here, but would not if financing needs meet the physical lifetime needs of the asset. That is, if assets are viewed as needing a regular stream of maintenance and rehabilitation and eventual replacement, funds are provided for this purpose.

Perhaps the most serious rehabilitation and replacement problem is that facing Launceston. It has one of the oldest sewerage systems in Australia which uses common sewer and stormwater mains, which are now not up to the demands placed upon them and are in serious danger of collapse. Some of these old mains are under buildings and it does not need much imagination to foresee the problems that would be created by a collapse from stormwater overload under one of the buildings in the centre of town. But fortunately, Launceston appears to be an isolated serious example of potential catastrophe. There may well be other sections of water and sewerage mains in other cities which are in need of major maintenance, but the Committee was not given sufficient evidence to assess this carefully. It says something for the managers of public assets that they have been able to maintain infrastructural assets with a generally declining share of national resources. But this situation is about to change with increasing requirements for rehabilitation and maintenance expenditure in the 1990s.

Perhaps of more concern than the state of the nation's assets at this point is the failure to thoroughly examine other areas for potentially productive investment. For example, many overseas countries have intermodal links between rail and ports and rail and airports-links which are generally missing in Australia. The report identifies a number of gaps and areas where it is desirable to increase investment. These include urban arterial and ring roads in capital cities; intermodal links such as standard gauge rail to ports such as Brisbane, Melbourne and Geelong; standard gauge rail to Sydney international airport; increasing airport capacity in Sydney; sewering significant areas of Perth; dealing with salination problems in the Murray-Darling Basin, and the quality of Adelaide's water supply; and improving telecommunications, there being great potential to invest in the integrated services digital network.

The Committee found that there is quite a significant backlog in the replacement and updating of scientific equipment in universities. Many items of equipment were just not accurate enough for research results to be accepted for publication in scientific journals. Examples of scientific research undertaken with home-made or improvised equipment point to the ingenuity of the researchers but disguise the waste of time and talent in the process, both directly in lost time of those researchers who stay, and through the loss of skilled researchers overseas to institutions where equipment is not a constraint. Yet the sums involved to tackle this equipment backlog are not huge-a significant impact could be made with perhaps $20m a year for five years or so. There are likely to be many other areas where greater infrastructure investment is likely to be in the national interest if the research is undertaken. Perhaps the most striking example is the study of a very fast train between Sydney, Canberra and Melbourne. This is being undertaken by a private consortium and the pre-feasibility study has been sufficiently promising for the group now to be doing a full feasibility study. But there must be other examples such as the very fast train which require initial vision and then a thorough assessment of viability.

Among the submissions received, the desire for greater efficiency in allocation and use of funds for public infrastructure was universal. At the national level the Committee found that the Loan Council had been too rigid and was not facilitating the infrastructure funding needs of those States experiencing the most rapid population and economic growth. The Federal Departments of Treasury and Finance were particularly concerned with the efficiency aspect of public enterprises. But there was some doubt that the present and proposed controls on public enterprises would allow the management flexibility that was essential to achieve substantially improved efficiency. While objective measures for selection of investment projects such as assessing rates of return are fine in theory, in practice there are many difficulties. For example, how does one value an asset constructed at the turn of the century-depreciated historic cost, scrap value, replacement value or opportunity cost? The problems of valuation are often greater for public infrastructure items than for private assets because of a greater age range and often the absence of a market in the assets to establish a value. Further work in this area will assist in easing these problems, and the forthcoming Department of Finance manual on cost-benefit analysis could make a contribution.

Assuming that a more thorough and accept- able procedure for selecting public infrastructure investments is established, the question remains as to whether all viable projects will be funded. If present practices continue to be followed, potentially profitable public investments may still be excluded by a cut-off in funds through the global limits on Loan Council borrowings. Private investment does not face the same absolute cut-off in funds once a certain level of investment is reached. Rather, projects are considered on their merits and if finance is not available locally, overseas funds are sought. If the project return is less certain, the cost of funds will be higher but provided the positive yield is there funds are seldom denied absolutely. The Committee recommends, therefore, that borrowings by commercial public authorities be excluded from the public sector borrowing requirement as in at least some other Western countries, such as the Federal Republic of Germany and France and as recommended by the United Nations.

To examine the place of public investment in Australia's economy the Committee commissioned a paper by Professor John Nevile from the Centre of Applied Economic Research at the University of New South Wales. This study has been well received by economic commentators and breaks new ground on a number of important issues. Nevile found that `in Australia the public sector plays a greater role in increasing the capital stock than is the case in the majority of Western European and North American economies'. This is an important point because, as the Committee shows in its report, the size of government in Australia is not large when compared with other OECD countries, whether measured on the basis of total tax raised or total government expenditure. Furthermore, public investment takes only about 17 per cent of government expenditure. Nevile found that public investment has been an important source of productivity growth in the past, and will be an essential part of any successful efforts to raise the long run rate of productivity growth in Australia.

Much of the report discusses the options available for funding public infrastructure. These include reducing public or private consumption, increasing taxation and borrowing either domestically or from overseas. There may be some scope for restraining growth of public consumption in order to increase investment but the opportunities are clearly limited, given the severity of the expenditure cuts in recent years. Already Australia spends less on social security, education and health as a proportion of GDP than do most Western countries.

Australia already finances a significant proportion of public investment from current revenue, and has done so in every year since 1950; that is, in every year since the end of the forties a portion of public investment has been financed from recurrent revenue. There may be some scope for financing increased investment from revenue, but public opinion would not favour any form of tax increase at present. However, as recent events in the United States have shown, attitudes can change quickly. Only a year ago, it was unthinkable that the United States budget deficit could be cut by tax increases or military expenditure cuts, but both are now accepted policies, even if the hard decisions have been difficult to agree about.

Increased borrowing to finance public investment may well be warranted, however. Contrary to general belief Australia has a relatively low level of public debt as a proportion of GDP-in fact we are second only to Finland having the lowest level of public debt to GDP amongst OECD member countries. There is little empirical evidence to support a view that public sector borrowing crowds out the private sector. Australian interest rates are set principally by interest rates in the United States, by expected changes in Australia's exchange rate, by our inflation rate and by monetary policy. Therefore, there is clearly scope for increased borrowings. It would be essential, nevertheless, to minimise potential damage to market perceptions from any increase in public sector borrowing. One way of doing this would be to separate the capital and recurrent sides of the budget. This would show that recurrent outlays are entirely covered by recurrent revenue and that recurrent revenue also pays for some investment, as I have already said. It would demonstrate clearly that all borrowing is for investment and is therefore justified by the long term rate of return. Publicity about the returns and other economic benefit of that investment would then contribute to justifying the borrowing. One major constraint on investment is simply that Australia's saving rate is too low. The spread of occupational superannuation may contribute to increasing household saving. It is interesting though to consider methods used for encouraging saving in countries where the saving rate is high, such as Japan. There, substantial tax concessions are offered to encourage saving. The Committee recommends that such policies should also be considered for Australia. The Committee concludes, by the way, that privatisation has nothing to offer as a means of mobilising resources for public investment because it is likely to involve an equivalent reduction in private investment. Sale of public assets is unlikely to mobilise a significant net addition to aggregate national investment.

Many other issues are also addressed in this report, but sufficient have been mentioned to give a flavour of the conclusions. I recognise the work of colleagues who were members of the committees involved in the preparation of this report, and in particular the honourable member for Aston (Mr Saunderson), Chairman of the new Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, who has assisted greatly in seeing this report through to tabling. The staff who have worked on the inquiry and report have been indispensable to the outcome. Peter Hamburger's quite outstanding analysis and drafting was essential to both completion and the quality of the report. Evan Tully made an important contribution through his knowledge of the industry and his sustained and intelligent application. Ian Dundas has been indispensable to the conduct of the inquiry and completion of the report through his work as Secretary of the Committee. Many others whom I have mentioned in the foreword made important contributions.

This report is an attempt to outline a strategy for providing the infrastructure framework for increasing national productivity and restructuring the economy. I hope that the report will be extensively discussed and influence thinking about appropriate national economic policies. Ideas can be powerful.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
The Bankruptcy Amendment Bill 1987 marks a major turning point in the administration of bankruptcy law in this country. The amendments proposed by the Bill have been developed in response to:
The finding of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union that bankruptcy laws were being abused by fraudulently motivated insolvency claims;
The Government's commitment to sensible and considered law reform; and
The need for modern bankruptcy law to attack insolvency fraud while also providing appropriate protection for those whose bankruptcy is caused through misfortune.

Honourable members will recall that the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act (No. 2) 1986 amended the Bankruptcy Act in a number of ways, including significant changes to the administrative powers and functions of the Official Trustee. This Bill takes that process one step further by implementing Mr Costigan's recommendation that the trustee in bankruptcy should be equipped with wider powers of investigation in order to combat insolvency fraud. The Bill amends the Act in three significant areas by:
Extending the investigative powers of the trustee;
Reforming part X of the Act and introducing a pre-bankruptcy moratorium period; and
Modernising the Act in relation to spouses' claims and the retention of personal transport.
Insolvency Fraud

It has been recognised for many years that the duty of the Trustee in Bankruptcy is twofold: to realise the debtor's property and distribute the proceeds amongst creditors and also to protect the public interest by investigating a bankrupt's conduct with a view to upholding standards of commercial morality. The powers which the Bankruptcy Act presently gives the trustee to facilitate the discharge of this duty have not kept pace with the wider use of modern commercial structures of companies and trusts. The trustee's ability to investigate companies and trusts associated with the bankrupt is severely circumscribed. For example, a bankrupt who is being examined on oath cannot be asked questions as to any actions he took in his capacity as managing director of a number of companies. Such limits on the trustee's powers have opened the way for unscrupulous debtors to defeat the aims of the bankruptcy law. By using a plethora of family trusts and companies, debtors have been able to organise their affairs so that they are apparently without any assets, while they continue to enjoy the use of property and assets which have the guise of being owned by a company or trust. Practices such as `remuneration skimming', which put assets of companies or trusts associated with a debtor beyond the trustee or creditors, fall into this category.

As well, provisions which presently limit which property of a bankrupt may be realised by the trustees exacerbate the problems. In broad terms, only that property in which the bankrupt had a beneficial interest at the date of the bankruptcy is available to the creditors. These provisions are ineffective to deal with `remuneration skimming'. This Bill proposes to deal with these problems by extending the trustee's powers to investigate the bankrupt's affairs and by enabling the trustee to recoup from companies, partnerships, trusts and other persons assets which have been acquired by the personal efforts of the bankrupt. The Bill will introduce related concepts of `associated entities' and `examinable affairs' and a proposed division 4a of part VI which will enable a court to make orders in relation to the property of entities controlled by a bankrupt.

An associated entity will be one which the bankrupt is able to influence by virtue of close business or family relationships or which is under the control of the bankrupt. The examinable affairs of the bankrupt which the trustee will be able to investigate the financial affairs of an entity associated with the bankrupt insofar as those financial affairs are relevant to the bankrupt's financial affairs. This will be in addition to the existing powers of a trustee to investigate the conduct, dealings and transactions of the bankrupt himself or herself. Associated entities will be placed under an obligation to co-operate with the trustee by making books of account and financial records available where this will assist in shedding light on the bankrupt's financial affairs.

The extension of the powers of the trustee to investigate all the circumstances surrounding a bankruptcy is of itself not enough if at the end of the day no real benefit will flow through to the creditors. Accordingly the court is to be empowered, on application of the trustee, to transfer specified property or an entity to the trustee, or to order the payment by which the net value of the entity has been enhanced, where the trustee establishes:
That the entity acquired the property or the entity's asset position was enhanced during the `examinable period';
During the examinable period, the bankrupt supplied personal services to the entity in accordance with the bankrupt's directions, wishes or instructions; and

The entity made property available, or would in the future, make property available, for the use and enjoyment of the bankrupt in accordance with his or her wishes or instructions, as if the property actually belonged to the bankrupt.

There are a number of provisions requiring the court to take account of the interests of third parties who have an interest in property of the entity, and creditors of the entity. The Government is confident that the new division 4a of part VI will be an effective weapon in stamping out insolvency fraud.
Pre-bankruptcy Moratorium

The Government recognises that bankruptcy is and must be a remedy of last resort. While an insolvent person must be able to obtain relief from his or her creditors, people should be encouraged to explore the alternatives to bankruptcy which are available. Those alternatives include the three forms of voluntary arrangement available under part X-a deed of arrangement, a deed of assignment, or a composition-or by an informal repayment scheme. These alternatives all involve consultation between a debtor and creditors and accordingly they usually proceed in a more co-operative fashion than bankruptcy.

The introduction of pre-bankruptcy moratorium period will allow a debtor to consider the alternatives to bankruptcy. Under a new division 2a of part IV, a debtor will be able to present to the Registrar in Bankruptcy a declaration of intention to present a debtor's petition. Once this declaration is accepted by the Registrar, the debtor will be able to invoke a limited stay upon certain debt recovery processes for a maximum period of seven days. The Registrar will be obliged to direct the debtor's attention to the sources of advice and guidance with respect to the debtor's financial affairs, and to the procedures under the Bankruptcy Act for dealing with insolvency.
Reform of Part X

At the same time the Government is aware that there are flaws in part X which have been exploited by a small number of unscrupulous trustees and solicitors in order to defraud the creditors. The Government has therefore moved quickly to include a group of amendments to part X to minimise the facility for abuse of its procedures. The Government has identified three particular problems with the procedures set out in part X. First, creditors do not receive sufficient information about a debtor's affairs before they accept arrangements under part X. Secondly, there are no provisions in the Act which ensure that previous dealings between a debtor, a particular creditor or creditors and the trustee are disclosed. Thirdly, there is no effective supervision of part X arrangements.

This Bill addresses the first of these three problems by requiring a debtor to submit a statement of affairs at the commencement of the process, rather than at the first meeting of creditors. At present, under part X a debtor may execute an authority to authorise a registered trustee to take control of their property or a solicitor to call a meeting of their creditors. This Bill will require this authority to be supported by a recently prepared statement of affairs which has been given to the trustee or solicitor. The trustee will be required to prepare a report on the debtor's affairs and indicate in that report which of the alternative modes of administration-deed of assignment, deed of arrangement or composition-would be in the best interests of creditors.

The trustee will also be required to indicate whether the creditors should accept a part X arrangement or require the debtor to present a bankruptcy petition. A registered trustee or solicitor will also be required to prepare a statement setting out the alternative special resolutions that may be passed by a meeting of creditors, namely, that that debtor execute a deed of assignment or a deed of arrangement, that the creditors accept a composition or that the debtor present a debtor's petition within seven days of the day on which the resolution is passed. The report by the controlling trustee and the statement outlining the alternative special resolutions which creditors may pass at the meeting are required to be circulated, with notice of the meeting by the controlling trustee or solicitor. These measures are complemented by changes to the proxy provisions relating to voting at meetings under part X.

In relation to the second problem of ensuring that prior dealings between debtors, creditors and trustees are fully disclosed, a new provision is to be inserted into the Act so that a resolution purporting to nominate or appoint a registered trustee to a particular trusteeship will be deemed not to have been duly passed unless the registered trustee has consented to the nomination and has made a declaration concerning his or her professional, business or personal relationship or connection, if any, with the debtor or the creditor or creditors who proposed the resolution.

To overcome the third problem-the inadequacy of the supervisory power in relation to part X arrangements-the Inspector-General in Bankruptcy is to be given the right to apply to the court for orders setting aside deeds and compositions. The Inspector-General will also be empowered to apply to the court for an order that a trustee make good any loss that is caused by a breach of duty by the trustee, and for orders cancelling or suspending the registration of the person as a trustee. Where the court makes an order cancelling the registration of the person as trustee, the bond into which the person entered as a condition of becoming registered will be able to be called in.

In another significant change in this area, examinations of registered trustees will now be conducted before a registrar, rather than before a court. These changes will continue the reforms of administration of the Bankruptcy Act which are designed to free up judicial resources to enable them to be used in the resolution of more important disputes.
Modernising the Act

Numerous other important reforms to modernise the Bankruptcy Act are introduced by this Bill. Section 111-`Postponement of spouse's claims'-is to be repealed. In addition, the provision whereby certain property of the non-bankrupt spouse which had been `made available to or lent to' the now bankrupt spouse was expropriated and made available to the creditors will be repealed.

Sub-section 116 (2) will be amended by including in the category of property not available to the trustee, a motor vehicle or other form of personal transport to the modest value of $2,500. Typically, creditors get little or no benefit from the sale of motor vehicles and this action places considerable hardship on the bankrupt and his family.
Summary

The Bankruptcy Amendment Bill will introduce significant changes to the bankruptcy legislation which will greatly improve the administration of insolvencies in the future. The amendments will, on the one hand, ensure that trustees in bankruptcy can investigate sophisticated commercial arrangements which have used the bankruptcy laws to defraud creditors. On the other hand, in recognition that bankruptcy is not the most appropriate solution in all circumstances, the Bill also introduces procedures to encourage debtors to consider possible alternatives to bankruptcy in appropriate circumstances and introduces reforms to part X to ensure that these alternative procedures can be of real benefit to both debtors and creditors.
Financial Impact Statement

The amendments proposed by the Bill will not involve any additional financial impact upon government expenditure. Following the restructuring of the Official Trustee to which I referred earlier, the resources necessary to discharge the wider investigatory powers conferred by these amendments will be available within the Official Trustee Corporation. I commend the Bill to the House. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Leave granted for debate to continue forthwith.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition supports in general the proposals contained in the Bankruptcy Amendment Bill 1987. The Bill is fairly comprehensive with 62 pages of amendments to the principal Act and 177 pages of explanatory memorandum. It comes at a time when the Australian Law Reform Commission (ALRC) has just handed down a discussion paper entitled `General Insolvency Inquiry' which itself is over 250 pages long. The Bill addresses a number of matters including the problem of insolvency fraud, some reforms to part X of the Bankruptcy Act, the introduction of a pre-bankruptcy moratorium, various provisions to modernise the Act and provisions to enhance the investigatory powers of bankruptcy trustees.

The Commonwealth Bankruptcy Act 1966 deals with individuals and the co-operative companies legislation, of course, deals with corporate bodies. There are three types of proceedings-involuntary bankruptcy, which is initiated by a creditor; voluntary bankruptcy, which is by far the most common; and voluntary administration, which is a means of avoiding bankruptcy by coming to terms with creditors. The procedure for this sort of proceeding is dealt with under part X of the Act. A meeting is called to agree to a deed of assignment or a composition or a deed of arrangement; or the meeting can require that the debtor voluntarily file a bankruptcy petition; or it can clear the way for a creditor's bankruptcy notice to be issued. In the year to 30 June 1986 there were 1,090 involuntary bankruptcies, 4,453 voluntary bankruptcies and 905 persons who had their financial affairs administered under part X of the Act.

I now turn to some of the specific proposals. In regard to insolvency fraud, it was really the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union which raised this issue and I suppose brought it to public light. The Costigan report, for example, referred to the activities of a person called Lockyer who had spent 23 years as a bankrupt and who had used his bankruptcy as a shield against his creditors. In 1980 he and his wife were estimated to be worth $5m. Not surprisingly, Costigan recommended that the Act be amended. The recommendations from Costigan were then the subject of an advice which the Attorney-General's Department obtained from counsel in Melbourne which, I understand, was received in the second half of 1985. The Australian Law Reform Commission states on page 118 of its discussion paper-I am paraphrasing-that in a number of cases the spirit of part X has been deliberately abused. It goes on to say that the process has been manipulated by resort to such devices as giving misleading or inadequate information to creditors, convening meetings in obscure places, not giving sufficient notice of meetings, stacking meetings with persons who exercise or purport to exercise voting rights in favour of the debtor and conducting meetings without an impartial chairman.

The Bill introduces a range of measures, including wider powers of investigation for the Trustee in Bankruptcy, and gives the court the power to require a third person to pay an amount to a trustee. The Bill establishes five criteria which must be met before the court can make such an order. The scope of the provisions to lift the corporate veil is to be found in the definitions of associated entities, close relatives, examinable matter, et cetera. The Opposition, of course, supported the Proceeds of Crime Act which had not dissimilar provisions.

A number of points need to be made about these proposals. Firstly, contrary to what the Minister has just said in his second reading speech when he talked about the Government acting with due haste, the fact is that the Government has been inordinately slow in bringing forward these amendments. Like many of the recommendations of the Costigan Commission, it has been dragged reluctantly to introduce these proposals. That brings me to refer to some remarks of Athol Moffitt in his very good book A Quarter to Midnight. He is a former supreme court judge and the first royal commissioner to investigate organised crime in Australia, in 1973-74. On page 120 of his book he said:
. . . it is inaction and negativism of the present Australian ALP Government, in Canberra and Sydney in particular, which have become and now are matters for grave concern.

I make that comment about this legislation because it is significant. When this Government first came to power, the coalition Government had passed legislation establishing the National Crime Authority. This Government fiddled around with it, had a summit and then introduced some more legislation. It has fiddled around for years and years with legislation. On telephone tapping it has fiddled around for years and years and it is still fiddling around. We had a Bill which has just come from the Senate which really is as a result of the prevarication that this Government has entered into on the question of powers that ought to be available for telephone tapping. Even in the proceeds of crime legislation, which we supported, the Government has been slow to act and I must say that I have real doubts about its capacity to organise and administer properly that sort of legislative initiative. The comment by the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) in his recent report about the lack of staff is certainly noted. But I think what there needs to be is some emphasis on the use of staff and the quality of staff. There are problems in that area in having pay rates which are sufficiently attractive to attract and to keep staff. There are questions such as the interaction between the DPP and the Australian Government Solicitor and the client department such as the Australian Taxation Office. Those are very important issues which we in the Opposition now see it as important to be focused upon. We have had some success with our prodding in regard to the civil remedies area of the DPP. We see an increase in dollars-77 per cent in fact-in that area in the Budget and an extra 20 staff. That is good. We give credit where credit is due, but this has occurred after the prodding that we have undertaken. I put some questions on notice on this matter because I think it is important that the Government get on with this job. We will certainly keep it up to the mark as best we are able to do so. Honourable members will also remember that prior to the Proceeds of Crime Act amendments were necessary to the powers of the Director of Public Prosecutions. It took over 12 months before they were prepared and through this place.

Some particular points need to be made about the investigative powers. Under clause 98, the owner of premises must allow reasonable use of facilities to a person holding a warrant. The provision is similar to that in the fringe benefits tax and other recent legislation. On those occasions we moved amendments, unsuccessfully, to require reasonable reimbursement of any expenses incurred-those amendments, obviously, being refused by the Government in this place. The clause in this Bill is drawn in very wide terms. However, it is my view that the court should properly read down those powers and even introduce a requirement for reimbursement. The Minister for Justice (Senator Tate), in his comments to the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, pointed out that the sanction against non-compliance is available only when non-compliance occurs without reasonable excuse. Whilst I note what he said, I draw to the attention of the House the Opposition's concern about the width of some of those provisions.

On the other side of the coin, in a sense, whilst those powers appear fairly wide, they all beg the question because by and large the powers rest on some link back to the bankrupt: for example, I interpret new section 77a (2) (e) to mean that whether a matter is relevant to the investigation would be reviewable by a court and, to that extent, it may be said that it is not much different from the provision under the existing legislation. I dare say that one day that will be subject to a dispute in the courts as the provisions lifting the corporate veil come into effect immediately and will be relevant to existing bankrupts or persons in the courts. I presume that someone such as Dr Edelsten will be in to test some of the provisions sooner rather than later. Some of the Trimbole relations who are still in the courts may have reason to try to fend off the implications of some of the amendments.

The Northern Territory and South Australian branches of the Insolvency Practitioners Association of Australia (IPAA) have been in contact with my colleague Senator Messner. Basically, they issued some warnings about the extent of some of the provisions in division 4a. I say in response that, in the end, it is a matter of competing policy interests-the need to stop fraud, to prevent transfers intended to defraud creditors, against the need of commerce to have a system of corporate entities with restrictions on liability. In many respects, the extent of those measures is not new. I have mentioned the proceeds of crime legislation. We support the Bill, but I share the Association's concern. I think that, as a Parliament, we will need to keep that under review as time goes on and as we have experience of dealing with the provisions.

I now turn to the proposal for a pre-bankruptcy moratorium which is properly and better referred to as the Tuckey amendment because I understand that it came about as a result of representations by my colleague the honourable member for O'Connor to the Attorney-General. The measure gives debtors seven days to consider the alternatives to bankruptcy. The Registrar is to direct the debtor to sources of advice and guidance, although no additional resources have been made available for this purpose. The Law Reform Commission says that some debtors have become bankrupt unnecessarily; in other words, part X may have been more appropriate. It says that there is no public counselling or advisory service and proposes that such a service be funded by Commonwealth legal aid agencies.

The IPAA has not supported the proposal. Its view was that creditors would be disadvantaged while the trustee cools his heels in the cooling off period. This is one of those issues which, in the end, is very much an on-balance decision. I am told that there are no counselling facilities available. Certainly, none are provided for in the Budget. Whilst not opposing the proposal because there have been some circumstances, such as those which the honourable member for O'Connor raised, where people have been adversely affected by the `sudden death' nature of the existing arrangement, I think that the Government ought to at least provide a response to this matter today.

The reform of part X includes a range of matters-a requirement that a statement of affairs be prepared prior to the debtor authorising the calling of a meeting; a requirement that the statement be provided to creditors when they are notified of the meeting; a requirement that the trustee prepare a report for creditors to assist the meetings of creditors; provisions to the effect that meetings that do not fulfil certain criteria are invalidated; the Inspector-General to have the right to apply to set aside part X deeds, et cetera; the examination of trustees to be by Registrar, not the court; the creditor spouse be not entitled to vote at the creditors meeting; and the giving of proxies, which is referred to in the ALRC report.

The requirement that a statement of affairs be prepared and provided to creditors prior to the meeting has been resisted by the Insolvency Practitioners Association of Australia. It says that there will be consequent delay to the disadvantage of creditors and that creditors will not be better informed. It says that meetings can be adjourned and that that is preferable in the few cases where additional information is needed. It also resists the requirement that the trustee prepare a report for the creditors. It says that the new requirements are an overreaction to the activities of a small minority who have abused a process that has otherwise worked well. However, the Law Reform Commission report supports the proposals in the Bill. In my view, the proposal to ensure that creditors have information prior to a meeting is reasonable and, in fact, corresponds to a not dissimilar requirement in bankruptcy.

It is worth reading to the House the statement by the Law Reform Commission on this subject. Before doing so, I note that the discussion paper also proposes that only a registered insolvency practitioner should be able to accept an authority under part X. This is not taken up in the Bill, but I think that the Government should give very serious consideration to that proposal. On the question of information being provided prior to meetings, page 120 of the Law Reform Commission's report states:

The Commission considers that creditors should be provided with adequate information about the debtor's financial affairs and the debtor's proposals a reasonable time prior to the meeting. If that were mandatory, it would lessen the prospect of voting manipulation and adjournments. Also, as will become apparent from another proposal in relation to proxy voting, providing creditors with sufficient information before the meeting will enable them to participate in the decision-making process-even if they do not actually attend the meeting.

The report goes on to outline the proposal. I think that that is a sensible outlook to take. I have spoken to Mr Ron Harmer, the commissioner in charge, about it, and that is the basis upon which the Opposition has come to its view, although it has listened very carefully to the views which have been put to it.

The proposal about the proxy power is another area raised by the IPAA. On balance, I am not greatly convinced that the solution proposed in the Bill, although it might be a marginal improvement, is the best possible solution. The IPAA has suggested that the difficulty with the amendment is that creditors may become locked into a position before a meeting and that that position may not be appropriate to the mood of the meeting. The amendment really aims at overcoming the problem where the chairman effectively collects proxies and then uses those proxies to the disadvantage of the other creditors. The fear of the IPAA is that, by prejudging the situation, we may end up with more part Xs going into bankruptcy with assets dissipated rather than encouraging people to trade out of their difficulties. It has been suggested to me that maybe there is a halfway house on this matter. The suggestion revolves around the idea that the proxy would not be directed where there is no possibility that the proxy will be an interested party-for example, where a finance company appoints a proxy to represent its interests. I do not today raise a solution to that. It is an area that needs to be looked at further and I encourage the Government to do so.

Other matters which are raised by the amendments include, firstly, maintenance agreements under section 86 of the Family Law Act, which are given protection under the bankruptcy legislation. Apparently there have been some fraudulent abuses and that matter is referred to at page 254 of the Law Reform Commission report dealing with matrimonial property. The amendments will remove the protection in cases of fraud. Secondly, the repeal of section 111 is supported and recommended by the Commission. That is referred to at page 189 of the report. The effect of the repeal is that a spouse's claim will rank with those of other unsecured creditors.

Thirdly, section 116 (2) lists property that is not divisible-that is, it does not vest in the trustee and is thus kept by the bankrupt. The amendments allow a bankrupt to keep a vehicle to the value of $2,500. Existing provisions include clothing, tools of trade, compensation and rural assistance grants. The IPAA also has doubts about the proposal to allow a bankrupt to keep a vehicle to the value of $2,500. There is some suggestion that impending bankrupts will be out there buying their cars in anticipation of bankruptcy. That is obviously a possibility, but the reality is that there will always be some abuses in this area, and the abuses of a minority should not necessarily be the basis upon which the majority ought to suffer-an argument put by the IPAA on another matter. In my electorate, there are many places where there is no reasonable public transport, and to be without transport is to be deprived of the opportunity to get off the treadmill, to get a job and to get out of adverse financial circumstances. I and the Opposition support that provision. We believe it is a reasonable measure. Again, we have been careful to take into account the various points of view that have been put to us.

One of the matters that are not covered in the Bill relates to priority among creditors as it affects the Commissioner of Taxation. The Commissioner's priority was the subject of a Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs report in 1978. The Senate Committee's report was partially accepted by the passage of legislation in 1981, which diminished the extensive priority given to debts due to the Commonwealth. The existing priority is for unremitted group tax, withholding tax, unremitted natural resource and royalty payment deductions and prescribed payments deductions. I will not say anything about the substantive matters because time will get away from me and these are not specifically before us in the Bill, but the Commissioner has called for public discussion on that, and I think that that is another area at which the Government could look.

Lastly, I want to go back to my opening remarks. Insolvency is a valuable indicator of trends in the economic system. It is an indictment of the Government that the level of bankruptcy in Australia has reached an all time high. This year the record set last year was smashed, and it looks as though another record will be set in 1987-88. That is a considerable indictment of the Government's policies. It is the biggest taxing government in our history. We had that promise about the trilogy, which was just a sick joke. The Government told people that it would bring down the levels of taxation, but they have gone up and up as a result of the Government's ideological views and the way in which it attempts to run the country. No wonder Gough Whitlam spoke this weekend about what a disaster the Government is. He is probably right. He was bad enough, but this Government will take the cake, according to that former Prime Minister.

I thank the Insolvency Practitioners Association of Australia, Mr Ted Andrew, Mr Michael Mount and others who have been in contact with us. The Bill is now in the House of Representatives, so the Opposition is not in the position to move amendments successfully against the Government, but I am concerned to raise the issues that have been brought before us and I hope that the Government will look at them in a constructive and sensible way. I also want to pay a compliment to Mr Ronald Harmer, who has been the commissioner in charge of the Law Reform Commission's reference into insolvency. Until 30 November, he was calling for submissions and I found his report useful. It was easy to read and it competently covered many areas of this important policy subject. The Opposition supports the Bill in principle. We have raised a number of matters and I look forward to the Government's response later this afternoon.

SPEECH.PARA: As the Deputy Prime Minister and Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) said in his second reading speech on the Bankruptcy Amendment Bill, it marks a major turning point in the administration of bankruptcy law in this country. I believe that it will be welcomed by all sectors of the community, especially those that have been concerned about the way in which bankruptcy laws have been abused. It will be welcomed by those who have long seen the need for modern bankruptcy law to attack insolvency fraud. It will be welcomed by those who believe that the system has not worked properly, who have listened to the calls of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union and of the Law Reform Commission, which have said that things have not worked as they should. Anyone with a reasonable mind will say that the amendments before the Parliament are a significant reform. They will address the problem of insolvency fraud yet at the same time will acknowledge the need for appropriate protection for those whose bankruptcy is caused not by some rort but by misfortune.

The Attorney-General and the Government deserve commendation from everybody who is involved and interested in this issue for the legislative action that is being taken now. It is the Hawke Government that has taken the action.

The honourable member for Flinders criticised the Hawke Government but he was in the previous Government when the same problems existed. The figures that he has used go back for years, to when the Fraser-Howard Government was in power. Did it do anything to solve the problem? No; it has been the Hawke Government that has been prepared to tackle the problems and find solutions. It is the Hawke Government that has heeded the calls of the accounting and legal professions and has acted on the findings of the Costigan Commission, that bankruptcy laws were being abused by fraudulent claims involving insolvency. It has been the Hawke Government that has acted to curb the activities of unscrupulous debtors, and has put an end to the questionable practices of some trustees who seemed more prepared to look after the debtors and the future of those debtors than to do anything for the prosperity and the rights of the creditors. It is the Hawke Government that has been willing to introduce a Bill and a new era into the bankruptcy arena. It must result in better returns for all creditors. It will now be possible to get at the assets of the bankrupt who, in the past, has camouflaged his true wealth amongst family trusts and companies. I know that in my area there has been case after case of people who have gone bankrupt and yet, regardless of the hundreds of thousands of dollars that they have left tied up-as we say, dogs are tied everywhere-and the number of creditors that they have left in trouble, they have been back in business a little while later.

I instance the case of one fellow who stood for the Liberal Party of Australia on, I think, three occasions who went bankrupt twice and still got back into business in another town. Only recently, he has gone bankrupt again in Rockhampton. It just amazes me how this can continue to happen. However, it has happened because of the way these people have hidden away their assets. I am hoping that this will change.

Clearly, bankruptcy has been abused as a form of relief from debt. The Government deserves credit for taking action to curb that abuse. I think that the importance of the bankruptcy issue has come to the fore recently not just because of the concern that people have had with the business sector but also, more importantly, because of the failure in the personal bankruptcy area. In May this year a number of reports were published, I suppose because it was just after the statistics came out. The Australian Financial Review carried a report entitled `Personal bankruptcies hit a record high'. The journalist, Julie Power, said:
High interest rates and the availability of plastic credit cards have led to a record number of personal bankruptcies.

She went on in her article to say how the South Australian Small Business Corporation had found steep rises in personal bankruptcies in all States. She said that the worst is yet to come. The thing that concerned me most in that report was that my home State of Queensland topped the study with an increase in bankruptcies to 30 March this year of 60 per cent. South Australia recorded a 50 per cent increase, Western Australia 49 per cent, Victoria 44 per cent, the Northern Territory 35 per cent, New South Wales 33 per cent and Tasmania 30 per cent. On 18 May the Melbourne Age carried an editorial entitled `So who is to blame for Australia's bankruptcy boom?'. It is a pity the honourable member for Flinders is leaving the chamber because I think he should read that editorial. It might give him some understanding of the situation. That article pointed out that last year 6,500 individuals and businesses went into bankruptcy. It stated that the figure painted a disturbing picture of the extent of credit distress in Australia. I ask honourable members to note the emphasis in that article which is not on the economic policies of the Federal Government but on the issue of credit distress. That is the issue on which I want to dwell.

The Melbourne Herald of 25 May had a headline entitled `Rising bankruptcy rate creates a new social class'. The writer, Bill Hitchings, made the point that the level of personal debt in Australia was increasing such that the social stigma once attached to bankruptcy was fast disappearing. He said that the number was so great and that so many people were being caught up that bankruptcy was not longer a social stigma. He said that the number of bankruptcies had increased from 3,889 in 1986 to 5,478 this year. Again in the same month, the Queensland Courier-Mail of 27 May had a headline `Australia counts its Bankruptcy Costs'. The figures it cited showed that between June 1986 and March 1987, 1,299 businesses and individuals went into bankruptcy in that State. This may not sound very much if one says it very quickly, but that is 16 more bankruptcies than New South Wales and the Australian Capital Territory combined.

Clearly, there is a major problem. I suppose that of all the States Queensland is of the greatest concern. I am concerned that this is taking place. We need to ask why. I believe that whilst we might say that this relates in some way to the lack of support given in Queensland to small business, I still believe that it comes back mainly to credit availability. I refer again to the Melbourne Age editorial because it was the most enlightening. It targeted the causes of bankruptcy, as well as citing the statistics. The editorial referred to a Mr Denis Nelthorpe, the Co-ordinator of the Consumer Credit Legal Service, who said that finance companies no longer stand out as a great menace in the credit industry. That is a very interesting point. He claimed that the banks and credit unions were becoming equally as aggressive in both lending and debt collecting. I believe that Mr Nelthorpe has hit the nail on the head.

There is a need for lending institutions to rethink their credit policies and practices. Fortunately, this Government realises that there is a problem. It was only last week that a joint announcement was made by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Mr Staples) of a review of consumer financial services. The essential purpose of the review is to examine the provision of adequate protection for consumer interest and also the need to maintain an efficient financial system. As the Minister for Consumer Affairs has also explained to the consumer affairs committee which I chair, this review will be carried out by a group of officials from the Department of the Treasury, the Bureau of Consumer Affairs, the Reserve Bank of Australia the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and the Department of Social Security. Because this is a nationwide problem, the Minister and the Treasurer have ensured that the nation will be involved. Invitations have now been extended to all the States and Territory governments to become members of the review group.

The review is to examine a wide range of consumer financial services and products such as housing finance, credit cards, personal loans and the charging of fees on some financial transactions. Anyone who is interested in this issue must realise how timely this review is. Certainly, it is in line with the action being taken individually by the Minister for Consumer Affairs when he announced, I think, in October this year that he intended to hold a mini-summit or a conference on consumer debt in 1988. I applaud him for this. I know that that is the feeling of consumer groups right across the nation because they are fed up with what is taking place in the credit market. They are fed up with being ripped off. They are fed up with being the underdog. It is time that someone took charge of the issue. I welcome the initiative taken by the Minister.

The mini-summit will examine the rapid growth in consumer debt in Australia. I am told that consumer debt now amounts to something like $23 billion. That is a debt of $23,000m in this small country of Australia. The summit also will consider State credit laws. Importantly, it will consider the rapid rise in overcommitment and bankruptcies. This is the issue that the newspaper editorial was talking about. It discussed the availability of easy credit that has led to overcommitment which, in turn, has led in many cases to personal bankruptcy.

I believe that it is time for the banks, the building societies and credit unions and all the other financial institutions to rethink their responsibilities. It is time for them to rethink their responsibilities to people, those people who cannot afford the credit they are offering. Also, it is time for them to rethink their responsibilities to pay their way in credit education. It is all very well to lend money, but what about counselling people and educating them so that they know how to use the money and what they can afford to borrow; so that they know their capacity to repay. That does not seem to be done. It seems more like a situation of bank managers in some sort of competitive race trying to outdo the next one; trying to lend more money, regardless of whom they might be lending to and regardless of the consequences at the end of the road.

I suggest that there is a need for credit providers to rethink all these responsibilities. I believe that the banks in particular, but the other institutions as well, are shirking this responsibility. There is a need to look at their promotion tactics. Everywhere one looks there are pamphlets describing how easy money is to get and saying that one can walk in and get it or ring up and get it within 24 hours and that there is no check on the borrower. It is nonsense to believe that this is how the money markets ought to operate. It is nonsense to suggest that that is how the credit providers ought to practise their profession. There is a need also to look very hard at credit charges, the cost of money the institutions are lending.

Recently again the Minister for Consumer Affairs briefed a number of members on consumer credit insurance. If ever there is a Pandora's box in the area of credit, this must be it. I congratulate the Minister for taking the initiative to ensure that members of parliament everywhere have received the excellent report entitled Need or Greed, a report on consumer credit insurance prepared by the Australian Financial Counselling and Credit Reform Association. I suggest that it should be compulsory reading for every member of parliament, both State and Federal, to understand what is taking place.

That report cites the case of a consumer who borrowed $10,000 but had to pay an additional $6,396, not for interest, but just in insurance costs. The consumer credit insurance cover cost $3,248 and there was an additional $3,148.46 in credit charges on the insurance premiums. Just imagine a person who borrowed $10,000 having to pay an extra $6,396. Talk about a rip-off. I wonder who would have counselled persons who took out such a loan. I wonder who would have had the opportunity to tell them that if they borrowed that $10,000 they would be required to pay not only interest charges but also, if they wanted to insure themselves against having an accident and being prevented from working, the cost of that insurance. It could cost them so much that they could lose everything they have.

The Victorian Consumer Credit Legal Service Co-operative Limited has conducted studies that have found that the average cost of consumer credit insurance added as much as 15 per cent to the amount financed. Its studies found that across the board insurance related costs represented in most cases 69 per cent of the net amount financed and 24.4 per cent of the total amount payable. Surely no one can accept that situation; no one can say that is fair. I believe it should not be allowed. Yet at this time deregulation of the industry is being sought. At this time people are calling for the number of rules to be reduced and for the impediments placed on business to be removed. Let us ensure that there is competition. Let us ensure that the industry has its own rules. Let us ensure that consumers who borrow money are made aware of the full details applying to loans and the ultimate cost of loans. Let us try to ensure that there is true competition in this field.

The second matter I wish to mention is that of overcommitment. That matter was mentioned in the report to which I have just referred and was raised at the consumer conference that I attended in New Zealand with the Minister for Consumer Affairs. It is an issue that concerns all the States. A working party has been looking into it. It is an issue that must concern every person who has a social conscience. There is a need for lenders and credit providers to show self-restraint. If we cannot achieve that by legislative means, we must find some way of achieving it by embarrassment. We must expose those who cause trauma and harm and who destroy the quality of life of thousands of Australians by demonstrating a lack of restraint in the lending of money.

The question must arise whether the courts should get tough on finance houses that knowingly lend money to people who lack the capacity to repay. A few judgments have been handed down in respect of unconscionable contracts. The courts have ruled that the lender should have known the consequences of providing the loan. We must get tougher. We must make suffer those bank managers who approve loans over the telephone when they know that they will not get the money back. The reputation of the bank managers must be put on the line.

It is time also that the banks rethought the value of plastic credit. Easy credit sounds wonderful. It is simple for a person to purchase items from a retailer by using a credit card. However, there is a cost at the end of it. It amazes me that banks send off letters informing people that their credit limit has been increased from $1,200 to $2,000 or from $2,000 to $3,000. Such a person might be unemployed, but the banks carry out no check as to that person's financial position at the time. It seems that every now and again banks with extra money increase the amount of credit available to their clients who use plastic credit cards. I suggest that that is irresponsible and it deserves exposing.

On behalf of those members of parliament who work with me in the consumer affairs area, I give an undertaking to this House that we will expose those banks that continue to act irresponsibly. We will expose the building societies and the credit unions that do not act responsibly by testing the capacity of their clients to repay borrowed moneys. We will expose those lending institutions that are not carrying out what we believe to be their responsibilities to the community in the provision of credit. I know that that undertaking will be backed up by honourable members opposite and by people in every other legislature in this land. We are getting to the point where we are seeing people destroyed because of the availability of money.
