SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bankruptcy Amendment Bill 1987 is the result of a report by the Australian Law Reform Commission on debt recovery and insolvency. That report made quite a few recommendations, although only some of them have been incorporated in this legislation. The report contains 47 recommendations, covering about 12 pages. It appears to me that insolvency is a Commonwealth responsibility and that not many people specialise in treating its causes. All we seem to be interested in is the act of insolvency and wrapping up the affairs of a person who is put in that unfortunate situation.

SPEECH.PARA: It appals me that honourable members on both sides of the House today have cited figures selectively. The Opposition spokesman in this area, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), cited some statistics from an official report. The honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) said that those figures were cited selectively, but then embarked upon citing figures selectively himself. However, he cited only percentage increases. It never ceases to confound me that the honourable member for Capricornia takes every opportunity in this House to slam his own State. I would have thought that members of this House would have had at least some responsibility to be loyal to their own State. However, as I say, that seems to be a hallmark of the honourable member's contributions to debate.

The honourable member for Capricornia cited the number of bankruptcies that occurred in a period that he selected. I intend to select the period from 1985-86 to 1986-87. The honourable member claimed that Queensland had the largest increase in bankruptcies at some 60 per cent. The figures for the two years to which I referred show that bankruptcies in Queensland increased from 1,251 to 1,717, which is a 37 per cent increase. I have not examined all of these figures, but the increase in South Australia was 46 per cent and the increase in Victoria is 40 per cent. I think that the figure for Western Australia would be similar. Although the honourable member accused the Opposition of citing figures selectively, he did the same thing himself.

It is not my contention that the States are responsible for the bankruptcies that occur within their jurisdiction. The Bankruptcy Act is a Commonwealth Act, and it is fairly well known that bankruptcies are not the sole responsibility of the individual State in which they occur. Like anyone else, bankrupts have the unfortunate ability to cross State borders. Bankruptcies, like liquidations, affect more States than one. However, it is on record that over a three-year period the number of bankruptcies has increased immeasurably. Although I acknowledge that there is a delayed reaction element to bankruptcies-in other words, the point of impact of the bankruptcy can be removed from the place in which the circumstances of the bankruptcy occurred-the Government cannot walk away from the fact that it has been on the treasury bench for the past four or five years. It cannot suggest that the increase in the figures for that three-year period is the result of what occurred during the years of the Fraser Government. Let me make some comparisons. In 1984-85 there were 4,664 bankruptcies throughout Australia; in 1985-86, when the influence of the Fraser Government must have been lessening, there were 5,539; in 1986-87, when the influence of the Hawke Labor Government would have had a full impact on the figures, there was a massive increase in bankruptcies to 7,495. That is quite a considerable increase over the figure for 1984-85. One could cite these figures selectively.

Bankruptcy details were fairly well embodied in the 1984-85 report on the Bankruptcy Act. Table No. 10 in that report sets out the major causes of bankruptcy. The report selected 1,284 examples of such bankruptcies. The report shows that in 596 cases the reason for failure was economic conditions. In other words, 46 per cent of bankrupts claimed that they failed because of economic reasons. I am not suggesting that the Government is responsible for all of those bankruptcies. However, it is worth doing a breakdown of those 596 bankruptcies. I note that 262 bankruptcies were due to lack of sufficient capital. In other words, the bankrupt person could not borrow in the current climate sufficient funds to do what was needed to expand the business. In 247 cases economic conditions were given as the reason for failure; excessive interest payments was given as the reason in 40 cases; and bad debt experience was given as the reason in 47 cases. In all this, the Government must take some considerable blame for setting up an economic climate in this country that encourages bankruptcy.

The honourable member for Capricornia spoke about the extent of credit. Nothing disturbs me more than to think that in most instances Australians are financially extended to levels greater than their capacities to service, and certainly to levels greater than individual companies lending that money would appreciate. It is a plastic society and I suggest that at the moment any person under the age of 21 could have available credit of about $2,000 to $3,000. One cannot have it both ways. One cannot blame this on the lending institutions when the Treasurer (Mr Keating) tells us that the economic situation in this country is so good. It does not matter whether the dollar is up or the dollar is down, we are always told that the economy is in good shape. There is an expectation among people that if the economy is so good and companies are prepared to lend, they have the capacity to borrow to the extent that the lenders are prepared to give them. In many instances, the reason given in the report on the reasons for bankruptcy in 1984-85 still apply.

I mention a couple of areas of government responsibility. One is interest rates. Many bankruptcies result when interest rates contract to a low figure, economic conditions turn around and then interest rates rise appreciably. At the beginning of this year I took a sample from a major bank which showed that in a period of about 12 months there were 21 adjustments of interest rates. Unfortunately, those adjustments were not downwards; they were mainly upwards. Someone who could have borrowed money at an interest rate of 12.5 per cent was eventually paying 21 or 22 per cent. Interest rates are a direct responsibility of this Government, a government that has had massive deficits in its Budgets in the past four years. This Government has had to borrow some $23 billion. Again, this is an example to the people. People think that if it is good enough for the Government it is good enough for them. The impact of the Government's action has sent interest rates sky high. This has a major economic impact on bankruptcies in this country. The Government must bear some responsibility for all the circumstances I have just mentioned, quite apart from interest rates.

TALK.START.PARA: —A good point.

—The Government ought to appreciate that. It should not slam the building societies and the banks of this country, the people who give credit, when they are actually operating on a standard set by the Government. The honourable member for Wide Bay is evidently in agreement that the Government must take some responsibility in this regard. The report does not show the impact of interest rates over the past few years. I just want to mention the fringe benefits tax. That is a tax that is paid when no income is being earned. It is fair enough that personal income tax or company tax is paid on a profit earning basis but fringe benefits tax is quite the reverse. There is also a domino effect well down the line. The effect of a rural bankruptcy or a small business bankruptcy goes right down the line to the individual. That is the accumulating or domino effect. These are areas for which the Government has a direct responsibility.

SPEECH.PARA: I must also condemn the Government for allowing companies going into liquidation and bankrupts to accumulate Commonwealth debts well in excess of what a prudent lender would allow. It has come to my notice that the taxation authorities-not so much in connection with the amount of tax owed personally by a business but in sales tax, group tax and in circumstances where people act as agents-have allowed some individuals to continue for nine to 12 months before they have called in their debts. If a business is operating on that basis but to all external appearances it is paying its way, who would question giving that company further credit in light of the fact that the Government is already doing so? That is what the Australiamn Taxation Office is doing.

Some fees-landing fees, licence fees and so on-are due also to the Department of Transport. I know of one instance in which the former Department of Aviation extended credit on such fees to a company that could not make its way for two years. I believe the Commonwealth has a responsibility to deal fairly with people but also to treat them as businesses wanting advice and to call in its debts when it should. No business in Australia would allow credit beyond 30, 45 or 50 days without calling in its debts. It could not afford to. A company's cash flow would be such that the credit manager would have to demand that money. If that is the case so far as individuals are concerned, surely payments of taxes and fees must be insisted upon by the Commonwealth. Of course, in many cases the Commonwealth stands in a priority position to other creditors; so that is an anomaly.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are also pretty slow payers.

—I was just coming to that point. It is an important one. How many bankruptcies have been forced on individuals because of slow payment by the Government? The Government will hold up some progress payment because of some minor dispute. Again, I suggest the Government is not the best party to join in a contract with a private individual or someone in private enterprise because it does not know the ramifications, but a delay in progress payment can be substantial to a person in business. I know of cases where a sole practitioner or an individual could have a debt owed by a government-not only the Commonwealth, the States are involved also-of $80,000 to $100,000. That is a substantial part of that person's cash flow and capital requirements. As the honourable member for Mallee says, the Government has a responsibility to prevent some of these bankruptcies by acting towards its clients as it should in private enterprise.

SPEECH.PARA: These bankruptcies are only one of the indicators of how our society is failing. Our society is failing also because of government action. I would hesitate to try to number the lost opportunities in society because of government initiated action-the businesses that have failed to expand, the businesses that cannot take opportunities because of their economic positions and, above all, the businesses that do not want to expand in the face of massive red tape forced upon them by government. It is a rare occasion when a business is able to take on the challenge of government regulation, government licensing, government fees and government approvals, fight through and establish a business in what I regard as a very harsh economic climate compared with the climate in other parts of the world.

The Bill addresses some of the problems I have found for quite some time not only in bankruptcies but also in liquidations. One is that so often when one compares bankruptcies with company liquidations there is no parallel or comparison to give equal emphasis to both sides. I note the Bill will give a right to the court, the Inspector-General or a trustee to go further than just the face value of what a person has in a company. They can inquire into a company structure. This has arisen from an anomaly brought out in the Costigan report of a person who spent 23 years as a bankrupt but who was able to accumulate, with his wife, the amount of $5m. These amendments are timely. In fact, they are probably long overdue, but they do try to address one of the problems.

A major cause of bankruptcies today comes from the advice or counsel available to people in society. The Bill before us tries to address this problem to make sure that the people who are in insolvent conditions are given the opportunity of trying to work it out with their creditors and with society. Some provisions allow official arrangements where creditors come together and try to get a person out of trouble. I believe this is right and proper, but it flies in the face of a report that came to us at the beginning of this year concerning the South Australian Department of Social Security advising clients on how they might proceed with a bankruptcy. As a matter of fact, it was encouraging bankruptcy so that people could then enter the social security system and get something from it. No one knows the distress people feel when they are in a situation where they cannot pay their debts. But there is not the same onus on people these days to meet their debts as there was years ago. To have a government department actually encouraging people to go into bankruptcy I think again flies in the face of what this Bill is about. I am happy to see that some attempt has been made to rectify that.

Obviously what is being suggested here has the approval of the Opposition. Again, I think it depends on the material that is used, in an argument of this kind, as to how one takes facts and figures, but I do believe that a lot more attention has to be paid to the method of advice and counsel that is available. I have found that many people are good technically in the work they undertake in the small businesses that they are in, but they fail in the final aspect of being able to come to grips with the cash flows, cash requirements, debtor control and stock control in such a way that they are faced with the situation where the easiest opportunity might be to go into bankruptcy or liquidation. If this Bill does nothing else but try to set the record straight and assist a person to recovery, it is going in the right direction.

As far as I am concerned, the domino effect is very important. I have had experience over the last two years in this field, and this is where I have a slight advantage over the honourable member for Capricornia, who, as I understand it, has never really been in the heartland of business full time. I know that he has been a newspaper proprietor, but that was when he was also holding down the job as the Leader of the Australian Labor Party in Queensland, so it has never been a full time proposition. Many examples over the last two years would suggest that the major cause of liquidations is the amount of insolvencies, bankruptcies and bad debts that a firm has to suffer. My experience over the last two years, which I believe is a reflection on the market-place and the economic situation of the country, is that liquidations are running at record highs. Many companies are being placed into insolvent positions caused by the credit that they have granted in normal commercial transactions to people who are going bankrupt and who have taken the line of least resistance and taken that through the courts on a company or individual basis.

This matter is the responsibility of the Commonwealth. No one doubts that. The Commonwealth also has a responsibility in this matter to make sure that the symptoms that people suffer are no longer within our society.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jakobsen Ms C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my pleasure to speak on the Bankruptcy Amendment Bill tonight and to follow the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) and the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Mr Staples) in this debate. The Bankruptcy Amendment Bill is an important piece of legislation from the perspective of government, business and consumers. Primarily it provides for changes to the Bankruptcy Act which permit investigation of a bankrupt's ability to access or use assets which may be indirectly owned through a maze of corporate arrangements. As was mentioned earlier in this debate by the Minister for Consumer Affairs, the need for this investigative capability was pointed out by the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union during its review of the dealings of that union some time ago.

SPEECH.PARA: The increasing incidence of so-called insolvency fraud is now widely recognised. This Bill will ensure that the investigatory powers available to the trustee in a bankruptcy are sufficient to permit penetration of the corporate veil in pursuit of a bankrupt's true assets. Persons who have been discharged from bankruptcy will be liable to be examined on oath and persons who are, or may be, associated with a bankrupt and with corporations, trusts and partnerships with which a bankrupt is or has been associated will also be liable to be summoned for examination. The scope of questioning at such an examination will be widened to take in all of the financial activities of the bankrupt, including activities in his or her capacity as an officer of an associated company.

It should be remembered at this juncture that the creditors who are cheated as a result of insolvency fraud will often be small business proprietors who rely on payment of their debts to maintain their own financial viability and stay out of the bankruptcy arena themselves. To this extent, and only to this extent, I concur with the comments of the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) on the domino effect of bankruptcy. However, he is quite wrong to claim that our Government's economic policies have caused an increase in business bankruptcies. In fact, the rate of business bankruptcies has been relatively stable in the years since the Hawke Government attained office. The overall increase in bankruptcies is attributable to the substantial increase in non-business bankruptcies and I intend to discuss some of the reasons for this at a later stage.

There are many protections to business as creditors in this Bill, particularly the requirement that a statement of the debtor's financial affairs must be presented to the initial meeting of creditors and that a trustee must declare any association with the debtor so that a potential conflict of interest may be exposed. Other amendments contained in the Bill include the reform of part X of the Act and the introduction of a limited pre-bankruptcy moratorium to enable debtors to consider possible alternatives to bankruptcy. Some time ago the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) agreed to consider ways in which the Act could be amended to ensure that the incidence of mistake bankruptcies was minimised and the pre-bankruptcy moratorium will enable a debtor contemplating bankruptcy to consider all the possible alternatives to that course of action.

It is obvious that many people declare themselves bankrupt without recognising the full consequences of their actions and certainly without properly considering the alternatives. Frequently such people would be better advised to approach their creditors for a reduction in the overall debt in return from early settlement. Creditors are seldom enamoured with the prospect of a debtor going bankrupt and will usually see reason when the person's predicament is made clear, especially if there is some way that the major portion of the debt can be paid.

Like other members of this House, I have come across a number of cases where a bankrupt has compounded the problem by withholding property from the bailiff. Such action stems from panic in my view and may be less likely to occur if the person contemplating bankruptcy is properly advised of its ramifications and is acquainted with other ways of working through the debt. For instance, one of my constituents recently experienced severe financial difficulties in his business-through the theft of client records by a competitor I might add-and was seriously considering bankruptcy as the only option remaining to him. He was fortunate enough, however, to receive advice which drew his attention to the alternatives and he is currently trading his way out of debt, with the assistance of his wife in the business, while also holding down another job to improve the cash flow of the business and his own ability to repay the debt.

By and large ordinary people do not want to be in debt, neither do they want to become bankrupt. They will usually do everything in their power to pay a creditor. Unfortunately, too often the financial deck is stacked against them.

Contrary to the claims of the Opposition, bankruptcy is not the province of unsuccessful business alone; it is also the domain of the poor, the harassed, the credit crazed and the exploited. On a significant number of occasions business itself is the cause of bankruptcy rather than the victim. In fact, the majority of people becoming bankrupt each year are consumers who become bankrupt through misfortune or poor judgment.

The widespread use of the plastic fantastic credit card, 24-hour accessibility of automatic bank telling machines, electronic funds transfers and the ready availability of expensive credit have all combined to exacerbate the likelihood of consumer bankruptcy. There is little competent advice available for even the most wary consumer on the actual cost of money borrowed. For instance, how many people in Australia are using their bank credit cards as a regular means of extending the purchasing power of their pay packets without realising that failure to pay the accumulated balance will result in an interest charge of 22 per cent or thereabouts? Some banks even levy the charge when the balance has been cleared within 30 days.

The proliferation of expensive consumer credit insurance has become a blot on the financial landscape in Australia and many hundreds of people are falling prey to its ravages. I endorse the remarks of the honourable member for Capricornia in this regard. Such people are misled by the product propaganda and the sales pitch of the people who are trying to sell them a product, which they probably cannot afford, to believe that their repayments will be fully covered by consumer credit insurance should they have the misfortune to become ill, or unemployed, or be otherwise rendered incapable of earning an income. Nothing could be further from the truth.

A report on this area of activity entitled Need or Greed has recently been compiled by the Australian Financial Counselling and Credit Reform Association. It points out that financial counsellors have become increasingly alarmed at the hardship caused to their clients from the selling of consumer credit and credit related insurance. It is obvious from this report that the benefits available under each type of policy are subject to many limitations and that, generally speaking, the policy does not provide the benefits which are attributed to it. What the consumer does get comes at an extremely high cost, usually including substantial commission to a trader or credit provider acting as an insurance intermediary.

The report also indicates that consumer credit insurance is oversold, in that policies are sold to consumers who could never claim on them, or consumers are sold cover far in excess of their needs. In other cases consumers are unaware that they have been sold an insurance policy at all. Consumers are frequently denied their right to choose whether to take out such credit insurance. They are even more frequently denied their right to the insurer of their choice and are frequently frustrated in their attempts to claim, even where the cover offered should meet their circumstances. For instance, with reference to unemployment cover, page 9 of the report states:
It is fair to say that in the form it is usually sold unemployment insurance is of little or no value to the consumer.

This smacks of exploitation to me. Banks will frequently provide borrowers with a life insurance policy for the amount of a mortgage on a home. However, they do so at their own expense because they recognise that the lender is the ultimate beneficiary of this type of policy. Contrast this approach with that of the car sales industry where exorbitant rates for credit insurance are charged and a high commission paid, all of which is to be included in the general contract for time payment, which is itself one of the most expensive methods of paying for anything. However, should the hapless consumer endeavour to claim on the insurance at some stage, he or she may well find that the policy either does not cover the remaining payments due-with many only meeting payments for a month or two-or that the value of the cover provided is actually less than the amount paid to obtain the insurance in the first place. This area is certainly one which warrants attention and I am confident that the Minister for Consumer Affairs is looking into the problem.

As most honourable members would realise, people who became bankrupt still need to work and earn money to pay off their debts and start their lives again. To this end, this Bill provides for amendments to section 116 of the Act to permit the retention of a form of personal transport in which the bankrupt's interest is not more than $2,500. This is a small but significant improvement which will assist bankrupts to gain or retain employment, thus altering their relative ability to repay outstanding debts and to come to terms with society.

With Christmas upon us, the prospect of an escalation in consumer bankruptcy is very real indeed and many newspapers and financial counsellors are presently issuing a sombre warning to people to avoid the Christmas debt crisis and the January blues. During Christmas people are under great pressure to spend money they do not have. Even for people on a reasonable income the financial burden of Christmas can be heavy. For low income earners and pensioners, Christmas can mean a very large debt through overreliance on expensive forms of credit and an inability to resist the sales hype of retailers. The use of credit cards to pay for extra spending at Christmas may well be the last straw that drives the family into bankruptcy. I hope, however, that the provisions of this Bill will ensure that some of these unfortunate people do not neglect the alternatives available to them as less drastic mechanisms for the resolution of a continuing debt crisis. Simultaneously, of course, the amendments contained in the Bill will protect the legitimate interests of creditors and enable proper scrutiny of the business activities of any bankrupt seeking to avoid creditors' claims for payment by use of the infamous corporate veil. This is an excellent and necessary piece of legislation. I congratulate the Minister for his continuing interest in the welfare of the consuming public and commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr Mr D. J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I adopt the remarks just made about the extension of the trustees' powers in investigating bankrupts' affairs and enabling trustees to pursue a fraudulent bankrupt through the processes that he may have erected to try to protect his assets. The introduction of the Bankruptcy Amendment Bill is an appropriate and long overdue step. This legislation will be, I believe, welcomed by all those concerned with the proper, efficient and appropriate administration of the legal system. I think also that all those who have a genuine concern for the administration of the system of bankruptcy laws will welcome the seven days' cooling off period for those who may be minded to go into bankruptcy that the Bill now provides. It certainly strikes me that there is a need for such cooling off provisions to be provided more particularly in those areas where credit provision is an issue. Many people face bankruptcy because of the availability-the too ready availability, the pressured availability-of credit.

SPEECH.PARA: I have been privileged in this debate to hear many speakers express concern on bankruptcy issues, but I must say that some of the analysis, particularly by the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), was simply crude nonsense. The rhetoric of this debate needs to be distinguished from the reality. The reality is that business bankruptcies in Australia have, in fact, declined.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under a Labor government.

—Under a Labor government, indeed. The statistics show that from 1981-82 business bankruptcies have declined marginally from 2,003 in the first year to a figure of 1,920 bankruptcies in the past year. It is not true, it is fraudulent, it is nonsense, it is cheap and it is disgusting behaviour to suggest that there is an increase in bankruptcies due to the conduct of this Government. On the non-business bankruptcies, personal bankruptcies, we have seen a fairly significant increase from just over 2,500 in 1981-82 to 3,624 in the past year for which figures are available. Why is that? The returns themselves give the answer, because 41 per cent of those affected by personal bankruptcy give as the reason for their plight the excessive use of credit facilities. That is extraordinary.

SPEECH.PARA: Recently I was made aware in my electorate of credit providers who are writing to people without any invitation offering $1,000 without investigation, without any credit checks, to anybody who cares to post a letter back-$1,000 for 37c. That kind of free credit which is thrust upon people who perhaps are finding temporary difficulty in meeting their accounts, people who are put in a position where they are given the opportunity for easy access to credit, places them in a most invidious position. It is not surprising that some people make bad judgments in those cases, judgments perhaps that they can stretch to yet another payment, yet another opportunity to defer the pressing accounts that they have and to take up credit that they really should not have pressed upon them at all. There is a failure of social responsibility on the major institutions that do provide credit if they do not set in train mechanisms to ensure that they are not causing social dislocation, not by helping people by providing credit but by hurting those for whom credit is the last thing they need in their personal lives.

The real cost of credit provision, of course, can balloon out. It is not merely the direct cost of credit but also additional costs that may be called upon for credit consumers to absorb. For example, credit consumers are now often asked to take out credit insurance. There is a very interesting report that has been produced by the Australian Financial Counselling and Credit Reform Association titled Need or Greed. It is a very appropriate title. It points out that one of the servicing costs that are now occasioned by the availability of credit is premiums for insuring the loan.

What that means is well demonstrated by a table that the Financial Counselling Association has displayed at page 18 of its report. It shows in table 1 of the document the true cost of credit insurance. It instances a net amount of $10,000 financed in cash to a borrower. Interest on that borrowing would represent 37.5 per cent of the total amount and would come to just under $10,000 itself. On top of that a premium on insurance and commission would add $3,284 and on top of that again interest on that insurance amounts to another $3,148.46. So the original base loan of $10,000 would be met subsequently by payments somewhat over $25,000. Of that, just under 25 per cent would represent the cost of credit insurance.

Speaking of that impact, it is a regrettable fact that some credit or insurance organisations appear to be stimulating the process of people going bankrupt. It has been brought to my attention that there are certain insurance companies, which insure persons against bad debts, which will pay out on those bad debts only when a debtor is made bankrupt. That is gross social irresponsibility. I hope the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Mr Staples) will take account of the matter I have just raised and have it investigated. It seems to me that if that is the conduct in the financial market-place, if that is the behaviour that is being insisted upon by those who provide credit insurance, it is something that this Government needs to look at very seriously.

I strenuously urge this House to take seriously the problems that arise with credit provision. I urge those who are responsible for formulating the response of the Opposition to treat the matter a little more seriously than the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), the shadow Attorney-General, and the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore), the shadow Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, appear to treat it. Both have responded to the very sensible proposal by the Minister for Consumer Affairs that there be a conference to look at the problems arising from the too ready availability of credit and to look at consumer debt by dismissing the idea, by giving it no credit. They have not responded to the very real and important social issues that are behind that call. It does them no credit and does no good to the real issues that are involved when they trivialise credit provision. This was manifested by the speeches made in this House today which do not deal with the substantive problems in the field of consumer protection and consumer credit. Rather, they have sought to make political capital out of the fact that personal bankruptcies have increased.

I welcome the initiative of the Minister in calling that conference. It is incumbent upon those who are in the market-place providing credit to show that they are socially responsible. Those who are in that market-place say that the Government should not be involved in regulation, that it should not be involved in constraints on how they operate. I imagine the Government could accept that argument if credit providers demonstrated that they were acting with proper self-restraint and organised their affairs in such a way that the kinds of abuses of the system that are now being reported to, I think, many members of this Parliament were restrained and checked by internal self-discipline. No one wants to see the need for greater business regulation. I think all of us in this Parliament would wish to see business conduct itself in an appropriately self-regulated manner. But if it does not, I believe our voices need to be raised to ensure that proper, convenient and efficient protection is given to those who are in the most need, those who are perhaps the easy and gullible victims of people who press too ready and convenient credit into the hands of those who are not in a position to afford to repay it.

This is an issue not just for the Government but for the credit provision industry. May I say just before Christmas that it seems to me that this is not just a partisan issue. It may be that now it is the Australian Labor Party which is speaking out most strongly on this issue. But this is certainly a matter that the Liberal State Government in Tasmania has recognised. The State Consumer Affairs Council has seen the need to ensure that those who are going into the pre-Christmas season are not swayed too heavily by those who seek to provide so-called cheap credit for the Christmas period. It has been very creditably involved in organising an educational campaign designed to ensure that consumers are also made aware of problems that arise with credit as well as the opportunities. So it is not just a matter of the Australian Labor Party in the Federal Parliament being concerned; responsible Liberal parties at a State level are also concerned. Responsible consumer affairs councils and consumer organisations at all levels are also concerned. Unfortunately, it appears the only group that is not responding to this concern, the group that is treating this issue with a disdain, a failure to come to terms with the real issues involved, is the Federal Opposition. I hope that those who are responsible for formulating a response are able to see their way clear to make a more constructive contribution to the process than appears to have been the case to date.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will make some technical comments about the Bankruptcy Amendment Bill later, but I think it is probably worth spending a couple of minutes responding to the comments that have been made about consumer credit. I have been marvelling at the prospect of a debtors football match in which many people will be asked to come along to explain how they could best improve their relationship with their creditors or their debtors. It has always struck me that at a time in which money was amply available to everybody, with advertisements in newspapers presenting a very appealing picture by financial institutions towards lending, the educators of this nation should have been inspired to include within the syllabus, in terms of management and of basic training, what could be best achieved in the management of financial affairs.

SPEECH.PARA: I can recall that in my university days very few students in the technical courses of engineering, medicine, dentistry and so on, except for a few weeks at the end of the courses that were given over to office management and the like, were given any real understanding of financial management. I suspect that today's educational courses are no better than they were in those times. So when this great summit gets under way-I find the proposal extraordinary-I hope a lot of attention will be paid to the education of people in relation to the use of credit, the use of money and what one might call basic accounting or housekeeping. I think as a result of that we would all be better off.

I do not know how many times we have heard the analogy about running the nation and running the house. It is said that one cannot spend more than one has and all the rest. There is no doubt temptation is placed in the hands of a lot of people with the use of credit cards and the like. But until such time as the educational authorities address themselves to ensuring that the young people of the nation understand their responsibilities, our youth will fall for the excessive use of credit. There has been a huge use of credit and all sorts of techniques have been evolved to allow access to funds which, in the normal course of events, would be denied.

For many retired people, their home is their only substantial investment. A number of institutions have found a way for such people to use their only substantial investment to gain access to money, the amount depending on the value of the house, the market price at the time. Such people can use this and maybe pay off some debts, have a trip or whatever. An extension of that ability would lead to enormous excesses in use of credit within Australia. I was a bit surprised when this practice occurred. I think this American innovation has become fairly well used even in Australia.

The general use of consumer credit in the nation relates very much to consumer optimism. The use of one's credit card or one's ability to borrow relates very much to how one feels in one's employment and income earning capacity. The rise in one's psychology of spending may well be in poor relationship to the trade cycle. For example, many people who have used credit excessively in the last two or three years will find themselves in difficulties. There is no use attempting to turn that around and blame the institutions. Institutions lent the money in times which were totally different from today and from what they will be in six months when there may be a lot of pressure on consumers who spent on credit.

I get back to the educational process. We must condition people to the realities of the problems associated with debt and to their responsibilities in taking out loans when they commit their assets, and sometimes the blue sky, when trying to raise money. It is not always the avarice of the lender that causes the problems, as I have read so much in the newspapers, particularly from the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Mr Staples). Those who take on the responsibility should be well and truly awakened to the problems at the time. No one should claim not to have read the small print. Caveat emptor applies today as much as it ever did. It will always apply. There is no doubt that, in the general mainstream, people should be very cautious about handling money.

In my professional career outside politics, I seldom found people who could manage money. That is one of the great problems in the nation. I found that those who were technically trained were probably the worst and those who were dependent upon a salary under the pay as you earn taxation system were probably the best. That came about through experience and training. If anything were to come out of this summit I hope it would be that institutions train people so that they have some understanding of accounting. Within the curriculum of all schools there should be a basic course on understanding one's finances and the management of money.

I dare say that the majority of broken marriages are caused by money problems. I dare say that the majority of small business failures are caused by the mismanagement of money. I dare say that the majority of people who have dropped out of society and are dependent on the remaining taxpayers' handouts have a total lack of understanding of the management of money. Because of that we have a responsibility to put into the education system, for the young people of today, basic systems of training in the management of money. Without that we will leave our successors a huge legacy of problems in that area. I make those comments about credit as one who has seen the situation from both sides.

When the Bankruptcy Act was last amended I was the Minister responsible for it, so I do know something about the problems involved. I have before me a letter from Mr W. J. Wilde of Coopers and Lybrand. He is a well known practitioner in this area, not only in Queensland but throughout Australia. He is one of the company's senior partners. Mr Wilde had two things to say in the letter and later I will read some of the technical aspects involved.

One of the things that we tried to do in the last amendments to the Act was to take away from the Federal bureaucracy the management of many of the estates. We did so because there was a consistent log-jam in getting answers. There was a requirement, because some estates were not commercial, to put together a bag of those which were possible and those which were impossible. That certainly produced a new interest from the trustees in this area and bestowed upon the Department a far greater responsibility. That met with resistance. I heard all sorts of reasons from the registrars around Australia as to why changes could not be made. The most common was that those involved were all crooks, or something like that. That is nonsense. Once again, the amendments before us to part X are based on the premise that people are crooks. What happened? I will read from the letter from Wilson Joseph Wilde in which, among other things, he said:
The reasons given by the previous Attorney-General and the present Attorney-General for the extensive amendments being made to part X are quite simply ridiculous. Both persons-
this is in terms of a misdemeanour-

have claimed that the amendments are necessary to counter activities of dishonest trustees who they claim have been practising in Australia. As far as the Insolvency Practitioners of Australia is aware, both trustees concerned were partners of the same firm and both have been dealt with, and in any case the suggested amendments have no relationship to the activities in which these two gentlemen took part.

I have no reason to disbelieve that person. Not only is he well known but also he was on the Government's advisory committee. I will quote him in a couple of other areas, because I happen to think that the proposed changes to part X do not relate to what I would call reasonable commercial activity. We do not condone any fraudulent activity in this area. I am quite sure that the writer of this letter would not do so. But there is a huge difference between commercial activities and what I will call the bureaucratic view of life in the commercial sector. There was a hard case fought in 1980. To get those involved turned round to the situation took some effort. It took some convincing to get the private sector to join in. It was not convinced of the necessity to get into it either. But it was a way in which I believed a fresh approach could be brought to areas in which some of the registrars were well and truly bogged down.
I raise two other matters concerning the provisions regarding the preparation of statements of affairs. This senior practitioner goes on to state:

Similar provisions with regard to the preparation of a statement of affairs into the companies code for creditors voluntarily winding up administrations and, as a result, the number of such administrations in Australia has dropped to such an extent that creditors voluntarily winding up is now a rare event and, as a consequence, returns to creditors in liquidations have been considerably reduced. A creditor's voluntary winding up is just not practical because of the voluminous amount of information required before the administration can be put into effect. This same situation will now be the case with regard to part X administrations.
This is a very senior practitioner and market-place operator writing this. He continues:

If the proposed amendments are allowed to become law, then the losses to creditors will be further exacerbated through the fact that insolvent debtors will trade on and incur liabilities while they take their time in preparing their statements of affairs.

Secondly, proposals in the Bill are simply impractical because the information supplied by a debtor in insolvent circumstances is always unreliable and inaccurate, and the debtors in the majority of cases have no knowledge or understanding of the significance of securities given-
hence, my reflection on educational standards-

the terms of contracts signed, the concept of preference and the concept of priority creditors. The correct approach to a Part X administration is that, as now, we see set out in the Bankruptcy Act. During the period in which the collecting trustee is in charge of the debtor's affairs, correct information for the benefit of creditors is able to be collected, and proper and sensible discussions can be held with the debtor to formulate a proposal which is then put to creditors at a meeting where they are given a copy of an accurate statement of affairs, and where they are able to question the debtor in full concerning his past actions and his proposed future actions. They are then able to make an informed decision through personal contact with regard to future arrangements which they consider will be in their best interests.

If the proposed amendments become law, then the only trustees in Australia stupid enough to accept an appointment as controlling trustees would be those very trustees the Attorney-General is complaining about. No self-respecting or experienced trustee would allow the statements proposed in the new Bill to go out to creditors under his name, particularly when he knows that, at the meeting of creditors, they will be treated by creditors as statements of the trustee.
Thirdly, there is no doubt in my mind that if the new proposals become law, then the cost of administration will be increased considerably and money available to creditors will be further reduced.

Fourthly, the proposal that an instrument of proxy must specify the manner of voting at the meeting will provide no benefit for creditors and in most cases will act to their disadvantage, as at the meeting of creditors it is possible for the creditors, after discussion with the debtor, to decide on a number of courses of action, some of which will allow preference to be recovered and others not. Creditors who have received a preference are likely to attend a meeting to ensure that if any proposal is accepted, it will be one which will have the effect of preventing recovery of preference. If a proxy has been instructed to vote in a certain manner prior to the meeting, then obviously creditors may be seriously disadvantaged.

From the amendments and from the comments in that quotation one can see the real reservations about the position of creditors in relation to those items and the way in which these meetings are proposed to be constructed. After all, that is at the heart of these amendments in relation to those creditors meetings and the preparation of statements before them. I welcome the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren) to this discussion. The right wing might be rampant without him.

As a consequence of what I have said, I hope the Minister will look at these considerations, because they are based on practical experience, not on whims or Public Service advice. One must bear in mind the background of this person, who is one of the foremost operators in this area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crawford Ms M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bankruptcy Amendment Bill 1987 is the Government's response to the demand within the community and to the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. The Bill attempts to present a total package that will tackle not only bankruptcy fraud but the difficulties for debtors, and in particular, consumer debtors. I was somewhat amused to hear the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) talk about a consumer education program, given that he belongs to an opposition that does not even have a consumer policy. Do we believe him? Does he genuinely believe in the value of money management programs, or are we simply to dismiss it as another of his meanderings?

SPEECH.PARA: We in the Government have responded to the demand to move into this whole area of bankruptcy fraud and the allied problem of consumer indebtedness. One of those who called for bankruptcy law reform was the head of the Law Reform Commission, Mr Ron Harmer. His call came when he tabled the Law Reform Commission report, at a time when we had a record number of bankruptcies. What is of greater concern to us as a Government, and to the Minister, is that consumer debt is now estimated to be $23 billion. The Law Reform Commission stated that its recommendations were designed to streamline the 700,000 legal actions to recover debt which take place in Australia every year. The growth in the number of bankruptcies in all States has been one of our most distressing concerns. In my State of Queensland, 1,860 bankruptcies were recorded in 1986-87, which was a rise of 34 per cent over the previous year. In the July-September quarter of this year, there were 493 bankruptcies in the south, central and northern regions of Queensland. This compares most unfavourably with the 430 of the previous year.

What is of concern in the 1985-86 figures is that, of the 5,544 bankruptcies, 3,624 were of the non-business variety. There is definitely a rise in the indebtedness in our community, particularly in the consumer and credit card area. Indeed, the report on consumer credit insurance looks at the need or greed factor. That is a question that we all need to look at. We also need to look at the rise in these bankruptcies and ask ourselves whether fraudulent business people are choosing the easier path of voluntary insolvency, and hence evading their rightful dues, or are people simply not able to pursue any other course of action which would enable them to meet their debts?

The problem in Queensland is centralised very much on Brisbane and the Gold Coast and one has to ask, in terms of the Gold Coast, which is the heartland of the National Party State Government, why the number of bankruptcies is so high, given that that Government is supposedly committed to progress and the small business and is supposed to have the corner on money management. The figures would belie this, and we as a government are here to attack and wrestle with this question. This Bill attempts to address these issues in terms of fraudulent insolvency.

It has been recognised for many years that the duty of the trustee in bankruptcy is twofold. Firstly, it is to realise the debtor's property and distribute the proceeds amongst creditors. Secondly, it is to protect public interests by investigating the bankrupt's contract. In 1983, an inquiry was set up to assess the practices of trustees. This departmental task force still exists and is continuing to monitor the way in which trustees work. This Bill will extend the trustee powers to investigate bankrupt's affairs by enabling the trustees to recoup from companies, partnerships, trusts and other persons assets which have been acquired by the personal efforts of the bankrupt.

This Bill will introduce related concepts of associated entities and examinable affairs which will enable the court to make orders in relation to the property of entities controlled by a bankrupt. Associated entities will be placed under an obligation to co-operate with the trustee by making books of account and financial records available where this will assist in shedding light on the bankrupt's financial affairs. Indeed, as we all know, many of the problems associated with voluntary insolvency simply resulted from attempts by persons declared bankrupt to shift their financial affairs out of the arena in which the trustee was able to participate. However, this will now not be enough. A number of provisions will require the court to take account of the interests of third parties who have an interest in the property of the entity and creditors. Voluntary insolvency is, and must always remain, a last resort. It is important that an insolvent person be able to gain relief from his or her creditors. However, she must also be encouraged to explore the alternatives to bankruptcy.

The introduction of the pre-bankruptcy moratorium of a maximum period of seven days will give some scope for dealing in this particular area. There are many people active within the family action and family support groups who claim that many of those people who declare themselves bankrupt are, of course, casualties in this consumer credit system. There is a need for tightening controls on the whole financial situation. Indeed, the corollary of the deregulation of the financial institutions is the need to look at and demand of those institutions some sort of control on their consumer credit and the way in which they operate their financial institutions.

We can all cite cases of families that have been granted loans of $50,000 for a house, $20,000 for a car and then $5,000 for smaller debts. They have been given credit cards and so on. Of course, once a partner gets sick or a marriage breaks up they are unable to pursue those debts and, of course, fall very quickly into arrears and then become bankrupt. Indeed, Jan Pentland, a credit advocate at Family Action in the Dandenong Valley, cited a case in which a single mother with two children found herself with debts of $17,000 which had accrued as a result of her estranged husband's failed business and for which she was now responsible. In this case, bankruptcy was her only option and the debts will probably remain unpaid and unpayable.

Such a moratorium now will in fact be able to address some of those very real problems and may lead to a resolution of better facilities for insolvents. Indeed, there has been a suggestion that, contrary to winding up companies, insolvency practices involve the utilisation of a wide range of resources, such as accounting, legal and other, to investigate and arrange a person's affairs so as to minimise the rates of bankruptcy which are occurring in our community.

It has been suggested by a number of solicitors who deal in insolvency cases that what needs to be looked at in terms of these insolvencies is a way in which businesses can become more viable. Commercial reality must dictate the solution. Such arrangements must be accepted in the eyes of business proprietors and all debtors as a viable alternative to labouring under the weight of mushrooming debts. Indeed, the honourable member for Ryan pointed to a very real need for education of those people who run our businesses. In fact, what we should be looking at constantly is the demand for commercial viability and that businesses should be forced to develop processes whereby they can develop and work their way out of debt rather than taking the easy way out through voluntary insolvency.

The Government has established a group of officials to undertake a comprehensive review of the provision of financial services in this area. The essential purpose of this will be to examine the adequate protection of consumer interests. Indeed, if we are to tackle the whole problem of insolvency within our community we must address it in two areas. The question of fraud has to be attacked. That has been done in this Bill. The Bill attempts to make some very significant changes to ensure that trustees in bankruptcy can investigate vested commercial arrangements which have used the bankruptcy laws to defraud creditors. On the other hand, in recognition that bankruptcy is not the most appropriate solution in all circumstances, the Bill encourages debtors to seek other solutions. Some of those solutions are as I have just mentioned.

What we must address also, of course, is the question of consumer credit and who is responsible for allowing people to be loaned money in situations in which they are unable to pay. There has even been a suggestion from some financial counsellors in Victoria that financial institutions which irresponsibly extend credit to consumers should be compelled to contribute to court and other bankruptcy costs. As honourable members can well imagine, the Executive Director of the Australian Bankers Association, Mr Cullen, has said that this idea is impractical. He has said that irresponsible lending accounted for a minuscule proportion of consumer bankruptcy. He has claimed that the most common reasons for bankruptcy are unemployment, divorce and illness. However, we have seen from figures cited by my colleagues on this side of the House that the real reason has been the overextended use of credit facilities. Indeed, Mr Cullen has said that to suggest that lenders are responsible for bankruptcy is a gross oversimplification and quite unfair. I would suggest, with respect to that gentleman, that he needs to look much more carefully at the kind of people to whom he is making credit available. Perhaps the consumer summit next year will address this very real problem.

What the consumer summit will attempt to do is to look at the whole package of facilities and financial services which currently are available to people within our society which tempt people to get themselves into situations in which they are overcommitted. Indeed, a number of cases can be cited here in terms of the insurance industry in which people have been granted insurance for times when they may become unemployed or disabled. It has transpired that in fact those people have been unemployed or disabled at the very time of the signing of the contract. There are other instances of husbands and wives signing contracts only to discover that when the wife becomes unemployed she is not eligible. Indeed, the report states:

The consumer credit insurance market is characterised by reverse competition. Insurers compete with each other to charge the highest price to consumers in order to be able to pay the highest commissions and so gain the greatest number of traders and credit providers selling their product (virtually) exclusively.

I hope that this will be addressed very definitely by the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Mr Staples) in his consumer and debt summit next year. It is not, as members of the Opposition have suggested, some sort of debtors football game. Indeed, this is a very serious business; people's lives are at stake. As a government we are attempting to respond to the demands and needs in our community. Hence, this Bill is a commitment by this Government to sensible law reform and a recognition of the need to attack fraud while protecting genuine victims. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Staples Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I noted at the outset of this debate on the Bankruptcy Amendment Bill the rather cynical remarks of the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) about the credit conference on overcommitment next year. I suppose it is the best we could hope for in the circumstances from those honourable members opposite. I point out that the proposal for a summit has had a very positive response from consumers in the community, from industry and, indeed, from the national media.
—That is important.

—It is important. The honourable member for Flinders also suggested in his speech that bankruptcy increases were due to government economic policy. He cited causes such as unemployment, high interest rates, the crash of the dollar and taxation policy. However, the overall reality is, of course, that a lot of these-this is particularly exemplified by the so-called crash of the dollar-were a result of the Opposition's policies when in government, in particular during the Fraser years when it desperately propped up the dollar at a fixed rate. If it had let the dollar float to its real world parity instead of hiding behind the facade of competence, for which it was well known over its years in government, perhaps the dollar would be in a different situation today.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately, the honourable member for Flinders did nothing-nor did any other honourable member opposite who contributed to the debate-to address the economic and industrial problems that faced Australia at that time, whether this was through protectionism or the inefficiencies that that engendered at the expense of taxpayers and consumers. The Opposition did nothing to address the basic economic and industrial problems in relation to wages and industrial relations policy, fiscal and monetary policies and, indeed, the Budget deficit. There is no need for me to justify this Government's economic performance, or its taxation policy for that matter. It has been judged twice by the people. One reason that I have to sit on the Opposition side of the House now is the success of those policies; I virtually have to sit next to the honourable member for Flinders. It has been a long time since members of the Australian Labor Party have sat on the left hand side of the Speaker and enjoyed it so much.

TALK.START.PARA: —You obviously do not know anything about bankruptcy; that is the message.
—I know a lot about bankruptcy because I sit so close to Opposition members and its policies have been bankrupt for so long.
—At least we are not intellectually bankrupt.
—Order! The honourable member for Flinders will cease interjecting and the Minister will not respond to interjections.

—Business bankruptcies were also mentioned. The number of such bankruptcies has been decreasing in the period that this Government has been in office. The percentage of bankrupts claiming that economic circumstance was the cause of their bankruptcy has fallen from 25.1 per cent in 1981-82 to 19.7 per cent in 1985-86. The honourable member for Flinders also said that bankruptcy statistics were released reluctantly. I think that is the word he used. I point out to the honourable member that under the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) provisional unverified statistics on bankruptcy are now released quarterly, whereas under the administration of the Fraser Government and his Party they were released only in the annual report. I think honourable members will acknowledge that the word `reluctantly' was hardly the word to use when the statistics are available more often now than they have been in the past. To sum up in this regard, the foray of the honourable member for Flinders into economic matters was blinkered ideological exaggeration, to put it mildly. However, I appreciate that the honourable member's remarks tended to make more sense after listening to the contributions of other honourable members to the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: For the sake of the debate I shall respond to a couple of the points raised by the honourable member for Flinders. He spoke about the reimbursement of costs incurred in complying with a warrant. Unlike the provision in the fringe benefits tax legislation, under proposed new section 130, the warrant is issued pursuant to judicial authority. A warrant issued under the fringe benefits tax legislation is issued by administrative arrangement. The occupier of the premises is obliged to provide all reasonable facilities and assistance. I think those two factors will provide a control on any unreasonable demand by an officer executing such a warrant. Under section 178 a person aggrieved by any act or omission of a trustee may apply to the court and the court may make an order of the sort about which the honourable member for Flinders was concerned, if the court believes it is justifiable.

The honourable member also said that only registered trustees and not solicitors should be able to call meetings under part 10 of the Act. He may or may not be aware that the sort of provision that he wanted inserted was very seriously considered by the Government. One practical problem in taking up that proposal is the fact that there is only a relatively small number of trustees and these tend to be concentrated in the major cities. The proposal to exclude solicitors could present substantial difficulties to many debtors in rural areas in gaining access to a registered trustee. I am sure that this matter will be given further consideration. The honourable member raised the matter of priority being given to tax debts. I note the honourable member's proposal that tax priority should be abolished.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not say that. I said that the Law Reform Commission had raised the issue and it should be looked at.

—As the honourable member indicates, the Law Reform Commission did raise the matter. The Government has been considering its recommendation but it is not prepared to entertain it at this stage. However, the remaining priorities for taxation and income tax liabilities relate to amounts that have been deducted by any one person to remit to the Commissioner of Taxation on account of another person; for example, tax instalment deductions which have not been remitted by an employer to the Commissioner and that employer becomes bankrupt. I hope that that covers some of the points raised by the honourable member.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) raised the matter of personal bankruptcies. He said that it was reported to him that some people in the Adelaide office of the Department of Social Security were recommending to people that they should declare themselves bankrupt in order to increase their income. I have heard some anecdotal evidence in relation to the matter raised by the honourable member for Dawson and from other sources as well. Bankruptcy is of as much concern to me as it is to the Government. I think it is a problem that is well and truly recognised by honourable members on both sides of the House but, unfortunately, perhaps not so much by the community. Declaring oneself bankrupt is a very serious step for a person to take. Advice of the nature referred to by the honourable member does not really state accurately the situation in which the person might find himself or herself. Hence the Government proposes that a seven-day cooling off period should apply. The sort of advice to which the honourable member referred could be one of the reasons for the statistical increase in personal bankruptcies. Whereas in the past such bankrupts formed part of the overcommitment statistics, some of those people are now included in the personal bankruptcy statistics.

The honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore), whom I welcome to the debate, spoke quite a lot about consumer education. I for one agree in principle with the comments of the honourable member for Ryan in this regard. However, he did not explore the matter sufficiently for me to get to the bottom of his concerns. I would like to know whether he expects the taxpayers to pay for this consumer education or whether he thinks that the financial institutions should contribute some of the cost. The financial institutions should acknowledge that they have a greater responsibility to contribute to consumer education in Australia with the deregulation of the Australian financial system and the resultant freedom that has been provided to them. They have greater responsibilities flowing from that freedom, which I am sure is a good Liberal Party philosophy. It should be acknowledged that many of the financial institutions operating in the United States of America take the role of consumer education much more seriously than do the financial institutions in Australia. The State Ministers responsible for consumer affairs and I are very concerned about the lack of involvement of financial institutions in consumer education, and we believe that is a matter that must be addressed.

I am sure that the honourable member for Ryan would applaud the fact that this year government expenditure on consumer education is to increase substantially. Unfortunately, we cannot rely upon consumer education being undertaken only in our schools, which is what the honourable member for Ryan seemed to concentrate on. We cannot wait for 20 or so years for the people who do not understand the implications of taking credit they cannot afford to move off this earth and for this wonderfully educated group of people to come through. Consumer education needs to take place in the schools and in the broader community as well. The honourable member for Ryan in his comments referred to a letter from Mr Wilson Wilde which stated that only two trustees had had their registration cancelled or in relation to whom application had been made for removal of their registration. In fact, despite Mr Wilde's position in this field, he might be interested to know, as well as the honourable member for Ryan, that in fact not two but seven trustees have had their registration cancelled or in relation to whom application had been made for removal of their registration in circumstances involving misconduct. These trustees were carrying out approximately 500 separate administrations under the Bankruptcy Act. A number of other trustees are also under investigation. One major trustee has proceedings pending against him for his removal.

The honourable member for Ryan, in his comments on part X, quoted criticism again by Mr Wilde that the statement of affairs provided for at the start of a part X administration would be disastrous and would delay the start of a part X matter. That is incorrect. The debtor would be able to use the new seven-day bankruptcy moratorium to obtain a breathing space in which to prepare a statement of affairs. Debtors will be protected and creditors will receive full and timely information. The Law Reform Commission in its recent discussion paper recommended that this step be taken and that creditors receive full and timely information.

I sum up by thanking Government supporters-the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright), the honourable member for Cowan (Ms Jakobson), the honourable member for Davison (Mr Kerr) and the honourable member for Forde (Ms Crawford)-for their constructive comments in this debate, particularly on the issues of overcommitment and the finance industry in general. I expect a full and detailed response from the Insurance Council of Australia and other interested finance bodies to the consumer credit insurance report that was presented by the Australian Financial Counselling and Credit Reform Association. I think it is important for the community to see that before much longer. The honourable member for Forde and the honourable member for Capricornia noted also that a working party has been established between the Treasury and the Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs to examine the provision of adequate protection for consumer interests and the need to maintain an efficient financial situation. I believe that working party will make an important contribution to the understanding of these issues by the Australian community. I thank all honourable members who have taken part in the debate. I thank the members of the Opposition for their generous support and contributions to this debate, for the good quality and standard of debate and for the manner in which the speeches were presented. I commend the Bill to the House.
