SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Mr JOHN BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to give effect to the restructuring and reorganisation of the Australian Tourist Commission (ATC) in line with the majority of the recommendations of the report of the Australian Government Inquiry into Tourism, known as the Kennedy Report, which were endorsed by the Government in December 1986. The Commission was established in 1967 by the Australian Tourist Commission Act. This Act, now 20 years old, and amended on a number of occasions, is deficient in many ways and does not reflect current legislative drafting practices. Therefore it was decided that rather than introduce substantial further amendments of the current Act, it would be desirable to introduce a new Bill which would not only reflect the recommendations of the Kennedy report endorsed by the Government, but also take into account recent Government reforms concerning statutory authorities.
Background

On 19 January 1986 I announced the establishment of the Australian Government Inquiry into Tourism. The inquiry was established in response to the rapid expansion of tourism in the previous three years and the industry's increasing importance to the Australian economy. In accordance with its terms of reference, the inquiry was principally concerned with the `effectiveness of Commonwealth administration of its tourism promotion functions and related issues'. In specific terms the inquiry was asked to review:
The appropriateness of existing provisions of the Australian Tourist Commission Act 1967;
Funding, contracting, and staffing arrangements and structures appropriate for achieving the Commonwealth's tourism promotion objectives;
Relevant operational arrangements, services and systems of the Australian Tourist Commission;
Relationships between the Australian Tourist Commission and Commonwealth, State and other organisations with responsibilities that impact on tourism;
Future policies and strategies that might be adopted by the Commonwealth to achieve greater effectiveness in its tourism promotion activities overseas and in Australia; and
Any other matters referred to the Committee by the then Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism during the period of the review.

The inquiry was carried out by a committee of five. The Chairman was Mr Jim Kennedy, Deputy Chairman of the Australian Tourist Commission and Deputy Chairman of the Queensland Tourist and Travel Corporation. Other members were Mr Jon Donohoe, Chairman of the Tourism Commission of New South Wales; Ms Geraldine Paton, publisher of the Australian newspaper; Mr Thomas Derry, General Marketing Manager, Ansett Airlines of Australia; and Dr Emanual Klein, then my Senior Private Secretary.

I would like to place on record at this point my and the Government's sincere appreciation for the untiring work of the committee, whose members gave freely a vast amount of their own time to carry out the most thorough investigation ever undertaken into tourism in this country. Miss Sue Hunt, the Secretary of that committee, who at that time was in my Department, also performed a brilliant task. The 96 recommendations of the committee's report were supported by a most comprehensively documented report. The report was produced after wide consultation with the industry and State and Territory Government authorities. The large number of detailed submissions and comments received by the committee from industry and government bodies also reflected the growing importance of this industry's place in the Australian economy.

On 7 May this year I outlined to the House the contribution of tourism to the economy. In doing so, I detailed the spectacular growth in the last five years which is due in no small part to the solid backing the industry has received from this Government and, in particular, the support it has given to the operations of the Australian Tourist Commission. I do not propose tonight to repeat in detail the areas in which this Government has laid the foundations to make this industry the fastest growing industry in Australia. Suffice to say that our achievements, spearheaded by the more than trebling of funding of the Australian Tourist Commission from $10m to over $33m, the easing of foreign investments guidelines, and encouragement of career training of people for the industry, to mention just three areas of progressive Government initiatives, have greatly assisted the tourism industry to move into its current dynamic mode.

The recommendations of the Kennedy report, most of which were adopted by the Government, will make the Australian Tourist Commission a much leaner and more commercially-oriented organisation with greater emphasis on marketing, planning and evaluation. This Bill provides for a new legislative base on which the Australian Tourist Commission will meet the exciting challenges of the future to make Australia a premier international tourist destination.
Major features of the Bill
THE FUNCTION OF THE COMMISSION

The principal object of this Bill is to restructure the Australian Tourist Commission to enable it to perform its functions more effectively. This Bill will provide a new focus for the Commission and will update the Commission's purpose and operating methods. This will act as an important lever for development of tourism in Australia and enable the Commonwealth to obtain the best return on the resources it has allocated for this purpose. Under this Bill, the scope of the corporate mission of the Commission will be narrowed. The Commission's activity will now be directed towards promoting Australia as an attractive tourist destination in the international market-place. It will withdraw from the field of promotion of domestic tourism, leaving that to the States and Territories. The Commission will, however, retain a role in enhancing the awareness of the importance of tourism to Australia. It will also have a role in monitoring the effects of international tourism on Australia's natural environment and society.

The development of tourism in Australia in relation to the inbound market requires specific planning and it is not proposed that the Commonwealth proceed down this track in isolation. We will be seeking the co-operation of all concerned. But it needs to be emphasised that rationalisation of the amount of money spent overseas by governments and industry is required to maximise the effects of those resources for the benefit of Australia's economy overall. Accordingly, the principal objects of the Commission are:
(a) to increase the number of visitors to Australia from overseas;
(b) to maximise the benefits to Australia from overseas visitors; and
(c) to ensure that Australia is protected from adverse environmental and social impacts of international tourism.
In order to achieve this the Commission's functions as set out in the Bill are:
To promote Australia overseas as a tourist destination;
To enhance awareness of Australia overseas as a tourist destination;
To co-ordinate the overseas promotional efforts of the Australian tourism industry, in co-operation with State and Territory tourism authorities and with the Australian tourism industry;
To enhance awareness in Australia of the Australian tourism industry; and
To closely monitor and report the effects of international tourism on Australia's natural environment and society.
STRUCTURE OF THE BOARD AND APPOINTMENT OF MEMBERS

This Bill provides for a Board of Directors of the Australian Tourist Commission to consist of a chairperson, a deputy chairperson, a government member, who will be an officer of the Australian Public Service, a managing director and five other members. Of the five other members, at least two will be drawn from representative national tourism organisations. This provides for a board of nine members as opposed to provision for 13 members under the existing legislation and is in line with government statutory authority reforms which aim to streamline boards to a workable size. The Kennedy report found that the current Board of 13 did not encourage efficient operations. In fact, a number of submissions, including that of the Australian Tourist Commission itself, advocated a smaller board.

A number of submissions to the inquiry reflected the desire to restructure representation on the Board including the statutory requirement for representatives from the States and Territories to sit on the Board on a rotational basis. The States themselves criticised the current rotational system, particularly on the basis that they were disadvantaged when not participating on the ATC Board and did not have ready access to agenda papers for meetings and current market intelligence. It would be impractical to have simultaneous representation of all States and Territories on the Board. This Bill removes the current formalised State representation on the Board. However, close consultations with the States is essential to the operations of the ATC and alternative and more effective consultative mechanisms are now being developed and implemented. For example, a round of newly instituted planning meetings held individually with each State and Territory has taken place over the last two to three months.

The Bill retains the existing provision for the appointment of a board member from the Australian Public Service, now referred to as the Government member. It is appropriate that the Board continues to have the facility to draw on knowledge and understanding of public administration and statutory accountability requirements, and Government policy. The Bill provides for the appointment of the chairperson on a part time or full time basis. At present it is considered appropriate for a chairperson to be appointed on a part time basis. However, should circumstances dictate at some future time that it would be more appropriate to appoint a full time chairperson, the Bill does provide that flexibility.

Accordingly, and in line with the report recommendations endorsed by the Government, the Bill provides for the Board members to be appointed by virtue of their individual skills, expertise and experience relevant to the tourism industry. The Bill provides that at least one of the members will be a person who has environmental or sociological expertise relevant to the tourism industry. It is also envisaged that a board appointee will have extensive commercial experience at a senior level, and have demonstrated track records of successful management.
CORPORATE PLANNING AND ACCOUNTABILITY

A major focus included in this Bill which affects the operations of the Australian Tourist Commission and an important area not covered under its existing legislation, concerns corporate planning and accountability as set out in part IV of the Bill. The Kennedy inquiry examined in detail, and made a number of recommendations relating to, an appropriate management framework for the ATC. Its report stressed that adequate evaluation of marketing and operational programs is essential. The analogy was drawn that just as all elements of Australian tourism should responsibly carry on their tourism business within a strategic, co-ordinated framework, the same principle must apply to the ATC. It is now intended that the Board of the ATC become more active in the establishment of corporate goals of performance and the setting of corporate priorities to enhance the strategic planning process, and in the use of its available resources.

Section 25 of the Bill requires the Board to prepare a corporate plan. The corporate plan will include a statement of objectives of the Board and an assessment of the market and economic outlook for inbound tourism to Australia. The plan will span a rolling five-year period and will be subject to review and revision each year. It will be submitted to the Minister for approval as soon as practicable after it is prepared. The corporate plan will provide the basis of accountability to the Parliament and the industry at large of the ATC's activities and is in accordance with the Government's reforms for statutory authorities. In addition to the preparation of a corporate plan, section 26 of this Bill provides for the Board to prepare an annual operational plan. The annual operational plan for a financial year will contain an estimate of the Commission's receipts and expenditure and specify the programs that the Board proposes to carry out and the resources that it proposes to allocate to each such program giving effect to the corporate plan for that year. Division 2 of part IV of the Bill details accountability of the ATC. It sets out the requirement for the Commission to prepare an annual report and also empowers the Minister in exceptional circumstances to give directions to the Board. It is included in accordance with standard and accepted legislative practice.
The Future

This Bill, the Australian Tourist Commission Bill 1987, provides a new and comprehensive legislative base for the Australian Tourist Commission to equip it to meet successfully the growth and the challenges of a dynamic tourism industry up to and into the twenty-first century. It is appropriate that the legislation under which the Commission has so ably performed for the last 20 years should now be replaced with new and amended legislation which more adequately provides for the future operation and direction of the Commission. These legislative changes are the result of this Government's initiative to commission a far-reaching inquiry to examine the operations of the Australian Tourist Commission. On the advice received from the Kennedy Committee of Inquiry, the Government has been able to formulate this Bill confident that it will provide the legislative basis for an efficient and effective Australian Tourist Commission. I commend the Bill to the House and I present the explanatory memorandum.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN TOURIST COMMISSION BILL 1987[COGNATE BILL:AUSTRALIAN TOURIST COMMISSION (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1987]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate the Australian Tourist Commission Bill concurrently with the Australian Tourist Commission (Transitional Provisions) Bill. There being no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Australian Tourist Commission Bill and the Australian Tourist Commission (Transitional Provisions) Bill is to reform the Australian Tourist Commission (ATC) following the recommendations made by the Australian Government Inquiry into Tourism-the Kennedy report. The Australian Tourist Commission was set up under a Liberal-National Party government to promote Australia's tourist product overseas in a co-ordinated and effective fashion. Since its inception, the ATC has grown in importance as our tourist industry has grown and has increasingly contributed more and more to the Australian economy and to employment. Tourism today is one of our most important industries; in fact, it is our fastest growing one. In 1986-87 tourism earned Australia $22 billion and employed more than 400,000 Australians. It is one of our largest industries and, with time, will compete for our number one spot.

SPEECH.PARA: Tourism employs more people than our textile, clothing, footwear and motor vehicle industries combined. It is worth noting that for every 32 international visitors one job will be created in the industry. Our agricultural industries represent collectively 4 per cent of gross domestic product. Tourism represents 6 per cent of gross domestic product. Of course, in addition to the economic benefits, having people from around the world coming to us as visitors has an immense intangible value in our relations with other countries.

I state these facts to highlight the need for the Parliament to recognise the importance of what we are doing today. We are dealing with one of the most crucial facets of the tourist industry-the body that promotes it overseas. Consequently, a good decision in relation to its restructuring will enhance tourism's potential contribution to our economy and to our society. A wrong decision will seriously weaken the industry reducing our chances of creating jobs for those hundreds of thousands of Australians who so desperately need them and, equally important, reducing the income earning potential that the industry's future represents.

So let us not treat this legislation lightly. We are dealing with Australia's future, both economic and social, and when we are dealing with those things we must recognise how few bright lights we have on our economic horizon. Tourism is one of those bright lights. We must treat it with great care and we must ensure that everything we do in this Parliament will not reduce our potential to make jobs and to make income for Australia.

The Government has made a complete botch of this legislation to reform the ATC. Sure, it has picked up the bulk of the recommendations in the Kennedy report, but it has picked up only the ones from the easy basket. It has left the important recommendations untouched in the too hard basket. In fact, looking at the legislation after it was amended in the Senate, we can say not only that the Government is gutless but also that the Government is crazy. The principal recommendation of the Kennedy report was that terms and conditions of employment within the Australian Tourist Commission be removed from Public Service rules to more flexible private sector-type rules. The Government has completely ignored this, leaving the Australian Tourist Commission bound up by the limitations of Public Service rules of employment.

It is a great shame that this is the case. Here we have a golden opportunity, a chance to amend our principal body that promotes our tourist product overseas. We have a chance to ensure that the future of this body will be maximum in its effect. We have a chance to get the very best people that the industry has to offer to work within the ATC. Unfortunately, we are passing up that opportunity. Unfortunately, the Government is not prepared to pick up this somewhat harder recommendation in the Kennedy report-a recommendation that, no doubt, goes against the wishes of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, an organisation which is very much in association with this Government, and the union movement in general. But I still say to the House that the Government should have done it.

The net effect of what the Government has done is that the ATC will not be able to meet the market if it wishes to employ the best people for the job. In other words, the best people for the job will not bother to apply because of the inflexible nature of the Public Service. Wages will not be attractive enough so we will possibly end up with second stringers in the job. This is immensely sad; in fact, it is disastrous. Here we have the premier tourist promotion body in the land promoting an industry that we so desperately need and, because of this Government's gutless approach, we will find that it will not be able to do the job 100 per cent because it will not be able to employ the best.

This factor concerns all those in the industry. It concerns the authors of the Kennedy report and it concerns the Liberal and National parties because we believe that it is vital to have at the top of one of the most competitive industries in the world the very best possible talent to carry out the job. For these reasons we will be moving amendments in the committee stage that will relate to the application of private sector rules and conditions of employment. For the Government to reject these amendments would be a sheer act of stupidity-an exercise of sticking its head in the sand as far as it can go. I know that there are members of the Government who stand with me in this claim. I know that there are people right throughout the industry who recognise the importance of changing the terms and conditions of employment within the ATC.

Our fastest growing industry deserves the best. This Government is denying it the best. As a result, every Australian will pay the price. As I have said, our tourist industry has the potential to create immense wealth for Australia. It has the potential to create many jobs, for young Australians in particular, but because we will not be promoting it to the maximum that we could, every Australian will pay the price. Our standard of living will not be as high as it could be. The number of jobs created will not be as great as it could be because of this decision.

The ATC has recently moved it offices from Melbourne to Sydney. This has been an expensive move in more ways than one. It cost $3.3m to move, in effect, four public servants and some files and to provide adequate facilities for them. Of the 45 staff employed by the ATC in Melbourne, only four chose to move to Sydney. This cost the taxpayer $1.48m in severance and redundancy payments. The 41 staff who left each received from $5,000 upwards. In fact, the average payment was about $34,000. But the additional and intangible cost is that the ATC has been left with only a handful of experienced staff. It lost some of its best in the move-and I suppose, to be fair, it can be said that it also lost some of the worst. But either way the ATC is really strapped for experienced personnel at the moment.

Of the four people who moved from Melbourne to Sydney, one was the Executive Director, whilst others were people such as Annie Burfitt and Bill Gray. Annie Burfitt is now Director of Corporate Planning, which is a crucial role mapping out long term strategy for the tourist industry. I understand that as at the end of November she had no staff to assist her. That is a very big task-one of the biggest tasks within the whole operation of the ATC-for someone to carry out on her own. Mr Gray, a former journalist with the Melbourne Herald, who used to run the public relations section, has been skyrocketed in importance. He now heads four divisions within the ATC-public relations, advertising, publications and information. That is a mighty task for one person to perform.

I am quite sure that both these people are very competent at their tasks, but the purposes of these examples is to highlight how badly off the ATC now is under the Government's administration following this legislation. If we add to that the fact that the Commission cannot offer attractive wage packages to get the very best people, we will see that things will go from bad to worse. The cost of the move has had to be borne by the ATC from its normal operating funds, and that $3.3m represents about 10 per cent of its total budget. Mr Rowe, the Executive Director, said-I think at a Senate Estimates committee hearing-that this will have to come from the ATC's promotions budget, which is the only area of flexibility. This means that, in the year of our Bicentenary, when more than two million people from overseas will be visiting Australia, we will not be promoting and marketing Australia as a tourist destination as well as we should. At a time when more and more people want to come to this country, we will be spending, in effect, less and less on telling them how they can get here because of the Government's approach to the administration of the Australian Tourist Commission.

The other exclusion in this legislation from the Kennedy report relates to the tourism overseas promotion scheme (TOPS). I am grateful that this legislation gives me the chance to speak on this matter as it is in the eyes of the industry not only one of the biggest issues of the day but also one of the great scandals of this Government. TOPS, as it is known within the industry, was created to help Australian tourist operators to promote and market their product overseas. The collective good that this did for Australia is well documented. Its most enthusiastic supporter was the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mr John Brown) himself. I could quote from pages of documents quoting the Minister who was crowing about what a marvellous innovation TOPS was, how clever he was for introducing it and what good it was doing for the industry. He always had at the top of his list of achievements for the Labor Government for the tourist industry the creation of TOPS.

Tourist operators recognised the value of TOPS and used it to its fullest. It was one of their most popular activities in relation to the Australian Tourist Commission and the Department of Tourism. The Opposition also recognised the importance and effectiveness of TOPS. Despite the Minister's claims that the Liberal and National parties would axe TOPS if elected to Government-claims he made repeatedly throughout the campaign-we do support an effective overseas promotion scheme such as TOPS. The Minister was plainly wrong in his assertions. The proof is in black and white in our policy document. I believe that it was mischievous to state throughout the election campaign, as the Minister repeatedly did, that we would axe the scheme if we were elected to government. Of course, quite the opposite was the effect.

Because of the value of TOPS industry grew to use it extensively and, at the same time, it grew used to the processes of applying for funding. Earlier this year rumours circulated that TOPS would be cut out. Quick to respond, the Minister said that this was not the case. On 4 June he released a statement to put a stop to such `ill-informed and mischievous rumours'. A Press release dated 4 June 1987 and entitled `Tourism Overseas Scheme to Continue' states:

I am happy to say that the Government has agreed to a forward commitment cover for the Tourism Overseas Promotion Scheme (TOPS) of $9 million for 1987-88, Mr Brown, Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism said today.
The Press release continued:
TOPS is a sound Scheme which has been designed specifically for the tourism industry.
Those applications which have been held up pending the resolution of this matter will now be processed forthwith.

There we have, in unequivocal language, a clear statement from the Minister saying that TOPS would continue in the following year and that not only would it continue but also it would have an 80 per cent increase in its funding from about $5m a year to $9m a year. People in the industry heard this message loud and clear. People were told by the Minister that if they voted for Labor TOPS would continue; if they voted for the other lot it would be axed. Of course, this was a very persuasive argument in the whole scheme of things in winning votes in the tourist industry in the 11 July election. But since the election the Minister repeated those claims. I understand that even the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen) in a letter at the beginning of September continued to repeat the claim that TOPS would continue under a Labor Government. All of this was seen to be completely misleading. On Budget night the real truth was out-TOPS was axed. I quote from the Budget Speech of the Treasurer (Mr Keating). He said:
The Government is convinced now that the industry is able to conduct its own promotion activities without direct assistance . . .
It is for this reason the Government will end . . . (TOPS) . . . which had provided Government assistance to the industry for promotion activities.

There we have a clear indication of the Minister, on the one hand, saying that the scheme would continue and would have its budget increased by 80 per cent and, on the other hand, only weeks later the Treasurer saying, `Sorry, ladies and gentlemen, TOPS will no longer exist. You do not need it. It is now officially axed'. That decision has left the industry in uproar with claims that it was taken for a sucker and led up the electoral garden path. I have spoken to so many people over the last few months about this issue. I have spoken to people who had applications pending, applications which received a registration number, applications which according to them met the guidelines, applications which, if funding were to be continued and increased in 1987-88, would certainly have been successful and would have received funding. All of those people are very upset at what the Minister and this Government have done.

If we are to appreciate the impact that that has had, we have to recognise that the tourist industry is basically made up of small businessmen. Very few operators are like the Hiltons, the Sheratons or the Regents; more likely they are small hotel or motel proprietors, small tourist operators, bus companies, boat charters, restaurants and so on. So the funding that TOPS represented to them could in some cases have made the difference between bankruptcy and viability. I do not use exaggerated language when I say that.

Since the Government's backdown on TOPS I have been inundated with correspondence expressing outrage and concern. Many people have told me outright that their overseas promotion from this day on is over, that they simply cannot afford to do it without help. The damage that this reaction will have on the potential income tourism could generate for Australia is inestimable. It will, without doubt, reduce the number of people who will come here in the future. It will do it because TOPS helped to ensure that people such as travel agents had all the information that was necessary in order to get tourists into this country, to inform those tourists what is available in this country, to inform them as to how they can travel around within the country. TOPS provided all of those services and those services will now no longer be available. Our industry will certainly suffer.

TALK.START.PARA: —A breach of contract.

—It is a breach of contract. The industry is looking at that from a legal point of view at this very moment. I know that in 12 months time the Minister will trot out figures attempting to show that my last comments are false. He will show that tourist numbers have increased dramatically. That no doubt will happen. How much more would they have increased if TOPS had been left to operate? How much more income would have been generated? How much more employment would have been created? These points are the relevant ones to consider. To try to deny them is to attempt to hide from reality. There is no doubt that we will not achieve our full potential because of this decision to axe TOPS. Over the last few weeks the Minister has tried to play down this breach of faith. May I say to the House that this has fooled no one except perhaps himself. I want to quote some people who have written to me expressing their feelings about the Minister's actions. I remind the House that these words are not my own words; they are the words of people who are desperate, who have been seriously let down by the Government. I quote from a letter from a reasonably sized company based in New South Wales. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: My major objection is the blatant dishonesty with which John Brown at every possible opportunity was coaxing companies to spend big and promote overseas.
To be duped by the Government . . . is nothing more than a dishonest copout by someone who obviously couldn't properly manage and administer the scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. There needs to be a substantive motion if an accusation of dishonesty is made against a member of the House.

—The Minister has a valid point of order in that an honourable member may not abuse Standing Orders by quoting from correspondence, reports or newspaper articles of any sort as the honourable member for Gilmore is doing. I ask him to avoid references which are of a personal nature.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I shall continue with this quote as I do not think any of it contravenes Standing Orders. The letter continues:

SPEECH.PARA: The tourism industry will no longer trust, support or co-operate with any project where Mr Brown and his Department-
that is, the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and the Territories-
are involved.
I refer to a letter from another reasonably sized company in New South Wales. It states:
We expended these monies-
that is, moneys it spent on overseas promotion-
in good faith after numerous reassurances from the Government that TOPS would continue.
These funds are essential to our survival.
A smaller company from Western Australia writes:
A grave injustice has been perpetrated.
I feel that the Government has misled us and let us down.
In the view of our company and our industry colleagues what the Government has done is totally immoral . . .
We lost $30,000-a huge amount for small business.
A company from Darwin in the Northern Territory wrote:
I am extremely disappointed in your failure-
the letter is to the Minister-
to uphold the promises made to us at the Australian Tourism Exchange in June this year . . .
I would not have undertaken promotions of this dimension without having believed in your commitment to this scheme.
For a new small business struggling to get established the withdrawal of this subsidy is devastating.
A company in Victoria, a reasonably sized bus coach company, wrote:
This organisation has found it necessary to virtually chop most of our budget for international activities.
This organisation has found it necessary to cancel our visit to the Japanese marketplace and it is purely based on having to adjust our budgets.
A Queensland firm says:
Assurances at A.T.E. Sydney June 1987 said that this scheme would continue and helped boost my plans for the future.

I am faced with having to curtail some of my projects-I will not be employing additional staff as planned-in fact I am now very much considering the prospect of making cuts in the existing number of employees.
I feel my integrity is being questioned.

These are words of the industry. They are not my words; they are the words of people out there who have been adversely affected by the decision of the Government, adversely affected by statements made by the Minister. I am afraid on this occasion neither the Minister nor the Government can wriggle out of this one. Their credibility has been put to the test.

The other area that is causing concern within the industry in relation to this legislation is that the Government, in cahoots with the Democrats, has effectively weakened the Australian Tourist Commission by turning it into some sort of sociological and environmental watchdog. Now, thanks to this Government, the Australian Tourist Commission, with no extra resources of personnel, has to monitor and report on the effects that international tourism has on the environment. This may sound like noble stuff. Everybody on this side of the House has a genuine concern about the environment. Certainly I recognise that as far as tourism is concerned protection of the environment is vital. It is vital because it is the environment that we sell in the tourist industry. We do not sell softer beds or hotter showers; the tourist industry sells the Australian environment. It is in the best interests of every tourism operator to protect, to maintain and indeed to enhance it. So everybody is agreed that the environment is very important, but the ridiculous nature of these inclusions into the role and functions of the ATC are unbelievable.

The ATC-and I can say that this view is shared unanimously in the industry-should be wholly and solely out there promoting and marketing our tourist product overseas. If we divert its attention away from that we do the industry and Australians a disservice. There are countless State and Federal government bodies set up at taxpayers' expense to monitor the environmental effects of all sorts of things. I did some quick research into the matter, courtesy of the Parliamentary Library and I discovered hundreds of such bodies. I have here lists of State and Federal government bodies set up to monitor the environment. Many of them have already put out reports on the effect of tourism on the environment. There must be 20 or 30 pages in the list of existing government bodies which deal with the environment. How the Government expects to maintain any respect within the tourist industry with this sort of inclusion is beyond me. It is a disgrace. It is not necessary. All the Government is doing is duplicating existing services.

Another disturbing aspect of the legislation was an inclusion within the Bill which gave the Minister the power to direct, in secret, the Board of the Australian Tourist Commission and, having given that direction, to expect the Board to follow it to the letter and not to reveal the existence of the direction if the Minister deemed it in the public interest so to do. This is an extraordinary inclusion. Not even the Treasurer has that sort of power of secret direction. One can only guess that this sort of power would be necessary if the nation's security were in question. But we are not dealing with a national security organisation; we are dealing with Australia's Tourist Commission. To give the Tourism Minister this extraordinary power is unnecessary and I believe the claims that it is outrageous are valid. Surely the Minister does not want to give directions to the Board of the Australian Tourist Commission that he believes need to be covered up. I am glad that at least one of our amendments in the Senate was agreed to by the Democrats and an alteration was subsequently made by the Government. If this had not been done a very nasty precedent would have been set.

The final concern with the legislation relates to appointments to the Board of the Australian Tourist Commission. Now the Board of nine members will be completely appointed by the Minister. This creates the opportunities for claims of jobs for the boys. The Liberal and National parties propose a very simple solution to this; that is, appoint two representatives from a panel of names from the Australian Travel Industry Association as nominated by the board of directors of that Association. This would guarantee that there is a flow of information between the peak industry body representing tourism-and it is that despite the Government's attempts to state otherwise-and the Board of the ATC.

The amendment accepted by the Government is a very clever trick designed to fool the Democrats. As the amendment reads now, our amendment is superseded by one which states that two representatives be selected from a national tourist industry representative body. In other words, anyone who is a member of any one of a number of national tourist industry organisations can be deemed to be the industry representatives on the Board of the ATC. I can assure the House that nobody, with the exception of the Democrats, will be fooled by that.

Overall, the Kennedy report is very good. It sets in place the way in which the Government should structure our Australian Tourist Commission. Unfortunately, this Government has neither the courage nor the interest to follow this move to its full potential. I believe the ATC is now a weaker body than it could have been. It has consumed a large proportion of its funds moving from Melbourne to Sydney. It has lost its experienced personnel and will be a long time replacing that experience. It has been given a new role and function-that of monitoring the environment, without any extra skills or resources to carry it out-thus diverting its efforts from its proper function. And it has also lost the chance to employ the best people to promote our fastest growing industry and our brightest light on the economic horizon by not giving it the flexibility of private sector terms and conditions of employment. At the same time the Government has done its best to offend the tourist industry's peak association by denying it representation on the board. All in all, the Government has done a good job of messing up a damned good report and an industry with heaps of potential. As a result of this legislation and the Government's decision to axe TOPS the Government has lost respect and credibility in the eyes of the tourist operators of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLeay Mr L.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight the Parliament is discussing the restructuring of the Australian Tourist Commission (ATC), which is just another example of this Government doing its very best to assist the development of the tourism business in Australia. However, from listening to the Opposition spokesman, the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp), with his negative, carping criticism, one would have thought that we were considering something else altogether. The Opposition says that it believes the Government's approach to tourism is gutless. The Opposition spokesman repeated that accusation throughout his speech. I hoped that I would hear from the honourable member for Gilmore a policy from the Opposition on what it might do if it were ever the Government of Australia. But once again all we heard from the Opposition was negative, carping criticism. There was no recognition that this Government has done more for the tourism industry than any government in the past, no recognition of the work that the current Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mr John Brown) has done to develop the tourism industry and no recognition that this restructuring of the Australian Tourist Commission will do something to assist the flow of tourists to Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I suppose in listening to the honourable member for Gilmore we were really hearing the echo rather than the substance of the Opposition's position on tourism. Recalling speeches on this matter in the past, we will really hear the Opposition's point of view on tourism when the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) speaks in this debate after me. The unfortunate thing from the Opposition's point of view is that the fellow who knows all about tourism on its side of the House is on the back bench and the fellow who purports to know-that is, the honourable member for Gilmore-is on the front bench. I suppose in many ways that points up the weakness in the Opposition in that the empty vessels that make the most sound are put on to the front bench to bay and make the most noise and the people of substance are kept on the back bench. While I had hoped to hear something from the honourable member for Gilmore about tourism, obviously I will have to wait to hear from the honourable member for Fadden and other Opposition members to find out something about this subject.

TALK.START.PARA: —You will never sit on the front bench so I would be a bit careful.

—The honourable member for Farrer is also one of those empty vessels that make most of the noise in this House. I think that the restructuring of the Australian Tourist Commission is very much a function of the work of the Kennedy committee-the Australian Government Inquiry into Tourism. That committee presented a two-volume report, which the Government commissioned, and brought down 96 specific recommendations, the great majority of which have been implemented by the Government. The recommendations cover the whole breadth of what we should be doing in the tourism industry in Australia. I think that Mr Jim Kennedy, the chairman of the committee, and the other members of the committee-Mr Donohoe, the Chairman of the Tourism Commission of New South Wales; Miss Paton, the publisher of the Australian; Mr Derry, the General Marketing Manager of Ansett Airlines of Australia; and Mr Klein, who was the Senior Private Secretary to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories-did an excellent job in terms of the report which they brought down.

SPEECH.PARA: It is very interesting to look at the people who were on that committee because this gives an indication of the lengths to which the Government will go to get the best input into how we should restructure public authorities. The Deputy Chairman of the Australian Tourist Commission, the Chairman of a State tourist commission, the publisher of the only national daily newspaper in Australia, the General Marketing Manager of one of the major airlines in the country and a senior public servant were on the committee. That is the type of input that one would expect one should have in terms of a government inquiry. One would have thought that, with that type of input, the Opposition's response to the Government's acceptance of most of the committee's recommendations would have been more than, as the Opposition spokesman said, a gutless approach by the Government. I do not know what the Government has to do to attract the support of Opposition members, but it tends to be more and more a case of their taking their bat and ball home rather than attempting to have a real influence on the direction that Australia and the marketing of government instrumentalities will take. As I said earlier, all we hear from the Opposition is carping criticism.

It should be remembered that the Australian Tourist Commission legislation was first brought into this House about 20 years ago. Frequently we hear the Opposition say that there should be reviews and sunset clauses. Twenty years on the Government has said that we will look at the legislation and make some changes. The changes will ensure that the ATC becomes a more lean body. Quite frankly, there were too many people on the previous Commission. Various sectional interests were represented. Other sectional interests claimed that they were not getting copies of papers, and so on. The whole thing was becoming a dog's breakfast. This time the Government has sought to make the ATC competitive, so it can get on with the job of selling Australia overseas and attracting people to this country. In combination with changing the Commission and moving its headquarters from Melbourne to Sydney, the measures contained in the Bill will allow ATC precisely to get on with that-encouraging people to come to Australia. When they get here, the State and Territory tourism organisations can rightly help them to decide on which destination in Australia they should go to. The important thing for us to do as a national government is to get tourists to Australia.

I believe that the current Labor Government's record in this area is the envy of the world. In view of the carping attitude of the Opposition, it is obviously the envy of the Opposition as well. Since coming to office in 1983, the Labor Government has overseen a remarkable growth in international visitor arrivals. Under the previous Liberal Government in 1983, we have gone from 900,000 arrivals to an estimated 2.2 million arrivals this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much is that again?

—It is estimated that this year there will be 2.2 million arrivals. The Opposition says that that has nothing to do with the Labor Government. My goodness, I do not know whom it has to do with. Certainly it has nothing to do with the honourable member for Gilmore who can only stand up in here and attack people. He is a carping, sniping, lazy Opposition member. The easiest thing for a person in opposition to do is to get up and whinge. We are in government because we sat down when in opposition and worked out ways to be the government of Australia. All we hear from the knockers on the other side is what we have done wrong. The honourable member for Gilmore said that because someone in Melbourne did not like having to move to Sydney the Government should abort its program to move the Commission's headquarters. I can say to the honourable member that if he could ever come up with something that increased the number of arrivals to Australia from 900,000 to 2.2 million, he might end up sitting on this side of the House. Instead, all we get from the honourable member is a number of pieces attacking people personally-indeed, Mr Deputy Speaker, you had to pull him up to stop him from that with some little funny story about the monorail at Ayers Rock.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government has put a real effort into the increasing the number of arrivals into this country. It is interesting that we hear this carping criticism from members of the National Party of Australia. Some of the people who have been able to profit the most from what this Government has done have been the honourable member's colleagues in Queensland. What this Government has done for tourism in Queensland has been the envy of everybody. Because of the activities of this Government people are now arriving in Cairns, Townsville and Brisbane, which was not the case before. It is interesting that under this Government the tourism and hospitality industry has a net value of $24 billion. Under the stewardship of the colleagues of the honourable member for Gilmore in 1983, it was $8 billion. But the honourable member for Gilmore says that we are a gutless bunch and that we have made some awful mistakes. We have managed to improve this country's income from tourism and hospitality from $8 billion to only $24 billion! If that is an example of gutlessness, I hope that we keep it up. A whole lot of people in this country who are profiting from this industry were not doing anything in it when the honourable member for Gilmore and his colleagues were on the treasury bench. I think the work that the honourable member for Parramatta, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, has done has been magnificent for the tourism industry in Australia. One of the reasons he has done such a good job is that he has been willing to listen not only to the industry but also to his colleagues. Indeed, if the honourable member for Gilmore came up with something for him to listen to, he would listen to that. I know that he listens to what the honourable member for Fadden says because the honourable for Fadden, unlike the rest of the Opposition, makes a lot of sense on this subject.

I have two brief points that I would like to mention which the Minister might like to take on board and do something about. The first and most important is that we need to do something about the congestion at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. The stock answer from the Opposition on that is, `Let's build another runway'. Of course, there are many other things that one can do at Sydney Airport than build another runway. One is to have a look at the flow of inbound traffic to Australia and in particular at where people stop off before the plane gets to Sydney. If the honourable member for Gilmore had thought about this, which of course he has not, but my friend the honourable member for Fadden has, he would realise that one of the smartest things that we could do is process people arriving in Australia in Brisbane. I would like the Government to take this on board. When the flights from Japan that go on to Sydney stopover in Brisbane for an hour, rather than just having the tourists sitting around in the transit lounge, we might look at doing some of the Customs, health or immigration checks.

I see that the honourable member for Fadden, who is an expert in this area, agrees with me. That would be a sensible way to use the Customs, quarantine and immigration personnel in Brisbane. It would ensure a much more speedy through-put at the terminal in Sydney. I would like the Minister to have a think about that proposal. I think that when the Government Pharmacists properly considers it, it will realise that that is something intelligent to do. I feel sorry for the poor member for Gilmore. He is sitting there looking at me wishing that he had thought of that himself. If he had talked to his mate, the honourable member for Fadden, he might have put him up to it. However--

TALK.START.PARA: —They don't get much chance to think.
—As the Minister says, the Opposition front bench members do not get a chance to think much--
—Cut that out.

—With the exception of some of the more astute people from Tasmania. Unfortunately for the honourable member for Bass, he probably will not be around if the Opposition ever gets over to this side of the chamber. He is pretty young now, but he will probably be older than the Minister for Employment Services and Youth Affairs (Mr Holding) and me by the time that he gets to this side of the House.

SPEECH.PARA: The other thing that I would like the Government to look at, and which I know the Minister is interested in, is the question of in-bound duty-free-one of the larger industries in Australia. Unfortunately, at present some of the operators working in the in-bound duty free industry, especially at Sydney Airport, are not willing to provide the whole range of Australian products that should be made available. It is not good enough to have just cigarettes, whisky and perfumes for sale. There should be offered a range of electronic and other items that people really wish to buy. I ask the Minister to turn his mind to that.

I look forward to hearing the genuine Opposition position on tourism when the honourable member for Fadden speaks in the continuation of this debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I wish to take this opportunity to apprise the House of the sterling work undertaken in my electorate and surrounding electorates by the Waverley Employment Resource Centre, the WERC. The WERC administers a highly successful employment training scheme that assists unemployed people of all ages and the school leavers of Waverley to obtain work through suitable training. The Centre was created in May 1984 by the Waverley City Council and, since its creation 3 1/2 years ago, the Council has financed its operations throughout. During its time of operation, approximately 700 unemployed residents of Waverley have moved into the work force. The program has a consistently high 75 to 80 per cent success rate.

SPEECH.PARA: The objectives of the Centre are to prepare each job seeker for his or her role in the work force, and to make a common meeting ground between employers and potential employees. People attending the Centre are taught the skills related to accepted personal presentation, which include good telephone manners as well as the ability to express themselves comfortably and adequately in a job interview. They are assisted with letters of application and equipped with a resume. They are then guided through all the channels of job advertised resources and ongoing supported assistance continues to be given until they are employed.

The Waverley Employment Resource Centre is very well supported by the local community, including the four Rotary clubs in the area which provide representation on the advisory committee and volunteers who assist with the Centre's training programs. Other volunteers provide administrative and clerical support when needed. Furthermore, the Centre works closely with the Commonwealth Employment Service office at Mount Waverley with the manager of the office being a member of the Centre's advisory committee. This scheme not only assists young people to have a real future, but also assists in restoring a mutual respect between employers and the people from WERC who have been `groomed' to match employer needs.

The unemployment figures in the Municipality of Waverley have without doubt been considerably reduced through the operations of WERC. I might add, Madam Speaker, that this service is provided by the Waverley City Council free of charge to its users. However, there is now a very real possibility that this excellent and pioneering service may have to be closed because of a lack of funds. The cost of maintaining the Centre, which is borne solely by the Waverley Council, is proving to be financially onerous for the City of Waverley. Both the Centre and I have attempted to alert the Federal Government to the Centre's plight and secure Commonwealth funding to ensure the Centre's survival.

On 22 September 1987, I wrote to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) strongly urging him to grant the necessary funds to WERC to ensure the continued operation of this unique, successful and very worthwhile resource. By way of reply I received a letter from the Minister's office, dated 17 November 1987, enclosing a copy of the letter to Mr Leo Canning, Chairman of the Centre's advisory committee. The letter, signed by a Mr Garth Lampe, a First Assistant Secretary, whilst not directly saying no to funding, says in the last paragraph:
I trust that the Centre will be successful in securing funds to enable its continued operation.

In other words, I think it is fair to say that the very Department responsible for employment and training is washing its hands of an organisation with a proven and successful track record in employment and training-the WERC. This Government has spent hundreds of millions of dollars of taxpayers' money in its efforts to fight unemployment, particularly the crisis of unemployed youth. If this Government is really concerned with tackling the basic issues of unemployment rather than concentrating on the public relations value of the next new job scheme it could not do better than provide funding to the very effective WERC.

Finally, I would like to say, for the benefit of the Minister more than anyone, that the Waverley Council at a meeting last week voted to continue funding the Centre until the end of its financial year. Considering the financial pressures that the Centre places on the Council's overall budget, the Waverley Council is to be much commended for its sense of civic duty in maintaining financial support for the Centre. On the other hand, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, together with his Department, should hang their heads in shame. If the financial pressures do indeed force the closure of the WERC it will be as a result of this Government's insensitive and callous attitude towards the unemployed, especially those in the City of Waverley and in my electorate of Bruce generally.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In 1960, Cyprus became an independent republic and its sovereignty and territorial integrity were guaranteed by the treaty of guarantee signed by Britain, Turkey and Greece. In 1974, northern Cyprus was invaded by Turkey and what later was purported to be an independent state in northern Cyprus was proclaimed. About 50,000 Turks were settled in northern Cyprus as a result of the invasion and occupation of that area. In the process of that occupation about 180,000 Greek Cypriot refugees were forced to flee the northern area, leaving their homes and properties.

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight I just want to draw attention to the fact that last month a few hundred brave Greek Cypriot women braved the minefields at the border of the northern state to storm the United Kingdom controlled buffer zone to reach the Turkish Cypriot north for the first time in 13 years. The report indicates that the demonstration was orderly. Of course, the women subjected themselves to considerable danger. What they were attempting to do was to reassert the right of Greek Cypriots to return to the land which they had occupied, the land in which they still own property and from which they were forced to flee, leaving their homes and other possessions.

I am delighted that the position which the Australian Government has adopted in relation to this unfortunate situation which prevails in Cyprus has been made perfectly clear, by both the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden). Only recently, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade wrote to members on the Government side, and perhaps to other honourable members as well, to indicate the Government's attitude towards Cyprus, because Australia had abstained in regard to a particular question which came before the Human Rights Commission of the United Nations. I think that that action on Australia's part has, in some quarters, been misunderstood. I do not think it should be taken to suggest or to imply in any way that Australia's attitude towards the Cypriot question and Cypriot problem has, in any way, been reduced. In that recent letter the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade said in very positive terms:
The Government-
that is, the Hawke Government-

remains firmly in favour of a peaceful negotiated settlement of the Cyprus problem which would provide for the independence, sovereignty, territorial integrity, unity and non-aligned status of Cyprus. We continue to support the negotiating efforts of the United Nations Secretary-General as the most promising means by which such a result can be achieved.

Australia continues to give its full support to the Government of the Republic of Cyprus. We continue to recognise it as the sole legitimate government in Cyprus and we refuse to give any recognition to the claims of the so-called ``Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus''. We condemn the continue presence in Cyprus of Turkish troops. Against this background it is clear that Australia supports the legitimate concerns of the Government of the Republic of Cyprus and is concerned for the human rights dimensions of the issue.

There is only one country in the world which recognises northern Cyprus as a separate republic in Cyprus-that is Turkey. No other country recognises it, nor should any other country in the world. Australia does not, and Australia will not. In order to restore the rights of the people of Cyprus, particularly the Creek Cypriots who were forced to flee from their homes as a result of that illegal invasion and occupation of northern Cyprus, it is quite clear that the Turkish armies should be withdrawn. The present build-up of forces in northern Cyprus which threatens the integrity and independence of Cyprus should immediately cease. The Greek Cypriots should be given the opportunity to return to their homes in northern Cyprus.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take a few minutes tonight to talk about a matter that has been raised in this House before. In a bipartisan way I wish to join with my counterpart on the Government side of the House, the Minister for Science and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones), in speaking about the importance of superconductors.
—What about the Nella Dan? He let that sink.

—Perhaps we will talk about that tomorrow. There is a need for research in Australia into superconducting materials which, if they can be improved, could result in incredibly cheap power and usher in a torrent of stunning possibilities. What is superconductivity? Superconductivity is the ability to convert electricity with no energy loss. Since no energy is lost, any electrical device becomes far more efficient when built with superconductors. Materials differ in their ability to conduct energy. Some are very poor conductors-we use them to insulate our homes-while others, all metals, are quite good conductors. However, these conventional conductors lose a proportion of the energy they carry because the energy-carrying electrons are scattered by thermal vibrations and impurities. Copper wire, for example, soaks up 5 per cent to 15 per cent of the electricity that surges through it. This is expensive. A study by California's Pacific Gas and Electric indicated that its losses through copper wire amounted to $US200m a year.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem with superconducting, a phenomenon discovered early this century, has been that it could only be achieved at extremely low temperatures, that is about minus 273 degrees celsius. The expense involved in handling liquid helium to achieve these temperatures makes any commercial application unthinkable. The challenge then is to find a material that will superconduct at higher temperatures. Two years ago, Karl Muller of Switzerland and Johannes Bednoz of West Germany, who received the Nobel Prize in Physics this year, discovered a new ceramic that raised the temperature to minus 238 degrees celsius. Since then other researchers have used similar materials to achieve superconductivity at even higher temperatures. Paul Chu and his colleagues at Houston University reached minus 175 degrees celsius. In July this year, his team observed superconductivity at minus 43 degrees celsius-well above the temperature of dry ice and conventional freezers. The goal is to push the limit to 60 to 70 degrees celsius, more or less room temperature.

What materials have this magical superconductive capacity? It is ironic that the new superconducting materials-ceramics-are those that usually act as insulators at room temperatures. The specific types of ceramics that have been found to do the job of superconducting are those based on `rare earths', in particular, barium and yttrium. We will be hearing a lot more about these elements in the years ahead. The problem is that while the superconductors are easily made-the oxides are ground into dust, fired, then pressed into their final shape-their quality is uneven. Some tend to crumble when produced in batches. The Soviets, for example, have already produced a room temperature superconductor material, but its shelf life is less than a day. All the products are brittle and the most disturbing factor is that scientists have no idea how these normally non-conductive oxides conduct energy at certain temperatures. There is a great deal of work still to be done. That is the point the Minister made back in October.

What are the possibilities and/or applications of superconductors? They are many and various. Among them are superfast trains, floating on invisible magnetic tracks; pea-sized supercomputers; frictionless bearings; and more powerful medical imaging machines. However, one of the most important possibilities in an energy hungry world is 100 per cent efficient power lines which will result in incredibly cheap energy. The most immediate possibilities are for short distance links of a few millimetres within computers. However, some researchers predict that superconducting transmission lines for long distance communications could become a possibility. These would have 100 times the capacity of optical fibres.

Why should Australia be involved? What should Australia be doing? We should be more involved than we are. Australia has the research strength in solid state physics, crystallography, and superconductivity physics. My plea is that we make a far more substantial commitment to further research in this premier high technology area. Indeed, that was the Minister's plea in October. There is no doubt that Australia will be left behind the rest of the world unless we recognise our potential to contribute to research in this area. Japan, the United States and the Soviet Union have all launched crash programs, and we must do the same. There is no doubt that superconductivity is becoming the glamour industry for the future. National recognition of this high technology revolution which is now under way is crucial if Australia is to have any part in its development. I ask at least those honourable members on the Government side who have an interest in this matter to make sure that the Government responds, at least through the agency of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, by providing more funds to do the job that is vitally necessary for all of us.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today marks the twelfth anniversary of the invasion and occupation of East Timor. East Timor is little more than 500 kilometres from my office in Darwin. East Timor has been sealed off from the rest of the world, with the exception of some carefully guided delegations, for the past 12 years. The city of Darwin and its people welcomed the thousands of East Timorese refugees who fled their country during and post-1975. I now have the responsibility of representing the largest population of East Timorese in any electorate in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Some 3,500 Timorese now live and work in Darwin. While many have settled and prospered in the country that welcomed them to its shores, the continuing denial of human rights and lack of progress in negotiations to settle the issue of self-determination for East Timorese people remains a point of bitterness and betrayal for these members of my electorate. Darwin, of course, has been the location of several radio transmitters set up to maintain contact with Fretilin forces. These transmissions have been a vital, if legal, source of information to the outside world of the current struggle that continues in East Timor. As we enter the thirteenth year of the occupation of East Timor by Indonesian forces, it is clear that the present situation is marked by gross violations of human rights.

The report by Amnesty International released in 1985 detailed extra-judicial executions, disappearances, systematic torture and political imprisonment of the local population. The report of the Uniting Church's Social Responsibility and Justice Committee, published in June this year, states in part in relation to East Timor:
Freedom of speech and assembly are heavily curtailed, Press censorship is part of daily life and the right to organise is very restricted.
Most importantly, the report states:
The actions of the Indonesian Government suggest that the intention is to destroy the East Timorese people, spiritually and culturally.

Since 1975 it is reported that some 200,000 East Timorese people, or a third of the population, have died in the conflict with Indonesians. This is nothing short of genocide. It is alleged that Timorese women are being forced into family planning programs and that Indonesian language has replaced the indigenous Timorese language in schools. The East Timorese fear that they will become a minority in their own land.

East Timorese resistance fighters continue to wage war against the Indonesians. The Government of Indonesia claims that the people of East Timor have already exercised their right to self-determination. They claim that Fretilin is now only a rag-tag band of guerrillas. I ask the obvious question: if this is the case, why does East Timor remain sealed off from the rest of the international community? If there is nothing to hide, open the doors to East Timor. The issue of East Timor remains a compelling one, both in terms of basic principles of international law and by virtue of the thousands of lives that have been lost on this small island over the past 12 years. The history of the position of successive Australian governments on this issue is well known and, I am afraid, is not an inspiring one. It is difficult at times to understand Australia's priorities in terms of its defence of human rights and self-determination when so often we prefer to ignore what is happening in our own backyard.

In a more general sense the Western history of colonialism and exploitation hardly justifies our claiming to be the champions of human rights. We in the West do not have any proprietorial claims to `universal humanist' values. Such ideas transcend time and place; they transcend arbitrary geographical boundaries. If we in Australia wish to be considered as adherents to the universal values of human rights and of cultural, religious and political freedom of the right to self-determination, we must be consistent. We must be consistent both within our national boundaries and in our relations with other countries.

Over the past 12 years the struggle for self-determination of the East Timorese has taken place on two fronts. There has been, and continues to be, the physical war fought in the hills and countryside of the island. The other front has been the diplomatic war-the war that we are part of that is essential to the final solution for the people of East Timor. I am firmly of the belief that we must renew our efforts to bring about a negotiated settlement. But that settlement must not be dictated from the top. The people of East Timor must be allowed to have a voice in any political settlement regarding their country's future. It is not only the governments of Portugal and Indonesia which should determine the final outcome of any political settlement regarding their country's future. The representatives of East Timor, the East Timorese people, must be allowed to partake in these discussions. There must be unrestricted access allowed by international humanitarian agencies in East Timor. There should be positive action taken on family reunification and emigration.

Finally, I wish to make this pledge to my Timorese constituents: while ever I take my place in the House as a member for the Northern Territory, I will continue to support and make representations on their behalf to ensure a just and durable peace in East Timor.
